fields.headline: The best lake scene
fields.standfirst: The Iron Giant
fields.trailText: A lakefront in rural Maine. Local beatnik Dean (voiced by Harry Connick Jr) sits with the seven-year-old Hogarth (Eli Marienthal) and his new best friend The Iron Giant (Vin Diesel).
fields.body:
A lakefront in rural Maine. Local beatnik Dean (voiced by Harry Connick Jr) sits with the seven-year-old Hogarth (Eli Marienthal) and his new best friend The Iron Giant (Vin Diesel).

Hogarth suddenly jumps to his feet and runs headlong towards the water: with a triumphant cry he plunges in. Shivering, he turns back to his companions.

"Come on in! The water's great!"

Dean boggles at the shuddering figure before him, then bursts out laughing.

"No thanks."

Hogarth turns to The Iron Giant, who hovers uncertainly at the edge of the water.

"Come on in, it's really very refreshing."

The Iron Giant silently turns and walks away from the lakefront, almost disappearing out of sight.

"What, you too?" Dean scoffs. "You big baby."

With the tremendous clunking of vast metal footsteps, The Iron Giant emerges from the woods at the far end of the beach, his huge legs striding towards the water. He leaps feet first into the lake.

As he hits the water, an enormous wave erupts. Several fish and a bedraggled racoon fly past the screen, before we cut to Hogarth, who has been flung from the lake and is now stuck in a tree. The Iron Giant's head pops up above the surface of the water.

See also: Friday The 13th, The Good Son, Funny Games

Don't see also: Alligator II - The Mutation

Pointless trivia: Having been raised in New Orleans, Harry Connick Jr later returned there to found a Mardi Gras "krewe" called Orpheus.

fields.headline: Leader: German sleaze inquiry
fields.standfirst: Not just Kohl but national politics on trial
fields.trailText: The fall and fall of Helmut Kohl, the longest-serving German chancellor of the 20th century, provides an unedifying and puzzling spectacle. As leader of the Christian Democrats from 1973, Dr Kohl quickly established an unassailable grip on his party.
fields.body:
The fall and fall of Helmut Kohl, the longest-serving German chancellor of the 20th century, provides an unedifying and puzzling spectacle. As leader of the Christian Democrats from 1973, Dr Kohl quickly established an unassailable grip on his party.

He lost his first national contest, against Helmut Schmidt's Social Democrats, in 1976. But once he had been elected chancellor for the first time, in 1982, there was no looking back. The larger-than-life former Rhineland Palatinate premier came to embody a confident and prosperous West Germany, dominating not only its domestic politics, but the development of the European Union as well.

When the Berlin Wall came down in 1989, a sense of inevitability swiftly enveloped Dr Kohl's determined drive towards German reunification. Despite the doubts of many of his own people (and the barely disguised hostility of Margaret Thatcher), he made Germany whole again. When he finally left office last year, his defeat by Gerhard Schröder was seen as nothing less than honourable. He looked set to end his career as a respected, elder statesman, secure in his historical place and liked, if not loved (Dr Kohl was never a politician to inspire passion), by allies and adversaries alike.

Not any more. In the space of a few weeks, Dr Kohl's reputation has been torn apart. He stands accused of channelling undeclared contributions from unidentified supporters into secret CDU accounts. This money, amounting at the very least to $1m, was allegedly paid to local party officials and organisations. The period under scrutiny dates back to 1993, but in fact CDU records relating to the whole period of Dr Kohl's leadership may well be re-examined.

While Dr Kohl denies any wrongdoing, he has admitted accepting undeclared party donations, which is in itself an apparent violation of electoral law. These revelations have laid him open to more serious charges of fraud, money-laundering and abuse of power, issues now under formal investigation by prosecutors in Bonn and by a committee of the Bundestag. Dr Kohl has meanwhile refused to name the secret donors. It is, he says, a matter of trust.

He is right. The inquiries now in train into Dr Kohl's conduct promise to be both complicated and protracted. His hope that he will be able quickly to clear his name now looks forlorn. Nor does Mr Schröder's SPD, enjoying its rivals' discomfiture, have much interest in resolving the problem rapidly.

All the same, these matters should be looked at with urgency. If the accusations against Dr Kohl are even partially proved, the consequences will be far-reaching. Many dozens of people in the CDU, past and present, will potentially be implicated. His CDU successor, Wolfgang Schäuble, has already been drawn in and asked to explain a mysterious movement of funds. Businesses and individuals who made secret donations will be asked to explain their motives in doing so, and what benefits they may have derived in return. The campaign finance practices of the other main political parties will necessarily come under scrutiny. Questions will be raised about the role of the tax authorities, and other regulators who, it seems, may have been so comprehensively bamboozled.

And before it grows sanctimonious, the German media may want to ask itself why its investigative journalists seem to have missed such an extraordinary, long-running story. If Dr Kohl is guilty, he should leave public life. But it seems there may be a broader guilt here, something systemic. The Kohl affair raises a much bigger question of how German politics works.

fields.headline: Cheerio, boyo
fields.standfirst: Victory in the valleys: a cultural revolution has put more  women in positions of power. Helen Wilkinson gives  three cheers for the feminisation of Welsh politics
fields.trailText: 4 January 2000: Victory in the valleys: a cultural revolution has put more women in positions of power. Helen Wilkinson gives three cheers for the feminisation of Welsh politics.
fields.body:
Welsh Labour politics is typically defined by its macho culture: working men's clubs, rugby union, male voice choirs. But at the end of the 20th century, that culture collided with Welsh feminism and, in round one at least, Welsh feminism won through.

The turning point came last January when Anita Gayle, a feisty 59-year-old who was then General Secretary of the Welsh Labour Party, turned up at Cynon Valley's selection meeting to enforce the controversial twinning process for selecting Assembly candidates which the local party was refusing to implement. A voice from the back yelled: 'You're nothing but a feminist and a trollop' but Gayle was undeterred. She told the members in no uncertain terms that those not prepared to abide by the party's rules should leave.

The majority stayed and from that moment the twinning campaign - whereby two constituency parties jointly selected two candidates from a shortlist, one man and one woman, then allocated one to fight each seat - was won. Months later, the public delivered their verdict and a new, more feminised Wales was born, with an Assembly whose 40% female membership put it way ahead of the national trend. The Labour group in the Welsh Assembly enters the new millennium boasting more women than men and a cabinet that is, excluding leader Alun Michael, entirely equal. Moreover, Edwina Hart's position as economic secretary signals women's entry into jobs traditionally perceived as men's.

But it has not all been plain sailing. Many women who went for Assembly seats encountered hostility. Val Feld, former director of the Welsh EOC and now Assembly member for Swansea East, was one of a number of women who received poison pen letters during the selection process. Having spent her life defending other women against discrimination, she admits: 'I was shaken by the letters and by how undermined I felt.'

Resistance to women's involvement in politics remains high in certain areas and the fear is that this resentment may be coming home to roost in the run-up to the parliamentary selections, set to begin in a few weeks' time. There are mutterings that decisions about vacant safe seats are being stitched up in the all-male bars and clubs that litter the Welsh valleys. As Huw Lewis, Assembly member for Merthyr Tydfil, puts it: 'There are a lot of bitter and bruised men out there. Many simply cannot accept that a woman beat them and they won't forget that in a hurry.'

Backlash may be part of the story, but it is not the whole story. As Julie Morgan, MP for Cardiff North, puts it: 'Twinning changed the face of Welsh politics. The public have got used to seeing women in powerful positions and more and more women now realise that politics is for them.' Men, too, are part of this cultural revolution. Huw Lewis, Assistant General Secretary when the twinning campaign was launched, had reservations - until he saw ugly prejudices laid bare. 'It made me realise that without positive action, many of these women simply would not be where they are now.'

Success in the Assembly is giving Welsh feminists the confidence to focus on Westminster. Here the record is appalling. Of 40 Welsh MPs, just four are women (all Labour). This is well below the national average of 18% and four times lower than in the Welsh Assembly. The forthcoming selections for safe Labour seats offer an opportunity to double women's representation in Wales. Six seats are available: select a woman, goes the logic, and you are almost certain to deliver another woman to Parliament. Welsh Labour women's bid to beat the old boys' network is spearheaded by Julie Morgan MP, in tandem with the Labour Women's Network. They have already held one training day in Cardiff and two more are planned. Local women are putting themselves forward, often for up to three seats, even if they do not believe they have a chance of winning.

Jessica Morden, 31 and new General Secretary for Wales, says more are standing than ever before and optimists speculate that traditional Labour strongholds like Caerphilly could surprise everyone, while Wrexham is hot favourite to select a woman.

Nevertheless, it would be unwise to overstate the extent of the cultural shift. Rapid feminisation coexists with deep-seated traditional attitudes. 'It's an awful thing to admit,' Anita Gayle says, 'but party members will accept women only with a degree of compulsion.' As Val Feld points out: 'You don't change patterns of behaviour and values overnight. There are positive signals in Wales, but it is still early days.' She favours renewed commitment to positive action at national level, but while constituency parties still have an obligation to produce 50:50 shortlists, experience suggests equality of opportunity does not result in equality of outcome. Three of the four Welsh women MPs currently in Westminster were selected through all-women shortlists and they are in marginal seats. 'The current system is flawed,' Julie Morgan says. 'There is a danger we will not capitalise on the gains of the Welsh Assembly and could end up with fewer female politicians in Wales after the next general election.'

The selections come at an important moment in Welsh political history and Wrexham, which kicks off the process, will be an important test of the party's feminisation. 'If women don't score well there,' Morgan argues, 'we still have time to organise ourselves and to raise our profile.' This is not victim feminism and why should it be?

In spite of the trouble and strife, 1999 was a good year for Welsh feminism and democracy, and equality campaigners are determined to consolidate on their victory. At her retirement party last year, Anita Gayle was handed a T-shirt with 'I'm a feminist' on the front, 'And a trollop' on the back. The joke went down well, but then Gayle and many other Welsh women could afford to laugh. Last year, they won through in ways unprecedented in Britain. Whether they will still be smiling after the next parliamentary selections remains to be seen.

fields.headline: The main recommendations
fields.trailText: Among the report's 52 recommendations are:
fields.body:
Among the report's 52 recommendations are:

Abolish tuition fees for Scottish domiciled students - the Scottish Executive to pick up the estimated £12m shortfall to the sector.

Set up the Scottish Graduate Endowment - all Scottish domiciled and European Union students starting courses from October 2001 will sign a contract to pay £3,075 to the fund once their graduate salary tops £25,000. Ministers should consider early payment incentives.

Ministers in England, Wales and Northern Ireland should waive fourth-year fees for Scottish universities as a matter of urgency.

A new body, Student Finance Scotland, to collect and take over wide-ranging responsibilities for student support.

A charitable trust, the Scottish Graduate Endowment Foundation, to provide additional support for higher and further education

students, receiving donations from existing graduates, firms or members of the public.

Students genuinely unable to find work during the summer vacation should have access to benefits.

Support for students increased to £4,100 (away from home), £3,240 (living at home) and £5,050 (in London).

Review support for further education students.

Students should be limited to maximum of 10 hours a week paid work in term time.

Three years' bursary support in FE college/school for young people from low-income backgrounds, plus bursaries in higher education equal to half the total support available.

Childcare allowance of £1,500 for lone-parent students.

Disabled student allowance to be open to all higher education students.

Review means test - low- and middle-income parents to pay less and better off pay more.

Wider Access and Mature Students' bursary schemes to target non-repayable support to particularly disadvantaged students - schemes administered by universities and colleges and would absorb current Access Funds.

Better information for prospective students on the internet and in libraries.

Tax breaks as incentives for people to contribute to Individual Learning Accounts.

Review support for postgraduate students.

fields.headline: Has Cubie killed fees?
fields.standfirst: Scotland's furious political row over tuition fees looks set to end in their abolition. But the repercussions will be felt throughout the UK. Donald MacLeod reports
fields.trailText: January 4 2000: Scotland's furious political row over tuition fees looks set to end in their abolition. But the repercussions will be felt throughout the UK. Donald MacLeod reports
fields.body:
Every developed country is struggling to keep pace with the intellectual arms race. They know that if they don't educate more of their citizens to a higher level, they'll fall behind but they also know there are limits to what taxpayers are willing to shell out for students.

It's a perennial issue, which seemed to have quietened down again in Britain once David Blunkett settled on paid tuition fees in the year after Labour was elected. But now it's come charging back up the agenda, and in a way that will probably affect students throughout the United Kingdom.

Shortly before Christmas, a report to the Scottish Parliament on student finance was produced in response to the furious political row north of the border over tuition fees and student loans. This week, a small group of Labour and Liberal Democrat politicians are trying to thrash out a deal based on the report, to save their ruling coalition in Edinburgh. They have not got much time - in two weeks it is the Scottish Nationalists' turn to choose the subject of debate in the Parliament, and the executive is under pressure to agree a policy by then.

But that battle for short-term tactical advantage at Holyrood will have consequences that reverberate far beyond Edinburgh. For the committee chaired by Edinburgh lawyer Andrew Cubie has tried to find a Scottish answer for a global phenomenon - the continuing pressure on funding for higher education. "Set against a widespread expansion of participation, the main policy issue facing student support for further and higher education is how to bring in private money to the sectors."

Scotland has taken participation further than the rest of Britain:

47% of young people, and half of all young women, go on to higher education there. But the problem is especially acute for a small nation that is determined to hang on to its four-year degrees.

New Labour's answer to the problem was announced in the heady weeks after the 1997 general election victory: means-tested annual tuition fees of £1,000 (this year £1,025) to be paid upfront while students can borrow from the Student Loans Company to cover fees and living costs up to a maximum of £3,635 a year. Repayment starts when the graduate's income reaches £10,000 a year. Crucially, Labour completed the phasing out of grants which the Conservatives began. Blunkett, as incoming education secretary, ignored the recommendations of the Dearing committee to keep some grants and levy contributions from graduates along the lines of the Australian Higher Education Contributions Scheme.

Public meetings throughout Scotland and a mass of written evidence left Cubie and his committee in little doubt that fees were extremely unpopular in Scotland and the parental or student contribution ought to be abolished.

His report makes uncomfortable reading for Blunkett. The system for funding students was "ineffective, insufficient and indecipherable" and many students were taking on high levels of additional paid work that was detrimental to their

studies. "We consider the government unwisely put aside Dearing's recommendations for a graduate contribution and chose an approach which has become unpopular in Scotland . We are clearÉ that the present arrangements are broadly discredited, add to anxieties about debt and create undue anomalies."

webTitle: Hopkins 'furious' at Foster's lack of Hannibal appetite

fields.headline: Hopkins 'furious' at Foster's lack of Hannibal appetite
fields.standfirst: Also today, Dogma fails to dent Bond's popularity, Not the Sound of Music down at South Park,  Now, Voyager director dies of natural causes, Cameron Diaz's millennium celebrations don't start too well,  In brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Anthony Hopkins is finding something hard to digest, and it isn't someone's liver. The Silence of the Lambs's star, who committed to reprise his role as the cannibal psychiatrist in Hannibal, is reportedly enraged by former co-star Jodie Foster's decision to opt out of the sequel.
fields.body:
Anthony Hopkins is finding something hard to digest, and it isn't someone's liver. The Silence of the Lambs's star, who committed to reprise his role as the cannibal psychiatrist in Hannibal, is reportedly enraged by former co-star Jodie Foster's decision to opt out of the sequel.

A source close to Hopkins is reported to have described the actor as 'absolutely furious'. "There had been a great deal of trouble coming up with the right script, but the latest version is superb," said the unnamed source. "Everyone thought Jodie was happy. Tony thought it essential to reprise the chemistry between the two characters for Lambs II [sic] to work, but she has pulled the rug from under everyone He feels hugely let down [Foster] gave every indication she was happy with the new script and shooting was to begin in spring."

A script adapted from novelist Thomas Harris's original novel was rewritten when Foster objected to a plotline that saw her character, FBI agent Clarice Starling, indulging in cannibalism after being brainwashed by Hannibal Lecter. The rewrite persuaded Hopkins to commit to the project, and it was generally assumed that Foster would sign up alongside him. See last week's news story for more details.

Hopkins and Universal Studios have yet to officially comment on Foster's decision, or the future of the film without one of its main players.

Dogma fails to dent Bond's popularity

Despite the hype, Dogma failed to knock The World is Not Enough from the top of the box-office tree over the Christmas holiday period.

It might have had the right festive theme (although many Catholics beg to differ), but Kevin Smith's self-proclaimed love letter to God failed to bring in the Yuletide punters, and it was up to James Bond to save the British public from more helpings of turkey and reheated TV movies.

The 19th Bond outing retained its number one spot for a fifth week and added £336,718 over the Christmas weekend bringing its box-office total to £20.5m.

Dogma came in third in the charts, pulling in £137,050 for the 24-26 December weekend, while Inspector Gadget held onto the number two slot. The live-action kid's adventure grossed £316,969 over the Christmas weekend.

Blue Streak managed only a disappointing £130,228, to limp in fourth.

The week's other new releases, Mystery Men and Muppets From Space, failed to make the top ten, placing 11th and 12th respectively. The comic-book comedy drew in £42,290, while our furry puppets' space escapade made only £40,651.

Not the Sound of Music

Although world's away from The Sound of Music, many reckoned it one of the year's best musicals. And yet the score for South Park: Bigger, Longer & Uncut is not eligible for an Oscar.

There are three Oscar music categories: original song, original score (primarily for background music), and original song score (a category designed specifically for musicals). Although the latter Oscar hasn't been awarded since 1984 (when the Artist Formerly Known as Prince won for Purple Rain), it transpires that movie musicals are not eligible for an original score nomination.

Undeterred, the film's creators Trey Park and Matt Stone, who wrote the music with Marc Shaiman, are planning to submit their war-mongering sing-along 'Blame Canada' for the original song category.

Journey's end for Now, Voyager director

Journeyman director Irving Rapper is belatedly reported to have died on December 20, of natural causes, at the ripe old age of 101. Born in London, Rapper rose to fame on the back of such solid Hollywood melodramas as The Glass Menagerie and the Oscar-nominated One Foot in Heaven. He remains best known, though, for helming 1942's high-flown tearjerker Now, Voyager, starring Claude Rains and Bette Davis.

Cameron Diaz robbed by rogue airport screener

Cameron Diaz's millennial celebrations suffered a hiccup when she was robbed of her passport and $7,000 in cash by a security screener at Los Angeles International Airport.

The star of There's Something About Mary and the upcoming Being John Malkovich was leaving LA for an undisclosed location on December 29 when her purse was rifled during a routine security check. Airport authorities were alerted and the missing items swiftly recovered. An unnamed airport official was arrested at the scene.

In brief

Sean Connery, Elizabeth Taylor and Julie Andrews are all in line for recognition in the first New Year's Honours List of the Millennium.

Roberto Benigni's Oscar-winning Life is Beautiful has become the most successful Italian film ever, beating the $43 million global box office of Bernardo Bertolucci's 1972 Last Tango in Paris. The Holocaust 'comedy' has raked in $45m to date.

The popularity of mainstream American film continues unabated, with the 1999's global box office share of Hollywood produce totalling $7.3 billion - breaking last year's record figure of $6.76 billion.

The witch's house in The Blair Witch Project has been saved from demolition after an 'interested party' - believed to be the film's distributor, Artisan - bought the derelict property.

Casting couch

 Keanu Reeves is to star in Sam Raimi's next project, The Gift, a film about a psychic (Cate Blanchett) from a small Southern town who becomes involved in a murder investigation. Reeves will play a redneck wife-beater who becomes the prime suspect.

 Edward Norton is to fill Ben Affleck's shoes when he takes over a role opposite Robert De Niro in The Score, about a young thief who blackmailsl a veteran crook (De Niro) into one last job. Bowfinger director Frank Oz will take the helm; shooting is scheduled to start in March.  Casting for the child roles in Nicole Kidman's as yet untitled project has began in England. Produced by Tom Cruise and directed by Alejandro Amenábar, the film is a creepy Omen-like thriller.

Public meetings throughout Scotland and a mass of written evidence left Cubie and his committee in little doubt that fees were extremely unpopular in Scotland and the parental or student contribution ought to be abolished. His report makes uncomfortable reading for Blunkett. The system for funding students was "ineffective, insufficient and indecipherable" and many students were taking on high levels of additional paid work that was detrimental to their studies. "We consider the government unwisely put aside Dearing's recommendations for a graduate contribution and chose an approach which has become unpopular in Scotland. We are clear . . . that the present arrangements are broadly discredited, add to anxieties about debt and create undue anomalies." The up-front contribution ought to go, but graduates ought to contribute to the costs of their education, argues the report. "We are not persuaded that a principle of free education should apply in all circumstances. Indeed, fairness suggests that those who gain from higher education should make an appropriate and timely contribution in respect of the benefits gained. After all, these benefits are significant and not available to all. "To ensure graduates who benefit from higher education make a contribution towards its future costs, we propose a Scottish Graduate Endowment. However, full-time further and higher education students, other than postgraduates, should have the opportunity to attend college or university without paying tuition fees." From 2001, it recommends, students would contract to pay into the endowment fund when their income reaches £25,000. The report sets a total figure of £3,075 to match what current students have to pay. Cubie also blamed Blunkett for not following the lead of Edinburgh ministers and waiving fees for the fourth year of Scottish degree courses. It was up to him to sort out the anomaly, not the Scots: "The decision by ministers elsewhere in the UK not to respect this principle on the issue of the fourth-year anomaly led to a discrediting of tuition fees in Scotland. This in turn led, through the political process, to the case for abolition of the tuition fee contribution being put so strongly." Blunkett has no intention of spending a penny of his budget on sorting out Scottish anomalies, but any implementation of the Cubie proposals will lead to embarrassing comparisons and could well reopen the fees debate in England, which the government thought it had dealt with. It is not only that students from England will be paying £1,025 more than their Scottish colleagues to study at Scottish universities, and having to pay it upfront. The result is likely to be fewer incoming students. The most recent figures from the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service showed a 5% fall in applications from English students, 13% from Wales, and more than 4% from Northern Ireland. (The number of Scots who wanted to study in their own country fell by just 1.8%.) Indeed, one well-respected physics department in Scotland is already rewriting its four-year course into three years in response to a drastic fall in applications from over the border. More vital in political terms to Blunkett and other members of the Blair government is whether Scotland comes up with a better system for promoting the increase in participation they have set their sights on. Cubie's case against fees is that they deter the people from poor backgrounds that New Labour wants to draw into the educational fold. Not only should fees be scrapped, but money should be redirected away from loans to well-off families and targeted on bursaries for the poor. In other words, grants should be restored under another name. Although 40% of Scotland's 140,000 full-time higher education students pay no fees at all and a further 30% pay a reduced fee, the Cubie committee was convinced their existence was a deterrent to "loan averse" low-income families and mature students. In England, ministers have argued strongly that fees have had no effect on applications, although they have had to admit a drop among mature students. Perhaps it is too soon to judge, but there has certainly been no significant expansion in numbers of people coming forward from the working class and ethnic minority families the government wants to attract. At the same time, there are growing complaints from universities with a lot of these sort of students that financial hardship is making their drop-out rates worse. Labour's majority at Westminster is too large for ministers to need to appease the Liberal Democrats, but Cubie's argument that students from low-income backgrounds will need financial help both at further education college and at university through special bursary schemes will strike a chord with English universities and students. For an "education, education, education" government, that could be embarrassing. One of the most significant features of the report is that, although media coverage has centred on university fees, half the discussion and recommendations are about further education colleges - the vital step on the ladder to increased participation. But will Cubie's proposals fare any better in the political arena than Lord Dearing's voluminous report on higher education? Ministers in Scotland are sceptical that Cubie's proposals could be delivered for the £62m extra he claims, rising in subsequent years to £71m, and universities areanxious they could simply lose the fee income without gaining anything in return. On the other hand, Tories have condemned the proposals as simply converting tuition fees into a tuition tax and some LibDems regard the graduate payments as deferred fees. The deal, therefore, is by no means done. But, as a senior Scottish Liberal Democrat backbencher put it: "Fees are dead - or else the coalition is dead." The main ideas Among the report's 52 recommendations are: Abolish tuition fees for Scottish domiciled students - the Scottish Executive to pick up the estimated £12m shortfall to the sector.  Set up the Scottish Graduate Endowment -all Scottish domiciled and European Union students starting courses from October 2001 will sign a contract to pay £3,075 to the fund once their graduate salary tops £25,000. Ministers should consider early payment incentives.  Ministers in England, Wales and Northern Ireland should waive fourth-year fees for Scottish universities as a matter of urgency.  A new body, Student Finance Scotland, to collect and take over wide-ranging responsibilities for student support.  A charitable trust, the Scottish Graduate Endowment Foundation, to provide additional support for higher and further education students, receiving donations from existing graduates, firms or members of the public.  Students genuinely unable to find work during the summer vacation should have access to benefits.  Support for students increased to £4,100 (away from home), £3,240 (living at home) and £5,050 (in London).  Review support for further education students.  Students should be limited to maximum of 10 hours a week paid work in term time.  Three years' bursary support in FE college/school for young people from low-income backgrounds, plus bursaries in higher education equal to half the total support available.  Childcare allowance of £1,500 for lone-parent students.  Disabled student allowance to be open to all higher education students.  Review means test - low- and middle-income parents to pay less and better off pay more.  Wider Access and Mature Students' bursary schemes to target non-repayable support to particularly disadvantaged students - schemes administered by universities and colleges and would absorb current Access Funds.  Better information for prospective students on the internet and in libraries.  Tax breaks as incentives for people to contribute to Individual Learning Accounts.  Review support for postgraduate students. The report of the independent commitee of inquiry into student finance is available on www.studentfinance.org.uk. The four-volume report can also be ordered from bookshops, total price £15.The main ideas

fields.headline: A tale of two tails
fields.trailText: Barring miracles, England cannot now win this series, and today showed why. First, they bowled as well as they can - yet it still wasn't good enough to prevent South Africa topping 400 again. Second, the South African tail once more proved almost as strong as its middle order. When they were 307 for 7, with a lead of 49, the game - and the series - was in the balance. But South Africa's No.9 is Mark Boucher, who hit 108 in his previous innings; England's is Darren Gough, who yesterday backed away to edge to the keeper for 4. The gulf between them is big enough to determine the outcome of a game.
fields.body:
Barring miracles, England cannot now win this series, and today showed why. First, they bowled as well as they can - yet it still wasn't good enough to prevent South Africa topping 400 again. Second, the South African tail once more proved almost as strong as its middle order. When they were 307 for 7, with a lead of 49, the game - and the series - was in the balance. But South Africa's No.9 is Mark Boucher, who hit 108 in his previous innings; England's is Darren Gough, who yesterday backed away to edge to the keeper for 4. The gulf between them is big enough to determine the outcome of a game.

And so it should prove here. If South Africa had been dismissed for 320, England could have still have won, in the manner of Melbourne last winter or even Trent Bridge two summers ago. But a deficit of 161 is too big to contemplate victory with two days to go. A draw must be the best England can hope for, although with Andrew Flintoff injured, even that may be beyond them.

When will England realise the benefit of a long tail? South Africa have Lance Klusener, Shaun Pollock and Boucher at 7, 8 and 9. It is rare that all three fail in the same innings. At Johannesburg, Klusener made 72; at Port Elizabeth he walloped 174 and Boucher chipped in with 42; at Durban, Pollock saved them from complete humiliation in the first innings with 64, and Boucher's hundred helped ensure a draw in the second. Today, Boucher added 90 with Daryll Cullinan for the eighth wicket. That's one vital contribution per innings. Even Paul Adams hung around for 30 balls this afternoon.

England persist with two players - Gough and Silverwood - who wouldn't be out of place at No.11, and one - Tufnell - who isn't that good. Surely better to replace The Cat with a bowler who is equally unpenetrative (he has 6 for 433 so far in the series, having taken a wicket once every 29 overs), but who doesn't scarper to square-leg if the ball is heading towards off stump. Graeme Swann might be a start. Or Ashley Giles.

England's seamers did bowl well today on a flat wicket. But they slipped back into their habit of turning it on only after almost being played out of the game. There was a startling contrast between the first two sessions today and the last two yesterday, when the way they let things drift reminded you of the 1989 Ashes series. Which makes the efforts of Cullinan and Boucher all the more creditable. They have reasserted South Africa's dominance, not only in this game, but in the series as a whole.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: I say what I like and I like what I say

fields.headline: I say what I like and I like what I say
fields.standfirst: Ken Clarke has made a name for himself condemning the Tories' lurch to the right. Perhaps he should take politics rather more seriously, says David McKie
fields.trailText: Ken Clarke is a bit of a card. He is one of those politicians who says what he thinks, regardless of what his pager tells him to say. What the hell! He likes his pint, and his birdwatching, and his afternoon at the football - even if that means watching Nottingham Forest. In other words, he's a real human being.
fields.body:
Ken Clarke is a bit of a card. He is one of those politicians who says what he thinks, regardless of what his pager tells him to say. What the hell! He likes his pint, and his birdwatching, and his afternoon at the football - even if that means watching Nottingham Forest. In other words, he's a real human being.

People like politicians like that. That is why they have such a soft spot for Ann Widdecombe in spite of some of her views. It's the way they used to think about John Prescott, until disaffection with the government's transport policies began to set in and there were all those jibes about Jags and driving a few hundred yards to a conference centre - a disaffection, it has to be said, assiduously fed by bright young acolytes of New Blair.

During the Christmas break Ken Clarke was the youngest of three old stagers - the others were the leader of the Liberal peers, Lord Rodgers, and the former Labour deputy leader Lord Hattersley - invited by the BBC World at One programme to review the political year. As ever, Ken said what he thought, not what party apparatchiks would have wished him to say. Although he found the odd kindly word for his party leader, William Hague, he condemned the Tories' lurch to the right, disparaged the bright young things rather too close to Hague who were peddling that kind of image, distanced himself from the party's stance on the euro and declared that in his opinion the new currency had done pretty well.

The people who usually call for his head on such occasions called for his head, and were quickly condemned as hopeless old Eurosceptics. Yet there is also a serious case against Ken: a case which says that in his lackadaisical way he does not always take politics as seriously as he should.

It is, after all, less than three years since this scourge of the Eurosceptics, this man who so often condemns their baleful influence on his party and his country, teamed up with the arch Eurosceptic John Redwood in a nightmare ticket opposing William Hague for the party leadership. They were, he said, "conviction politicians" who had come together to unify the party. Oh yes? Did it not matter that their respective convictions belonged at opposite end of the scale? Did he really believe a deeply Eurosceptical party could be unified behind the kind of all-out support for Europe he now shows? And what role would John Redwood have been given in such an enterprise? The whole idea is preposterous.

Of course as party leader Clarke would have had to compromise. Of course he would have come up with some misty slogan with which he and Redwood could just about live: "In Europe but not run by Europe", perhaps. And yet he contrives to give the impression that Hague is weak when he does exactly that. True, the World at One's review of the year is hardly a platform at Conservative conference or a long-considered speech in the House of Commons. But Clarke must have known how his comments would play in the next day's papers. What the hell! He did it anyway.

Useful links
Special report: the Tories in turmoil
Special report: the euro

Big bad bugs

The millennium has arrived, and in the cool light of these wet new year mornings we have learned that the millennium bug, once a worldwide menace set to destroy our computers, was never much more than a midge. People now complain that the very expensive precautions taken against it were a vast waste of public money. Maybe in time the Commons select committee which superintends this region of life will tell us the answer. But meanwhile we should not underestimate the psychological value of the millennium bug as one of those features of life which binds a nation together by giving it something that everyone can worry about. Can it be pure coincidence that just as a great national sigh of relief goes up over Y2K, the government announces its successor in the Big Worries league: the threat that we may be struck by some death-dealing object from outer space?

fields.headline: Elbows, Eyes and Nipples
fields.trailText: EVERYONE'S TALKING ABOUT... BEN THATCHER'S ELBOW
fields.body:
EVERYONE'S TALKING ABOUT... BEN THATCHER'S ELBOW

It's the hottest extremity in the Premiership since Paul Merson stopped inhaling through his nose, and everyone wants a piece of it. It was spotted at last month's Bond premiere on the arm of gorgeous lad's-mag adornment Caprice and, if the rumours are true, it's just signed a three album deal with Warner Brothers. But just what made Ben Thatcher's elbow so hot hot hot?

The answer lies in a large amount of well-placed publicity, and a little forearm smash. Nicky Summerbee set it all off, with close friends saying he was "completely floored" by the joint in the build up to Wimbledon's winner against Sunderland. Unavailable for comment on the incident (due to swelling in the cheek region), Summerbee has instead left it to Wimbledon manager Egil Olsen to express the nation's feelings.

"He was running with his arms, it's impossible to put them down," said the Norwegian communist, who must have had a special view of the incident as Thatcher appeared to be running on his legs. "He did hit the opponent but when you have the ball it's very difficult to punish a player." Who was talking about punishment? Not the FA, who have simply requested a video of the game so they can marvel at that elbow. "We treat each case on its merits," said a spokesman today. If there's an elbow more meretricious the Fiver wants to hear about it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

RIO BRAVO!

Twenty four hours into their South American odyssey and already things appear to be going a bit wrong for Manchester United. The weather is a bit sweaty, the Maracana is a building site, the entire squad has been forced to pitch camp on a hillside under a favella, the portable stoves have run out of gas, and Steve McLaren hasn't brought enough baked beans. If all that wasn't bad enough, Martin Edwards has decided he's homesick.

"If we had had the choice we would not have come to Brazil," said Money Mart today, presumably using the royal 'we', as Michael Clegg is just loving his time in the party capital of the New World. "We had to give up the FA Cup," Money went on, his eyes misting up at the thought of Stanley Matthews nutmegging Charlie George in a gusty fourth-round replay at Fratton Park. "About that we are disappointed."

Observant readers will note that this is not the first time Money Mart has claimed, in a manner not too dissimilar to Oliver Stone after an all-night Democrat fundraiser, that evil forces have pushed United out of the Cup they hold dearest to their hearts. At the same time as Alex Ferguson MDF is trying to tout the Fifa Club World Championshop as the dawn of a new era as well. Let's hope none of the youngsters get hooked on glue before the tournament starts. That would really cap it off.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I didn't do much for New Year's Eve. I had three beers with my wife and she had a little bit of red wine. We stayed up for an hour after midnight and then went to bed. I know that's really bad." - Derby's new Belgian striker Branko Strupar reveals a sharp understanding of lad culture.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MR LOGIC

There are some things football can provide you with, and some things it can't. If you want excitement, frustration and a garish replica shirt made out of material which will chafe your nipples in cold weather, then football's the game for you. But if you're after logic and common sense, then you'll have to look elsewhere.

Take the arguments of Erik Soler, for example, the philosopher-cum-agent currently trying to secure a £500,000 transfer to FC Copenhagen for lumbering Celtic 'goalscorer' Harald Brattbakk. The Norwegian 'striker' has spent the best part of the last two years shinning sitters into the Parkhead stands, but apparently this is only because he is far too good for Scottish football. "I don't mean to be disrespectful to the Scottish style of play," sniffed Soler, "but I think it would be much better for Harald's style to play in a place like Denmark. Danish football is played on the ground."

Soler suggests that such a classy "continental" approach will allow his client to "show again that he is a top-quality striker" and not a lame carthorse regularly humiliated by the likes of Steven Pressley and Shaun McSkimming. After all, he argues, this is the player who single-handedly won Celtic's only league title of the Nineties: "How many times have Celtic been champions in the last few years? But they were champions the season Harald played regularly." You're right, Erik, those seven goals were important. In fact there was almost no need for the rest of the team to knock in the other 57.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Derby are interested in Celtic defender Jackie McNamara. The Scottish international will be available for free at the end of the season under the Bosman ruling.

Brentford defender Darren Powell has been attracting the attention of several Premiership clubs, including Arsenal and Aston Villa, who sent a scout to watch the Bees' defeat against Stoke at the weekend.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Manchester United are now 9-4 joint favourites alongside Corinthians to win the Fifa Club World Championshop, moving in from 3-1. Meanwhile, United are laying yet another pitch at Old Trafford. The bulldozers move in tomorrow to replace the whole playing area for the third time since the summer and the sixth since 1998.

The Scottish FA have ruled out the prospect of playing Yugoslavia in a friendly before their World Cup 2002 campaign. Scotland manager Craig Brown had indicated that he felt Yugoslavia would be ideal opponents to gear up for meeting Croatia in competitive action. But the SFA have played down the possibility of a game being arranged after the potential political problems of any match were highlighted.

Brighton's Darren Freeman is to be given a special award for scoring the first goal of the millennium in English professional football. Freeman scored after just two minutes in the Seagulls' 4-2 win over Exeter, and league sponsors Nationwide are to present him with a specially commissioned magnum of champagne. Birmingham's Bryan Hughes scored after 12 seconds against Huddersfield but Freeman's goal was earlier because the Brighton match was a noon kick-off.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (1.45am)

Dave Beckett. We need say nothing more.

Sky Sports 1: Brian Moore Interviews (6.30pm, 11pm SS2)

Liverpool's Peter Thompson talks to Armchair Viewer's nightmare.

Live Football Special (7pm, 1.15am)

Chelsea attempt to become the latest Londoners to leave Highfield Road with their championship hopes in tatters.

Premiership Shorts (10.25pm)

Were very skimpy in the saucy Eighties.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.45pm, 4.45am)

As McCaffrey's face fills the screen, the Fiver realises that all the hopes and dreams it had for the new millennium are in ruins.

Eurosport: Football (10pm)

What's this? All we want to watch is fat grunting Scandinavians lifting large stones onto platforms.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

Alan Green makes a New Year's resolution not to moan about the quality of the football. But you may as well wait for Shane MacGowan to give up booze.

Soler suggests that such a classy "continental" approach will allow his client to "show again that he is a top-quality striker" and not a lame carthorse regularly humiliated by the likes of Steven Pressley and Shaun McSkimming. In fact there was almost no need for the rest of the team to knock in the other 57. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Derby are interested in Celtic defender Jackie McNamara. The Scottish international will be available for free at the end of the season under the Bosman ruling. Brentford defender Darren Powell has been attracting the attention of several Premiership clubs, including Arsenal and Aston Villa, who sent a scout to watch the Bees' defeat against Stoke at the weekend. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Manchester United are now 9-4 joint favourites alongside Corinthians to win the Fifa Club World Championshop, moving in from 3-1. Meanwhile, United are laying yet another pitch at Old Trafford. The bulldozers move in tomorrow to replace the whole playing area for the third time since the summer and the sixth since 1998. The Scottish FA have ruled out the prospect of playing Yugoslavia in a friendly before their World Cup 2002 campaign. Scotland manager Craig Brown had indicated that he felt Yugoslavia would be ideal opponents to gear up for meeting Croatia in competitive action. But the SFA have played down the possibility of a game being arranged after the potential political problems of any match were highlighted. Freeman scored after just two minutes in the Seagulls' 4-2 win over Exeter, and league sponsors Nationwide are to present him with a specially commissioned magnum of champagne. Live Football Special (7pm, 1.15am) Chelsea attempt to become the latest Londoners to leave Highfield Road with their championship hopes in tatters. Premiership Shorts (10.25pm) Were very skimpy in the saucy Eighties. You're On Sky Sports! (10.45pm, 4.45am) As McCaffrey's face fills the screen, the Fiver realises that all the hopes and dreams it had for the new millennium are in ruins. Eurosport: Football (10pm) What's this? All we want to watch is fat grunting Scandinavians lifting large stones onto platforms. Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm) Alan Green makes a New Year's resolution not to moan about the quality of the football. But you may as well wait for Shane MacGowan to give up booze.

webTitle: Task force to assess risk of asteroid collision

fields.headline: Task force to assess risk of asteroid collision
fields.standfirst: 2,000 near-earth objects 'pose threat that cannot be ignored'
fields.trailText: The government has formed a task force to consider the ultimate hazard: a collision with a large object from outer space.
fields.body:
The government has formed a task force to consider the ultimate hazard: a collision with a large object from outer space.

A team of three named today will consider the probability of a direct hit by an asteroid - a large lump of stony iron travelling at perhaps 20 miles a second - of the kind that wiped out the dinosaurs 65m years ago.

The science minister, Lord Sainsbury, said: "The risk of an asteroid or comet causing substantial damage is extremely remote. This is not something that people should lie awake worrying about. But we cannot ignore the risk, however remote, and a case can be made for monitoring the situation on an international basis."

The three are Harry Atkinson, who has worked with the European space agency, the US agency Nasa and the cabinet office, Sir Crispin Tickell, chancellor of Kent university and a prominent environmentalist, and David Williams, professor at University College London. They will consider the problem of what are known officially as near-earth objects, NEOs. These could be asteroids or comets, and Nasa scientists calculate that there could be more than 2,000 over a kilometre across, each one a cosmic traffic accident in the making. So far only about 10% of these have been detected.

The asteroid problem was originally dubbed the Chicken-Licken issue, after the hen in the children's story who believed the sky was falling in. Gradually, as evidence has amassed from earth and other planets of a story of random but frequent bombardment over billions of years, governments have begun to take it seriously. The planet's history has been punctuated by major collisions.

A 10km asteroid smashed into the earth at the end of the cretaceous era, triggering tsunamis (a series of long, high sea waves), a nuclear winter, acid rain, global warming and worldwide forest fires. A 100 metre object crashed into the atmosphere over Siberia forest in 1908, producing an explosion estimated at 30 megatons and felling 2,000 sq miles of forest.

In 1937 and 1989 large asteroids passed uncomfortably close to earth. US comet specialists have calculated that although impacts are rare in human history, a collision with a large enough object could wipe out all civilisation, or even most of life. Because the death toll would run to billions, they argued, the risk of such an event in any one year would be about 1 in 20,000, roughly the same as for death in an air disaster.

The UN and the International Astronomical Union say governments should take the matter seriously. Jonathan Tate, founder of the British pressure group Spaceguard UK, welcomed the government statement.

"The threat from asteroidal or cometary impacts, while being low probability but very high consequence, exceeds by orders of magnitude the government's own threshold of risk tolerability," he said. "Compared with nuclear safety, BSE/CJD, genetically modified food and so on, the impact threat is in a league of its own."

Dr Atkinson and colleagues will consider what evidence there is and report to the British national space centre this year. "Any recommendations we make must be based on good science, and that will include looking at the risks of things," he said.

"We will look in detail to see what other countries are doing in terms of ground-based telescopes. We will also look to see what is going on the ground in the southern hemisphere. We will also be looking at space-based activities."

A Nasa spacecraft is destined to meet the asteroid Eros this month and orbit it for at least a year. A mission called Stardust is on its way to fly close to Comet Wild-2, collect some of its dust and return in 2006. The Japanese are planning to put a tiny space rover on asteroid 4660 Nereus and collect some of its rock.

The Europeans are planning to meet a comet and fly with it.

In a recent Hollywood thriller, scientists saved the world by sending Bruce Willis to blow up a menacing near-earth object.

But Dr Atkinson and colleagues will not be proposing ways of deflecting or demolishing impending doom. "That would be something for the longer term. Until one knows something about the composition of asteroids, to talk about mitigation is perhaps a bit premature."

fields.headline: On the critical list
fields.standfirst: In the last three weeks, there have been nights when there were no intensive-care beds available in parts of Britain. So why are there so few? It all comes down to money, says Bibi van der Zee, who spent New Year's Eve on the front line between life and death
fields.trailText: In the last three weeks, there have been nights when there were no intensive-care beds available in parts of Britain. So why are there so few? It all comes down to money, says Bibi van der Zee, who spent New Year's Eve on the front line between life and death
fields.body:
This is the most helpless we will ever be. The patients here are mostly unconscious or sedated, lying high on their pillows, faces tilted blindly towards the ceiling while tubes and drips and feeds invade them from every angle. Syringe drivers dose their systems with drugs at timed intervals and the contents of feedbags drip through tubes into their stomachs; monitors trace heart rates, central venus pressure and blood pressure in thin coloured lines that track mountain ranges across a black screen.

On the other side of the beds are breathing machines, flashing up digital breakdowns of breathing patterns, while tubes pass through throats, hands or arms, drugs keep hearts beating, and ventilators gently fill and empty lungs, breath by breath by breath.

'It must look like a torture chamber if you're not used to it,' says Andrea Martin, head nurse of the intensive care unit at London's University College Hospital. 'I suppose I hardly see it any more, but I wonder what relatives think when they first get here.'

In truth, it takes a while to make out the relatives amid the bright lights and fast-moving staff and metres and metres of tubing. Beside a bed near the nurses' station sits an elderly woman, holding tight to her unseeing husband's hand, and staring blankly beyond him. Leaning against a wall nearby, a middle-aged man watches as two nurses move gently round the bed of his relative, suctioning him. He shifts to the other foot after a while. Christmas has come and gone here, but there are no decorations on the ward.

Few of the patients would notice anyway. The intensive care unit (ICU) is reserved for some of the sickest people in a hospital: patients suffering from multiple organ failure. When we are ill, or the body suffers some trauma, normally our own chemicals will begin the battle against the invader while the rest of the system keeps on going. But in cases of truly severe 'insult', as it is called, to the body, such as a car accident, major surgery, or severe infection, the balance between defence and attack is lost, the body starts to do battle with itself and one by one organs are damaged and, eventually, shut down in the crossfire. Lungs, heart, stomach, kidneys, liver: it's hard to believe that things we've never even seen and just assume will always work can let us down so badly.

This is when patients are moved to the ICU: Martin says that part of the reason she came here was because she wondered where the patients who were too sick to be on the ordinary wards went. The ICU is the only place in a hospital that can support those collapsing organs and keep a patient stable enough to administer the other medical treatments they may need urgently.

Fifty or 60 years ago none of this would have been possible: before ventilators existed to keep lungs going when the body had given up on them, a patient would have been left to die. Intensive care has been pioneered over the last half century and turned into a speciality all of its own. The invention of machines and drugs that can keep a restarted heart beating, make failed lungs breathe and force kidneys to function has kept many thousands of patients alive since.

But, as Sara Bunkhall, head of the ICU at UCH points out, the financial pressures are immense. An ICU bed costs about £1,800 a day to keep going. We count up the cost of the machines around just one bed: the ventilator £20,000, each of the four syringe drivers £3,000, the feeding pump £5,000, the beds £3,000 each, the monitoring system for the ward £500,000, a haemo (blood) filter £18,000. What do these new machines do that the old ones didn't? Dr Monty Mythen points to a woman down the corridor. She sits upright in bed, a tube feeding into her throat and multiple lines running through her chest and arms, with a pair of glasses perched on her nose, reading a newspaper.

'Fifty years ago,' says Mythen, 'she would have had to be in an iron lung. Twenty years ago she would have had to be heavily sedated.'

The support machines being used here now are far less intrusive than the old machinery: patients can be conscious and almost comfortable while they are treated. Do the machines save lives then? As you look around at these patients, so paper-white and fragile it seems one moment more of trauma would push them beyond help, the answer must surely be yes. Some doctors say they do, and most intensivists will tell you that they can save many more lives today than they could 20 years ago.

But, says Mythen, slowly: 'There is some evidence to suggest that they may just reduce suffering. That's something, but when it comes to health economics suffering is often acceptable if it's cheap.'

Money, money, money. Anyone in the NHS will tell you that there's not enough of it (in Britain we spend about 6% of our gross domestic product on the health service: most other North European countries spend closer to 9%, while the United States spends more than 10%). The rate of inflation in a hospital is not the same as that of a country: the cost of machinery and drugs multiplies exponentially, not just by a few per cent every year. And while intensive care in this country is under the same financial pressure from which the rest of the NHS suffers, ICUs also put pressure on themselves by insisting on an expensive one-to-one ratio of nurses to patients.

Detractors may suggest that the level of care in Britain is worse than Europe or North America (UCH has the largest ICU in Britain, with 22 beds, while a hospital of similar size in the US will have more than 100), but intensivists point to nurse-patient ratios elsewhere: Mythen has seen patients in the US tied to their beds to stop them dislodging tubes because they are not watched 24 hours a day.

One-to-one care is, in the end, the reason most nurses and doctors come into this field, the reason they take on the higher mortality rates and never-ending pressure (Mythen has had nights when he has been telephoned due to an emergency every 40 minutes). The passage of a patient through this unit is different to any other: relatives need special care and attention as they watch a mother, a brother or child kept alive by pieces of plastic and metal. The daughters of Valerie Cumming, who is being ventilated after breathing difficulties on Christmas Eve, are full of praise for the staff. 'We felt involved from the beginning,' says Jane Fiona. 'They told us, and my mother, even though she was unconscious, exactly what was going on. Everyone has been so supportive, and even though there are such sad things happening here, it's oddly peaceful. We all wish each other well.'

Nurse Martin says: 'Because patients so often come in unconscious, I often think that one of the hardest moments for them must be when they come round and realise where they are.' Behind her, a wall is covered in thank you cards from patients or relatives who have left the ward behind. The nurses stride by, capable, organised, making jokes and being rude about the hospital trust, as NHS staff are. The machines quietly tick over, steadily feeding and breathing and moving the still bodies. New Year's Eve passes, just as Christmas did. But here there are so many clocks ticking to different timescales that hardly anyone notices.

webTitle: How I found myself at last

fields.headline: How I found myself at last
fields.standfirst: His parents thought he was naughty and sent him to a psychiatrist. Schoolmates beat him up daily. The unhappy child became an adult loner. Then Andrew Walker had a revelation - he was suffering from a form of autism
fields.trailText: His parents thought he was naughty and sent him to a psychiatrist. Schoolmates beat him up daily. The unhappy child became an adult loner. Then Andrew Walker had a revelation - he was suffering from a form of autism
fields.body:
I knew that I was different, in some indefinable way, even as a small child. My parents regarded me as a naughty boy and I constantly argued with my younger sister and brother. At six, I started to see a child psychiatrist. I never fitted in at school. I felt totally isolated and had no desire to make friends or to be part of a gang. I didn't know how to interact or to communicate and felt deeply ashamed. I was also academically bright, which stirred up much name-calling and bullying from my peers. At secondary school, it was an extraordinarily violent time, both physically and mentally.

The seeds of loathing were sown; my sense of isolation and alienation became progressively worse. I was tearing myself up with hatred, feeling suicidal most of the time. I don't remember my childhood or teenage days without suicidal thoughts. It was relentless - day in, day out - and so was the bullying because I was different. Whenever a teacher turned his back in class I was slapped and I was kicked or beaten-up during lunch-breaks. The constant fear of being picked on forced me to tone down my interest in education, and instead I yearned for the school holidays. At 13, an obsession with planes became an outlet for my deep unhappiness at school. I joined the air cadets and excelled at using firearms, which made me feel tolerant towards people. But I still couldn't fit in or communicate with my peers or understand the politics or mentality of the air cadets.

I had no concept of confidence and incredibly low expectations of a future or a career. I failed all my O-levels because during an exam I could become totally distracted by anything - a plane flying overhead, a rubber on the floor, even the skirting board. My mind would suddenly focus like a sharp, narrow torchlight beam and all thoughts about the exam were forgotten.

My relationship with my family was conflict-based and when I was a teenager it buckled under the perpetual strain of arguments. My mother would accuse me of insubordination and insolence - in her eyes I was impossible to live with. I knew my behaviour was difficult to understand. I just didn't know why.

Rock-climbing became even more of an unbridled passion than planes because I felt self-reliant and autonomous. I loved feeling independent so, at 18, I left home, moved into my own flat and found casual work.

I always assumed that I would never have a girlfriend, so I didn't try. I considered myself very unattractive, yet women did make overt gestures towards me, which I often ignored through a complete lack of self-awareness.

My first cohabiting relationship was in my early twenties and I totally neglected my girlfriend. I had no concept of another person's needs and took her for granted. Then, while working for the civil service in my late twenties, I met Diane. We were married after courting for six months, but my obsession with rock-climbing meant that we spent little time together. With scant communication in between, we were tragically misunderstanding each other - and I had no idea of what was happening. Out of sheer frustration, Diane regularly exploded in emotional and violent outbursts. Despite agreeing to seek help from a marriage guidance counsellor and a psychiatrist, a recommended trial separation came as a nasty shock.

We perceived our marriage difficulties totally differently; this was compounded by the fact that we couldn't talk about the problems in a gentle, civilised manner. I would leave messages in our flat requesting an appointment to talk to her, clueless that these gestures were divisive and fed her anger. It was a clash of two cognitive cultures and perceptions with different value systems. After three years of marriage we were divorced.

I took unpaid leave from work at the age of 31 to study geology at Sunderland university as a mature student, but I still felt alienated. Dogged by suicidal thoughts, I spiralled into clinical depression. Although I knew that there was something different about me, I hated the idea of relying on outside help not knowing what was wrong or what to ask. Bitterly determined to find out the cause of my behaviour, I began night classes in psychology to look for clues as to how and why I perceived the world in the way I did.

The defining moment, the revelation, came five years ago. I was watching a BBC documentary on Asperger syndrome, a form of autism. It was a condition I had never heard about but immediately identified with. I was 35 and, for the first time, felt that I knew what, why and who I was.

The diagnosis was life-changing. It was liberating to know that I shared a wavelength with other autistic people. I have since read voraciously on autism and have learnt how to be around people. Now I can explain to others how I perceive the world in a different way, in a society which is oriented towards a majority. I have learnt how to adapt to the majority's ways and customs. I'm also studying for a PhD in autism and education at Birmingham university and regular presentations I give for the autistic society and research unit are helping both children and parents to find their way in a world they don't fully perceive. I share a fantastically rewarding relationship with my partner of 18 months, Jacqui, and her nine-year-old autistic son, Coln, and my own family relationships have strengthened enormously.

Now, at the age of 40, I wake up every morning wanting to make things better for the next generation. I have the confidence and courage to understand more comprehensively what is required of me by people and I feel far more included in a society that is making more adjustments towards autism.
 Interview by Sarah Sims

Case notes: Asperger syndrome

* Asperger syndrome is a form of autism, a disability which affects the way a person communicates and relates to others. We can often guess a person's age or status simply by sight, and by their facial expression or tone of voice we can tell immediately whether they are happy, angry or sad. People with Asperger syndrome find it difficult to read these signals. As a result, they find it hard to communicate and interact with others.

* Although Asperger syndrome is seen as an 'autism spectrum disorder', people with the syndrome usually have fewer problems with language than those with autism. They often speak fluently, although their words can sometimes sound formal or stilted.

* Unlike those with 'classic' autism, who often appear withdrawn and uninterested in their surroundings, many people with Asperger syndrome try hard to be sociable and do not dislike human contact, even though they still find it hard to understand non-verbal signals

* People with Asperger syndrome tend not to have the learning disabilities often associated with autism; in fact, they are often of average or above average intelligence

* Because of this many children with Asperger syndrome enter mainstream school and, with the right support and encouragement, can make good progress and go on to further education and employment

 Source: The National Autistic Society. Call 0171 833 2299 or visit www.oneworld.org/autism-uk/
