The constant fear of being picked on forced me to tone down my interest in education, and instead I yearned for the school holidays. At 13, an obsession with planes became an outlet for my deep unhappiness at school. I joined the air cadets and excelled at using firearms, which made me feel tolerant towards people. But I still couldn't fit in or communicate with my peers or understand the politics or mentality of the air cadets. I had no concept of confidence and incredibly low expectations of a future or a career. I failed all my O-levels because during an exam I could become totally distracted by anything - a plane flying overhead, a rubber on the floor, even the skirting board. My mind would suddenly focus like a sharp, narrow torchlight beam and all thoughts about the exam were forgotten. My relationship with my family was conflict-based and when I was a teenager it buckled under the perpetual strain of arguments. My mother would accuse me of insubordination and insolence - in her eyes I was impossible to live with. I knew my behaviour was difficult to understand. I just didn't know why. Rock-climbing became even more of an unbridled passion than planes because I felt self-reliant and autonomous. I loved feeling independent so, at 18, I left home, moved into my own flat and found casual work. I always assumed that I would never have a girlfriend, so I didn't try. I considered myself very unattractive, yet women did make overt gestures towards me, which I often ignored through a complete lack of self-awareness. My first cohabiting relationship was in my early twenties and I totally neglected my girlfriend. I had no concept of another person's needs and took her for granted. Then, while working for the civil service in my late twenties, I met Diane. We were married after courting for six months, but my obsession with rock-climbing meant that we spent little time together. With scant communication in between, we were tragically misunderstanding each other - and I had no idea of what was happening. Out of sheer frustration, Diane regularly exploded in emotional and violent outbursts. Despite agreeing to seek help from a marriage guidance counsellor and a psychiatrist, a recommended trial separation came as a nasty shock. We perceived our marriage difficulties totally differently; this was compounded by the fact that we couldn't talk about the problems in a gentle, civilised manner. I would leave messages in our flat requesting an appointment to talk to her, clueless that these gestures were divisive and fed her anger. It was a clash of two cognitive cultures and perceptions with different value systems. After three years of marriage we were divorced. I took unpaid leave from work at the age of 31 to study geology at Sunderland university as a mature student, but I still felt alienated. Dogged by suicidal thoughts, I spiralled into clinical depression. Although I knew that there was something different about me, I hated the idea of relying on outside help not knowing what was wrong or what to ask. Bitterly determined to find out the cause of my behaviour, I began night classes in psychology to look for clues as to how and why I perceived the world in the way I did. The defining moment, the revelation, came five years ago. I was watching a BBC documentary on Asperger syndrome, a form of autism. It was a condition I had never heard about but immediately identified with. I was 35 and, for the first time, felt that I knew what, why and who I was. The diagnosis was life-changing. It was liberating to know that I shared a wavelength with other autistic people. I have since read voraciously on autism and have learnt how to be around people. Now I can explain to others how I perceive the world in a different way, in a society which is oriented towards a majority. I have learnt how to adapt to the majority's ways and customs. I'm also studying for a PhD in autism and education at Birmingham university and regular presentations I give for the autistic society and research unit are helping both children and parents to find their way in a world they don't fully perceive. I share a fantastically rewarding relationship with my partner of 18 months, Jacqui, and her nine-year-old autistic son, Coln, and my own family relationships have strengthened enormously. Now, at the age of 40, I wake up every morning wanting to make things better for the next generation. I have the confidence and courage to understand more comprehensively what is required of me by people and I feel far more included in a society that is making more adjustments towards autism.  Interview by Sarah Sims Case notes: Asperger syndrome * Asperger syndrome is a form of autism, a disability which affects the way a person communicates and relates to others. We can often guess a person's age or status simply by sight, and by their facial expression or tone of voice we can tell immediately whether they are happy, angry or sad. People with Asperger syndrome find it difficult to read these signals. As a result, they find it hard to communicate and interact with others. * Although Asperger syndrome is seen as an 'autism spectrum disorder', people with the syndrome usually have fewer problems with language than those with autism. They often speak fluently, although their words can sometimes sound formal or stilted. * Unlike those with 'classic' autism, who often appear withdrawn and uninterested in their surroundings, many people with Asperger syndrome try hard to be sociable and do not dislike human contact, even though they still find it hard to understand non-verbal signals * People with Asperger syndrome tend not to have the learning disabilities often associated with autism; in fact, they are often of average or above average intelligence * Because of this many children with Asperger syndrome enter mainstream school and, with the right support and encouragement, can make good progress and go on to further education and employment  Source: The National Autistic Society. Call 0171 833 2299 or visit www.oneworld.org/autism-uk/

fields.headline: The timing of their lives
fields.standfirst:
Is the moment of birth when the head appears or when the baby breathes? Lucy Atkins reports

The Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Last Friday, as Big Ben prepared to strike the hour we had all been waiting for, labour wards up and down the country echoed with the sound of straining pelvises. The pressure was on: in the week leading up to millennium night, victims of Channel 4's April 'bonk night' were furiously drinking raspberry tea, having sex and eating curries in the hope that their babies would arrive on the stroke of midnight - bringing with them fame and fortune.
fields.body:
Last Friday, as Big Ben prepared to strike the hour we had all been waiting for, labour wards up and down the country echoed with the sound of straining pelvises. The pressure was on: in the week leading up to millennium night, victims of Channel 4's April 'bonk night' were furiously drinking raspberry tea, having sex and eating curries in the hope that their babies would arrive on the stroke of midnight - bringing with them fame and fortune.

Who, then, is our millennium first-born? We're not talking just symbolic glory here, but sponsorship deals estimated at £1m and six-figure tabloid negotiations. As PR man Max Clifford puts it, 'You could make a fortune.'

Consequently, from John O'Groats to Lands End, tiny red-fisted rivals are lining up to stake their claim. There's wee Daniel, son of Joanne McConville and Robert Gordon, who made a brave stab at the title by emerging from his mother at 12.04am in Glasgow.

He was pipped, though, by little Andrew Watson in Durham (12.03am), while, according to the Sun newspaper, a gorgeous seven-pounder (as yet unnamed) shot out of her mother Alison Webb in Birmingham 15 seconds after midnight. But the true champ seems to be tiny Tamara Abomide, who - allegedly - made it through the amniotic fluid a whole second sooner. I use the term 'allegedly', because there's the small question of what constitutes the moment of birth. If seconds count, we need to know which ones: is the moment of birth when the head appears (or feet, if it's a breech birth)? When the whole body comes out? Some define it as the moment the cord is cut and others insist that it's when you take your first breath.

The confusion and conspiracy of silence was eventually broken by a midwife friend of a friend who reluctantly divulged, off the record, that she believes the moment of birth to be 'once the baby is out of the mother's body'. Calculating this moment to the nanosecond cannot be an easy task. Call me a nit-picker, but if it was only Tamara's head that appeared 14 seconds after midnight, then it could have taken her mother rather longer to produce her entire 8lb 15oz, in which case even little Daniel, four minutes past the magic hour, might be the title-holder.

Globally, more than 350,000 babies were delivered in the first 24 hours of the millennium, 2,000 of which popped out in Britain. But unless national hospital clocks were secretly synchronised, then this millennium baby stuff is, in fact, total nonsense. If the Birmingham hospital's clock was a second slow, then baby Webb has lost out to Tamara on a technicality.

Fortunately, baby Webb's parents, Alison and her partner Mark Heafield, don't give a damn. They tore up their £100,000 newspaper contract and turned down spin-off sponsorship deals, saying that their top priority is privacy. The church greeted the news with delight. In the words of the Venerable John Barton, Archdeacon of Aston: 'It is an amazing display of non-materialism... [they] have turned down fame and wealth, and if they carry on bringing up their daughter like this it will be a brilliant example to everyone.' He may have a point.

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Preventing a hangover
fields.body:
Preventing a hangover

Q What is the most scientific method of preventing a hangover?

A Hangovers are related to how much you drink, what you drink, and who you are. Drinking more than five units (two-and-a-half pints of beer or five glasses of wine) can lead to a hangover in most of us. Rum, brandy and whisky are more likely to cause a hangover than white wine, gin or vodka because they contain methanol, formaldehyde and formic acid which are the chemicals most likely to cause the headache and rapid heart rate of hangovers. To prevent a hangover, drink a glass of water for every alcoholic drink and line your stomach first with food. The French like a spoonful of olive oil, the Italians like a boiled potato, the Russians are said to favour half a pound of fat and the British seem to favour a bag of chips or a curry. Keep your head upright to avoid that unpleasant sensation of descending into a whirring pit when you lie down - caused by alcohol getting into the inner ear and upsetting your balance. Most hangover cures don't work, apart from paracetamol for the headache and a couple of Rennie's for the nausea. The Swiss like to breathe pure oxygen, Italians eat coffee with ash and Jamaicans rub lemons and limes under their armpits. I have no idea whether any of these traditional remedies work.

Help! I weigh 19 stone

Q I'm a 32 year old man, 5ft 10in and very overweight. I weigh around 19 stone and have been told I must lose weight or risk serious illness. I've tried really hard - working out at the gym and watching what I eat, but have only managed to lose a few pounds. My GP has offered me Xenical but I don't like the sound of the side effects. What do you think?

A I'd take it if I were you. Orlistat (Xenical) stops you absorbing up to a third of the fat you eat by blocking the effect of the chemicals produced by the pancreas and stomach that let you absorb fat. You take a 120mg tablet with each meal. If you don't stick to a low fat diet, you may well get oily diarrhoea and unpleasant wind - which is quite a strong incentive to stick to a healthy diet. If you take 100 very overweight people who try to stick to a low calorie diet and take more exercise, 15 of them will lose 10% of their total weight in a year. With Orlistat, this goes up to 30. So it's not a guarantee, but it can boost your efforts.

What is a placebo?

Q My GP told me recently that I could take vitamin supplements if I wanted to because it would be a good placebo if nothing else. I wondered where the term 'placebo' came from but my GP didn't know. Do you?

A I didn't, until you asked. But some hasty research reveals that it's from the Latin meaning 'I shall please'. It was apparently used in the 14th century to mean hired mourners and, by 1785, was being used to mean a medicine. By 1811 it had taken on its modern usage, meaning a medicine intended to please rather than benefit the patient. In 1933 it was used to describe an inert treatment given to a control group against which the effectiveness of an active drug was measured. Doctors often say 'it's just placebo' meaning that a treatment is only doing you good because you think it is, not because of any measurable effect. But placebo has the advantage of not doing any harm, and the feelgood effect accounts for up to a third of our responses to medication. So I think we should say: 'Just because it's placebo, doesn't mean it's not working.'

Am I a chocolate addict?

Q What is it about chococolate that makes it so irresistable? I really want to cut down on my daily Fruit and Nut and nightly Celebrations but can't kick the habit. Any tips?

A Chocolate is choc-a-bloc with chemicals that activate our nervous system sending messages of subliminal delight through our brains. The fat and sugar give it its characteristic yummy texture and taste, and the high magnesium levels may appeal to those lacking in this trace element. You could try willpower (boring but worthy) or try a new line while you gorge yourself: 'I'm not a greedy pig, I'm just keeping up my magnesium levels.' But you are seeking advice from another chocaholic - I'm the wrong person to ask.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: Irish court halts IRA man's extradition to Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Irish court halts IRA man's extradition to Northern Ireland
fields.trailText:
The Irish high court today dramatically halted the extradition of former IRA man and
convicted murderer Angelo Fusco to Northern Ireland as he was being driven towards the
Ulster border.
fields.body:
The Irish high court today dramatically halted the extradition of former IRA man and convicted murderer Angelo Fusco to Northern Ireland as he was being driven towards the Ulster border.

The move followed an intervention by lawyers acting for Fusco, who was arrested by Irish police in Co Kerry last night. The court ordered that he should appear before it on Thursday for legal arguments about whether his extradition can proceed.

The former top IRA man was convicted of killing SAS Captain Herbert Westmacott 20 years ago. He is thought to have been living in Co Kerry with his partner and children for at least two years, and was arrested after being recognised by an Irish policeman.

The Belfast-born one-time senior IRA figure - who was sentenced to jail in his absence in Belfast in 1981 for the 1980 murder - was questioned overnight at Tralee police station, Co Kerry, and was being driven the 250 miles to the Ulster border when the high court ruling came. It had been expected that Fusco would be handed over to RUC custody at the Killeen border crossing point on the main road between Dublin and Belfast - in line with extradition warrants issued in 1992.

In 1981, Fusco was sentenced to jail in absentia for the 1980 murder of the most senior SAS man killed by the IRA.

Capt Westmacott was shot dead with an M-60 machine gun while leading an eight-man patrol in north Belfast during a raid on a house. Fusco was one of a number of men later arrested and charged with the killing. But two days before the end of their trial the accused escaped by shooting their way out of the courthouse in Belfast's Crumlin Road.

Fusco was arrested in the Irish Republic in 1982 and jailed for 10 years for the Belfast escape. During his sentence he tried to escape again and was imprisoned for a further three years. On his release with remission in 1992, Fusco was served with warrants for his extradition to Northern Ireland in connection with the murder conviction.

After a long-running legal process, he absconded when the Irish supreme court overruled a high court judgment blocking the order for his return to Belfast.

Fusco's extradition was halted today after his lawyers applied to the high court for a writ of habeas corpus. The action is thought to have been launched on the basis that the political circumstances relating to Northern Ireland had changed entirely because of the Good Friday agreement. Earlier, Martin Ferris, a senior member of Sinn Fein, had called on the Dublin government to rescind the extradition decision.

The reasons for the timing of Fusco's latest arrest were not immediately clear today. One line of speculation suggested that the Irish police might have acted against him as part of continuing operations to clamp down on the activities of hardline republican paramilitaries pledged to wreck the Northern Ireland peace process.

Fusco's extradition was automatically activated because he had previously exhausted all legal ways of avoiding his return to the north.

Fusco's position within the prison system in Northern Ireland, had he been extradited, was uncertain. The Northern Ireland Prison Service said it was for the sentence review commission - set up to administer early releases under the Good Friday agreement - to evaluate his case.

Almost all paramilitary prisoners will be freed by 28 July this year but some are excluded from the scheme, including those aligned to groups opposed to the peace process and inmates convicted of terrorist offences after the Good Friday deal was agreed in April 1998.

webTitle: Burundi peace initiative fades after rebels reject Mandela as mediator

fields.headline: Burundi peace initiative fades after rebels reject Mandela as mediator
fields.trailText: Hope that Nelson Mandela might bring an end to one of Africa's most bitter and bloody civil wars - the six-year conflict between Hutus and Tutsis in Burundi that has claimed close to 300,000 lives - has started to fade after the country's two main rebel armies rejected his appointment as the new mediator for peace talks.
fields.body:
Hope that Nelson Mandela might bring an end to one of Africa's most bitter and bloody civil wars - the six-year conflict between Hutus and Tutsis in Burundi that has claimed close to 300,000 lives - has started to fade after the country's two main rebel armies rejected his appointment as the new mediator for peace talks.

The leader of the Hutu rebel Forces for the Defence of Democracy, Jean Bosco Ndayikengurukiye, accused Mr Mandela of backing Burundi's Tutsi military government when he was president of South Africa.

'We have proof the government of South Africa helped the putschist government of Burundi with arms and helped them bypass a regional embargo,' he said. 'There is no point in sitting down with these people.'

The hardline Hutu Palipahutu faction also rejected Mr Mandela's appointment, saying it could not guarantee his safety if he travelled to Burundi.

Mr Mandela replaced the late former Tanzanian president, Julius Nyerere, as mediator. Burundi's government had accused Mr Nyerere of favouring the Hutu rebels, and said he had become an impediment to a settlement.

But Mr Mandela's advisers believe his credibility is such that, despite the rebels' rejection, he will at least get all of Burundi's antagonists around the same table for the first time since the civil war started after Tutsi soldiers murdered Burundi's first elected president, Melchior Ndadaye, in 1993 because he was Hutu.

Nearly two years of negotiation have faltered in part because Mr Nyerere refused to permit Mr Ndayikengurukiye's army to join the talks after it broke away from another rebel group.

Mr Mandela says he will adopt a different approach. 'We can't sideline anybody who can create instability in the country,' he said. 'We must find ways of accommodating them in these discussions, either by inviting them to join or by addressing them separately, but we cannot ignore them.'

Mr Mandela may be Burundi's last chance for a negotiated settlement of a war that is effectively tied to the conflicts in neighbouring Congo and Rwanda.

Jan van Eck, a former African National Congress member of parliament who has been working on the Burundi peace process for five years, says that without progress at the talks the war will escalate.

'The internal Burundian security, economic and political situation is fast deteriorating and fragmenting,' he said in his latest report. `The spectre of a new and more disastrous regional war, with even more pronounced ethnic overtones, is looming larger by the day.'

Burundi's civil war has intensified in recent months with rebel attacks close to the capital, Bujumbura. The government has responded by forcing about 800,000 Hutu villagers into what it calls relocation camps, but which the rebels describe as concentration camps.

Although the military government of Major Pierre Buyoya has managed to co-opt Hutu and Tutsi politicians into what he describes as a broad-based administration, his opponents accuse him of manoeuvring to maintain political and economic domination by the Tutsi minority.

As the government provides about three-quarters of all fulltime employment, whoever runs the state controls the jobs. Tutsis in Bujumbura fear a Hutu-run administration will throw them out of work.

Despite the rebels' call for the restoration of democracy, Mr Mandela's advisers say fresh elections are not even on the agenda. They are considering a nominated `transitional' administration of at least five years, with a 10-year mandate also a possibility.

However, the greatest obstacle to a settlement is security. Hutus were the target of attempted genocide by the overwhelmingly Tutsi army in 1972. And President Ndadaye's assassination provoked another bout of bloodletting, during which about 150,000 Hutus and Tutsis were killed.

The Hutu rebels are demanding to be integrated into the Tutsi-dominated army, and to make up at least half of the force. But many Tutsis fear that if they lose control of the military, there will be little to prevent Burundi from succumbing to a repetition of the 1994 genocide in neighbouring Rwanda.

Mr Mandela replaced the late former Tanzanian president, Julius Nyerere, as mediator. Burundi's government had accused Mr Nyerere of favouring the Hutu rebels, and said he had become an impediment to a settlement. But Mr Mandela's advisers believe his credibility is such that, despite the rebels' rejection, he will at least get all of Burundi's antagonists around the same table for the first time since the civil war started after Tutsi soldiers murdered Burundi's first elected president, Melchior Ndadaye, in 1993 because he was Hutu. Nearly two years of negotiation have faltered in part because Mr Nyerere refused to permit Mr Ndayikengurukiye's army to join the talks after it broke away from another rebel group. Mr Mandela says he will adopt a different approach. 'We can't sideline anybody who can create instability in the country,' he said. 'We must find ways of accommodating them in these discussions, either by inviting them to join or by addressing them separately, but we cannot ignore them.' Mr Mandela may be Burundi's last chance for a negotiated settlement of a war that is effectively tied to the conflicts in neighbouring Congo and Rwanda. Jan van Eck, a former African National Congress member of parliament who has been working on the Burundi peace process for five years, says that without progress at the talks the war will escalate. 'The internal Burundian security, economic and political situation is fast deteriorating and fragmenting,' he said in his latest report. `The spectre of a new and more disastrous regional war, with even more pronounced ethnic overtones, is looming larger by the day.' Burundi's civil war has intensified in recent months with rebel attacks close to the capital, Bujumbura. The government has responded by forcing about 800,000 Hutu villagers into what it calls relocation camps, but which the rebels describe as concentration camps. Although the military government of Major Pierre Buyoya has managed to co-opt Hutu and Tutsi politicians into what he describes as a broad-based administration, his opponents accuse him of manoeuvring to maintain political and economic domination by the Tutsi minority. As the government provides about three-quarters of all fulltime employment, whoever runs the state controls the jobs. Tutsis in Bujumbura fear a Hutu-run administration will throw them out of work. Despite the rebels' call for the restoration of democracy, Mr Mandela's advisers say fresh elections are not even on the agenda. They are considering a nominated `transitional' administration of at least five years, with a 10-year mandate also a possibility. However, the greatest obstacle to a settlement is security. Hutus were the target of attempted genocide by the overwhelmingly Tutsi army in 1972. And President Ndadaye's assassination provoked another bout of bloodletting, during which about 150,000 Hutus and Tutsis were killed. The Hutu rebels are demanding to be integrated into the Tutsi-dominated army, and to make up at least half of the force. But many Tutsis fear that if they lose control of the military, there will be little to prevent Burundi from succumbing to a repetition of the 1994 genocide in neighbouring Rwanda.

webTitle: PE points the way forward to the ECB

fields.headline: PE points the way forward to the ECB
fields.trailText: The 1990s weren't just a decade of evangelism for the Church of England. The United Cricket Board of South Africa has spent the ten years since readmission, in 1991, trying to attract a larger and wider audience to cricket. It was and is a huge task. While the white population retained a strong interest in cricket during isolation because of the strength of the provincial game, players like Graeme Pollock and rebel tours, disillusioned black youths turned to football.
fields.body:
The 1990s weren't just a decade of evangelism for the Church of England. The United Cricket Board of South Africa has spent the ten years since readmission, in 1991, trying to attract a larger and wider audience to cricket. It was and is a huge task. While the white population retained a strong interest in cricket during isolation because of the strength of the provincial game, players like Graeme Pollock and rebel tours, disillusioned black youths turned to football.

But it is not just the black and coloured communities that the authorities are targeting. They are also trying to win over women, who, according to Chris Day of the UCBSA, have an important role in cricket's future. Most of the teachers at primary school are women, and the board has trained between 300 and 500 as qualified coaches for mini cricket (the South African equivalent of Kwik Cricket). But it is not just because of their evangelical zeal that they are being targeted: the board genuinely seems to want a more inclusive game.

The crowd watching the second Test at Port Elizabeth, historically the most racially mixed of all the grounds in South Africa, contained a substantial number of women. There was certainly a far larger female presence among the South African fans than among the Barmy Army, or even Test Match crowds in England. Sitting high in the Grandstand, next to the St George's band, were a group of cricket friends: Charmaine, 46, Ellen, 46, and her daughter Lucinda, 17; Ursula, 45, and her daughter Nyree, 13. All black women from Port Elizabeth who are cricket mad and who come to St George's whenever there is a major game.

'We have known each other for years', says Charmaine. 'And though we might not see each other for ages we know that when we come to the cricket we will always meet.' 'We always sit here, next to the band', says Ellen. 'We meet such a lot of people and have a really enjoyable day. A lot has changed since readmission. More coloureds are attending matches, and blacks and whites are starting to mix. It is certainly more mixed in this stand than it used to be. We are all supporting South Africa and accommodate each other.'

The women feel completely at ease at the ground and say they are never made to feel stupid or patronised by men in the crowd. And, unlike in England, there is nothing unusual about a group of women coming to a match without male company.

Chris Day again: 'Market surveys now show that 35% of people who watch cricket on television or at the ground are women. And if for some reason a match is not shown on television or coverage stops early, the TV companies are inundated by phone calls, the majority of them from women.'

What do they like best about a day at the cricket? 'Everything', shouts Nyree. 'The fours and sixes of Lance Klusener, being away from home and having a peaceful and restful day. Our favourites are Zulu, who was fantastic today [the second day of his 175] and Jonty.' Ellen stops singing for a minute to interject, 'And don't forget the captain. My husband died twenty years ago but when I see Hansie I wish I was young again...'

Not everything is hunky-dory. The women complain that there are far too few matches at Port Elizabeth, that there are no day/nighters and no big screens on which to watch replays. But these women have a passion for cricket which relatively few of their counterparts in Britain have. Perhaps it is the weather, the success of South Africa, the party atmosphere at the ground or the wonderful music of the Port Elizabeth Brass Band, but whatever it is the ECB should bottle it and send out a free sample to every woman in the country in time for the 2000 season.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Campaigners keep up pressure on Nazi war crimes suspect

fields.headline: Campaigners keep up pressure on Nazi war crimes suspect
fields.standfirst: Related story: Deportation, not trial, for Nazi war crimes suspect
fields.trailText: Campaigners pledged today not to give up the fight to bring a suspected Nazi war criminal to justice.
fields.body:
Campaigners pledged today not to give up the fight to bring a suspected Nazi war criminal to justice.

Konrad Kalejs, 86, is believed to be planning to pre-empt government moves to deport him by leaving Britain voluntarily on Thursday. But campaigners said the police were continuing to investigate allegations that he was second-in-command of a unit responsible for murdering 30,000 people in Latvia during the second world war.

Pressure was also being put on the foreign office and Latvian authorities to try to ensure that if Mr Kalejs leaves the UK he will face justice abroad.

Lord Janner, chairman of the Holocaust Educational Trust, emerged from a meeting with home secretary Jack Straw today to declare: "This is not the end."

He said the trust hoped to meet Scotland Yard assistant commissioner David Veness as soon as possible to discuss the investigations.

Meetings were also being planned with the Latvian ambassador to Britain to discuss extraditing Mr Kalejs to the country where his alleged crimes took place, and with foreign secretary Robin Cook to consider the role Britain could play in a possible prosecution overseas.

Lord Janner said he believed the police had carried out a "proper and satisfactory" review of the evidence against Mr Kalejs before deciding there were insufficient grounds to arrest him. He added that he was very happy the investigations were continuing.

David Sunberg MEP, another trust member who met Mr Straw today, expressed dismay at the brevity of the police investigation and the decision to begin deportation proceedings. Mr Sunberg said police usually spent years investigating allegations before deciding whether or not to prosecute a suspected war criminal.

The decision to deport was "gesture politics" which, given that Mr Kalejs was leaving voluntarily, underlined the lack of action being taken by the government.

Mr Straw yesterday served Mr Kalejs with notice that he intended to deport him to Australia, where he has held a passport since 1957, giving him seven days to make representations.

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe demanded a public statement from Mr Straw on whether the police investigation was complete and whether there were outstanding areas of investigation.

"It would be a real betrayal of justice and human rights if Konrad Kalejs were to be prematurely deported and then new evidence were to be uncovered."

It is alleged that Mr Kalejs was second in command of a notorious Latvian secret police unit, the Arajs Kommando, responsible for murdering more than 30,000 people, primarily Jews, during the second world war. Mr Kalejs has dismissed his accusers as "liars and storytellers".

He arrived in Britain six months ago after being deported from Canada and the US and has been staying at Catthorpe Manor, Lutterworth, a retirement home run by the Latvian Welfare Fund.

The Australian authorities have pledged to consider any new evidence if he returns to the country.

The decision to deport Mr Kalejs has been criticised by the Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Jerusalem, which first exposed his whereabouts and has warned that a successful prosecution is unlikely to be brought against him anywhere in the world.

fields.headline: Jane Ratcliffe
fields.trailText: Jane Ratcliffe, who has died aged 82, was a passionate wildlife campaigner, naturalist and author, renowned for rescuing injured animals and releasing them back into the wild.
fields.body:
Jane Ratcliffe, who has died aged 82, was a passionate wildlife campaigner, naturalist and author, renowned for rescuing injured animals and releasing them back into the wild.

The enduring testimony to her fight against the digging, baiting and killing of badgers is the 1973 Badgers Act - the first protection for wild land mammals ever passed by parliament.

A resolution on badger protection submitted by Ratcliffe to her local Women's Institute in Cheshire was adopted by its national conference in 1970. She then helped Lord Arran pilot through his private member's bill, which made it an offence to "cruelly illtreat" badgers.

She combined this work with the physical protection of badgers from hunters with dogs, as well as recording the decline of the local badger populations, rescuing wounded badgers and moving whole setts to safer locations.

Through The Badger Gate (1974), her story of the battle, was serialised on BBC Radio 4.

Born in Dewsbury, Yorkshire, Ratcliffe's love of wild things began as a child, when she tended injured sparrows and house mice. She trained as a home economics teacher, got married, brought up three children and worked in an old people's home before devoting her time to wildlife.

For 25 years, she rescued hundreds of injured birds and mammals, including badgers, foxes, buzzards, owls, kestrels and peregrine falcons. As the title of her second book, Fly High, Run Free (1979), emphasised, she never sought to tame nature, preferring to release creatures back into the wild.

She worked with farmers and landowners to provide suitable habitat and breeding boxes for birds. As a member of the British Trust for Ornithology, she ringed her releases so their successful rehabilitation could be traced. One barn owl was recorded alive 10 years later.

Ratcliffe was a member of the wildlife trusts in Cheshire and the Lake District, where she and her husband, Teddy, had honeymooned in 1940, and where they retired to in 1980. There, she combined nursing injured animals with writing and international lecturing. Her final book, Wildlife In My Garden (1986), outlined the practical steps people could take to enliven their gardens with wildlife.

The magazine articles Ratcliffe wrote covered everything from building ponds for wildlife to constructing nestboxes for families of tawny owls. She even gave a paper to the Institute of Highway Engineers on the building of motorway underpasses to reduce the number of hedgehogs and badgers killed by traffic. Some of her writing has been translated into Italian, German and Japanese.

Ratcliffe's passion for nature was always allied to practical steps to allieviate the suffering of animals in her surroundings. As she argued in Through The Badger Gate: "We, as human beings, were lucky enough to have evolved a high-powered brain, but this does not give us such superiority over all living things that we are entitled to treat them in a servant and master relationship."

Suffering from Alzheimer's disease, she moved to a nursing home in Kendall in 1996. She is survived by Teddy, who nursed her through much of the 1990s, three children and five grandchildren.

 Edna Jane Ratcliffe, naturalist and writer, born June 2 1917; died December 3 1999

webTitle: Yet more things you wouldn't know without the movies

fields.headline: Yet more things you wouldn't know without the movies
fields.trailText: • Good guys won't be harmed after falling down the stairs. Bad guys will   die immediately.
fields.body:
 Good guys won't be harmed after falling down the stairs. Bad guys will die immediately.

 Monsters never die at once.

 You can make love with your boxers on.

 You can put your clothes over your pyjamas.

 No matter how high the wall may be, the bad guys' car will pass over it before exploding.

 You can disassemble anything with a one cent coin.

 The last centimetre of fuse will take 30 minutes to burn.

 Always cut the other wire to stop a bomb.

 American cars' doors can stop any size of bullet.

 Buildings will only explode after you have crossed the door.

 Cars will explode if turned on by your sweetheart.

 American cars don't have mirrors.

 Six-bullet guns can hold up to 10,000 bullets, depending on how good you are.

 The vital evidence will remain hidden until the last day of the trial.

 Laboratories can discover anything from a 0.001 cubic centimetre of cloth.

 Anyone can get into the Pentagon's or FBI's files.

Thanks to: Augusto

fields.headline: Millennium bug fails to bite
fields.trailText: The much-hyped millennium bug failed to wreak any kind of chaos as Britain got back to work today, although bug watchers cautioned that Y2K computer problems could yet emerge.
fields.body:
The much-hyped millennium bug failed to wreak any kind of chaos as Britain got back to work today, although bug watchers cautioned that Y2K computer problems could yet emerge.

Robin Guenier, head of Taskforce 2000, the independent bug watchdog, said just 5% of all potential bug problems were likely to occur at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve.

"I am more concerned about databases and billing systems and general administrative systems which are vital to businesses. I am concerned whether they have had the same attention as other things," he said.

The private sector, the banking system and the London stock exchange all reported a clean bill of health, although fears of imminent interest rate increases caused shares to plummet 229 points in the first few hours of trading.

A Scottish hospital where a kidney dialysis machine suffered a computer failure - possibly caused by the millennium bug - today revealed another machine had also malfunctioned.

Monklands District Hospital, in Airdrie, near Glasgow, said two of the machines had suffered a malfunction at midnight on January 1, not one, as had earlier been reported.

An investigation was under way into how the machines suffered the failure, and if it was related to the bug.

Millennium bug minister Margaret Beckett has dismissed claims that the crisis had been over-hyped, saying Britain owed a "great debt of gratitude" to those who had helped avoid a New Year computer crisis.

But Mrs Beckett said the virtually bug-free weekend had been the result of years of hard work and money well spent.

"Things don't go right by accident," she said. "People across the world have found all kinds of date change faults in business and public services which, as a result of money, effort and time, have been fixed.

"I think we owe a great debt of gratitude to those people who have worked flat out over the last two years to make sure that we have up to now had a peaceful transition in to the year 2000."

The government's millennium centre continued to report business as usual in departments and key public services on Monday.

The government has spent about £430 million while private industry is thought to have spent about £20 billion fixing the bug and preparing contingency plans in case the worst happened.

Technology advisers Gartner Group estimate that worldwide governments and industry have spent up to £360 billion.

fields.headline: Bowlers star in Ranji Trophy
fields.trailText: India
fields.body:
India

The most outstanding performance in the latest round of Ranji Trophy matches came in the Central Zone game at Kanpur, where medium-pacer Ashish Winston Zaidi set up a ten-wicket win for Uttar Pradesh against Vidarbha with match figures of 15-192. Zaidi began the destruction with 9-45 as Vidarbha were skittled for 98 in their first innings, and then claimed 6-147 in a second innings of 331 (Alind Naidu 118*). In between, Uttar Pradesh racked up 404, with 112 from Mohammad Kaif, and 95 from Rizwan Shamshad.

There was another fine bowling display in the drawn West Zone game at Pune, where Maharashtra bowler Iqbal Siddiqui took 8-72 in Saurashtra's first innings of 217. And he might have had nine had not Manoj Parmar retired hurt for 58. Kaushik Aphale then hit 158 as Maharashtra replied strongly with 431, but Saurashtra closed on 374 for 5 in their second innings (Shitanshu Kotak 126) to force a draw. Siddiqui finished with ten in the match after taking 2-92.

Yet another bowler starred in Assam's innings-and-56-run crushing of Tripura at Mangoldoi in the East Zone. Left-arm medium-pacer Gautam Dutta returned first-innings figures of 11.3-3-23-8 as Tripura were humbled for 57. Assam were then reduced to 58 for 6, but were rescued by some good late-order hitting, especially from No.10 Sukhbinder Singh, who blasted a scintillating 73 from 68 balls, with five fours and five sixes, to raise the total to 249. Tripura then folded again, for 136, as Dutta added two more wickets to make it ten in the match.

Two former Test batsmen helped Mumbai to a comfortable ten-wicket win against Gujarat at Surat in the West Zone. Replying to Gujarat's 305 (Paras Mhambrey 4-71), Mumbai totalled 419, thanks to 173 from opener Wasim Jaffer and 116 by Vinod Kambli. Mhambrey then added four more wickets as Gujarat stumbled to 167, and the Mumbai openers did the rest. In the other West Zone match, Tamil Nadu forced Hyderabad to follow on, but 135 from opener Ammanabrole Nandakrishore and 69 from ex-Indian captain Mohammad Azharuddin ensured a draw; Azha had earlier made 84 in the first innings.

In the South Zone at Kakinda, the reigning champions Karnataka won a close game against Andhra by 46 runs. Set 191 to win in the fourth innings, Andhra were bowled out for 144 by the medium-pace of Mansoor Ali Khan, who took 6-47. At Margao, Kerala trounced Goa by ten wickets, with legspinner Suresh Kumar returning first-innings figures of 18-10-21-5.

Twin centuries from Orissa batsman Pravanjan Mullick weren't enough to defeat Bengal at Cuttack.Mullick hit 108 and 111*, but Rohan Gavaskar replied with 115 as the game finished in a draw. Railways drew with Rajasthan in the Central Zone at Delhi.

Australia

Queensland moved up to third in the one-day Mercantile Mutual Cup table ahead of Victoria, whom they thrashed by eight wickets in a day/night game at the Gabba. Victoria were dismissed for 193 as Michael Kasprowicz claimed 3-29, before Queensland made mincemeat of their target, romping home with almost 19 overs to spare. Matthew Hayden hit 78*, and added 125 for the second wicket with Stuart Law, who scored 60. Andrew Symonds provided a flourish at the end with an unbeaten 45 off just 31 balls. Damien Fleming had figures of 10-2-50-0, while Shane Warne was battered to the tune of 6-0-43-1.

New South Wales were still top of the table with 5 points from 4 games, followed by Western Australia (4 points, 2 games), Queensland (4,4), Victoria (4,5), South Australia (3,3), Tasmania (2,2) and Canberra (0,2).

South Africa

In the latest round of the one-day Standard Bank competition, KwaZulu-Natal overcame Western Province by 39 runs at Cape Town. Natal opened with 214 for 5 from their 45 overs, with Dale Benkenstein hitting 78* after being dropped on 6 and 10. Lance Klusener biffed a quickfire unbeaten 48, and Alan Dawson took 3-24. WP were well-placed at 137 for 2 in reply, but lost their last eight wickets in 8.2 overs for 48 runs, as Eldine Baptiste finished with 3-33.

It was a case of nightmare at Port Elizabeth for North West who were bowled out 140 by Eastern Province seamer Garnett Kruger, who claimed 6-23. EP cruised to victory, reaching 141 for 4 in 33.4 overs.

At East London, Border lost four wickets with the score on 75 and were eventually dismissed for 123 by Boland, who got home for the loss of six wickets. The match between Easterns and Northerns was ruined by rain.

New Zealand

The one-day 50-over-a-side Shell Cup got under way this week, with the six sides playing two games each. The early leaders were Auckland, who began with a four-wicket win against Wellington at Eden Park. Wellington were hurried out for 111, after crumbling from 79 for 2, as Adams took 3-3 from 22 balls. Auckland tottered themselves, declining from 62 for 1 to 99 for 6, but won with more than ten overs to spare.

They followed that win with another, more comfortable victory over Central Districts. Adams again starred, taking 5-20 from his 10 overs as CD scraped together 123, before Auckland got to their target for the loss of just one wicket with almost 17 overs to spare.

Second in the table, on run-rate, are Canterbury. They beat Otago by five wickets at Christchurch, winning off the penultimate ball as they chased 241. Chris Harris steered Canterbury to victory with an undefeated 90, after Doody had hit 95. Otago captain Robert Lawson had earlier scored 74 in his side's total of 240 for 4. Canterbury then saw off Northern Districts by 20 runs at Blake Park, with 70 from Englefield and 59 from Doody. Fast bowler Chris Martin undermined the ND run-chase with 5-43 as they closed on 209 for 9.

Two days earlier, ND had beaten CD by four wickets. ND were indebted to an unbroken stand of 53 for the seventh wicket between opener Parlane (80*) and Alex Tait (21*) as they successfully chased 168 to win.

In the final game of the second round, Otago beat Wellington by 33 runs at Molyneux Park. Wellington are bottom after the first two rounds.

fields.headline: Waterstone's ain't what it used to be
fields.trailText: Waterstone's rose to success at least in part because it gave its sales staff an unprecedented degree of control over the books they stocked and the way they arranged and displayed them. An enlightened and very profitable policy all round, it had one or two particularly splendid results. Thus Ray Monk, who worked at the Charing Cross branch while writing his celebrated biography of Wittgenstein, created the best philosophy section of any bookshop in London. Monk has since gone on to greater things, but that shop's shelves still carry a few treatises by obscure German and French logicians that bear the imprint of his presence.
fields.body:
Waterstone's rose to success at least in part because it gave its sales staff an unprecedented degree of control over the books they stocked and the way they arranged and displayed them. An enlightened and very profitable policy all round, it had one or two particularly splendid results. Thus Ray Monk, who worked at the Charing Cross branch while writing his celebrated biography of Wittgenstein, created the best philosophy section of any bookshop in London. Monk has since gone on to greater things, but that shop's shelves still carry a few treatises by obscure German and French logicians that bear the imprint of his presence.

But Waterstone's, facing stiff competition from Borders and the internet, is not, perhaps, all that it was. I was surprised to wander into the philosophy section of Waterstone's in Gower Street last week - until recently one of London's three or four leading bookshops - to find that someone had decorated the eastern philosophy section with bells, lamps and incense holders. Worse still, someone had divided the whole of post-medieval western philosophy into two classes, continental and Anglo-American.

It is easy enough to understand the thinking behind this new arrangement. Most educated Britons don't know much about philosophy, but the one thing they do know, or think they know, is that it is riven by a conflict between analytic and continental schools, where the first believes in reason, clarity and science and the second in something else. Despite the firm grip it exercises over non-philosophers (and, alas, quite a few philosophers), this remains one of the silliest distinctions ever made - as the philosopher Bernard Williams said, it is like dividing cars into two classes: left-hand drive and made in Japan. And in Gower Street it has had some very strange results.

I was interested to see, for instance, that the great German logician Gottlob Frege has been assigned to the Anglo-American section, despite the fact that he never, to my knowledge, wrote a word of philosophy in English and has exercised a considerable influence over European as well as Anglo-American logic.

Voltaire, on the other hand, goes into continental, despite the fact that he was a follower of Locke and in matters intellectual an admirer of all things English. Russell's The Philosophy of Leibniz, a study of the 17th-century German rationalist whom Russell much admired, goes into Anglo-American.

The anomalies continue. Sokal and Bricmont's recent Intellectual Impostures, an attack on the pseudo-scientific pronouncements of certain contemporary continental philosophers, must have given the staff a bit of a headache. How to classify a book by an American and a Belgian about European philosophy, written from an analytic perspective? In the end they opted for Anglo-American. Post-Analytic Philosophy, on the other hand, a collection of 1980s essays by American philosophers of varying allegiances, has gone into the continental section. The American Richard Rorty, who admires those arch continentals Heidegger and Sartre, has gone into Anglo-American, but his colleague Stanley Cavell, who admires the British analytic philosopher John Austin, has gone into continental. Waterstone's, oddly, does not stock any of the British Hegelians who dominated English philosophy a century ago. Is this chance, or were they returned to supplier 'uncategorisable'?

I could go on, but it should be clear by now that the whole basis of the classification is, to put it mildly, a little unworkable. The truth is that British and American philosophy have, throughout their history, existed in a state of constant interchange with European. Hobbes and Descartes met and exchanged letters; Locke read Gassendi; Hume was as at home in France as he was in England and knew both Voltaire and Rousseau.

Coleridge read Hegel; Russell read Peano. Logical positivism, one of the main sources of modern Anglo-American analytic philosophy, originated in Vienna, as did Wittgenstein, another important influence. Indeed, it is very hard to think of a great American or British philosopher who has not taken important ideas from European thinkers, even if the reverse is not quite so true.

It goes without saying that everyone pays homage to the Greeks. And of course neither British nor American philosophy, let alone Anglo-American philosophy, is a simple entity in itself. The English like to think of empiricism as a home-grown thing, but of 'our' leading empiricist philosophers, Berkeley was Irish, Hume and Mill were Scottish and AJ Ayer was half Dutch-Jewish, half French-Swiss.

The Anglo-American/continental distinction would hardly matter if it were just silly, which it is, but it is also invidious. It plays to one of the worst features of the English (and I mean the English more than the British): their insularity. Norman Davies's new history, The Isles, reminds us that the history of the British Isles is not the same thing as 'English' history and that neither can be understood other than as a part of the history of Europe. What we need now is a book that does the same thing for the history of 'British' philosophy.

 Ben Rogers is the author of AJ Ayer, A Life (Chatto & Windus, Ë20)

webTitle: Three French tourists killed in Namibia

fields.headline: Three French tourists killed in Namibia
fields.standfirst: Foreign & Commonwealth Office: Travel warnings
fields.trailText: Three French tourists have been killed in the Namibian border town of Rundu, police reported today.
fields.body:
Three French tourists have been killed in the Namibian border town of Rundu, police reported today.

The area has been the focus of recent troop movements in fighting between Angolan government forces and rebels.

"Details are still sketchy at the moment, but we can confirm that an attack on tourists took place last night in the Rundu area," a police spokesman said.

South African radio reported that one adult and two children died when gunmen fired on their vehicle. It said two vehicles carrying French tourists were attacked and stripped of all their possessions.

The radio said three other vehicles carrying civilians and aid workers were also fired upon in the same area.

Heavy fighting between Angolan government troops and UNITA rebels has been reported along the border with Namibia in recent weeks, with the Namibian government allowing their Angolan allies to launch attacks from their soil.

The area is home to some of Namibia's best game reserves and is very popular with foreign tourists.

The British foreign office doesn't currently advise against visiting the area, but the US embassy warned its US citizens to avoid the area last month.

webTitle: Deportation, not trial, for Nazi war crimes suspect

fields.headline: Deportation, not trial, for Nazi war crimes suspect
fields.standfirst:
Simon Wiesenthal Center
The holocaust history project
The Home Office: Immigration information
Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: The home secretary is to deport the suspected war criminal Konrad Kalejs rather than prosecute him without Britain requesting or examining the most authoritative body of evidence against him.
fields.body:
The home secretary is to deport the suspected war criminal Konrad Kalejs rather than prosecute him without Britain requesting or examining the most authoritative body of evidence against him.

Jack Straw announced yesterday that Mr Kalejs, who entered Britain in September, will be deported to Australia where he is a citizen despite demands from Nazi hunters that he be tried in Britain for involvement in mass murder.

Australia has already refused to prosecute Mr Kalejs, 86, who was deported from the United States and Canada because he was joint second in command of the feared Latvian Arajs Kommando. It collaborated with the Nazi occupiers of the Baltic state and killed an estimated 30,000 people, mainly Jews.

Nazi hunters fear the decision to return Kalejs to Australia will mean he will never have to answer for his alleged crimes and accused Jack Straw of lacking the will to prosecute war criminals.

The main body of evidence against Mr Kalejs was gathered by the US justice department, who yesterday confirmed to the Guardian that they had received no request from any British authority for the thousands of pages they hold. A justice department source expressed amazement that they had not been asked to supply evidence including statements from victims of the unit and officers who say they served alongside Kalejs, which are all held on a CD Rom.

Mike Whine of the board of deputies said: 'That's bottling out, the home secretary took the easy option. Its a shame if the evidence is available elsewhere that he didn't call it to review.

'It doesn't look like there is the political will to prosecute war criminals.' Dr Efraim Zuroff, director of the Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Jerusalem, said: 'That's outrageous. I can't understand a decision like that, it is a cop out.

'The decision shows a desire to get rid of the problem rather than to strike a blow for justice and morality.'

Simon Hughes, the liberal democrat's home affairs spokesman, said: 'All the evidence, from Australia, Canada and the US should be looked at and they've had a week to ask for it. To make a decision without seeing or assessing it, would be a gross dereliction of duty by the home secretary without assuring himself that the police had seen all the evidence. It make me doubt if everything was done that could be done.'

'Playing human pass the parcel with war crimes suspects does not bring justice for anybody.' Mr Straw defended his decision by saying that a thorough investigation by officers from the Metropolitan Police had not found enough evidence to arrest Kalejs.

He told BBC Radio that there was the political will to prosecute alleged war criminals: 'The police have pursued these inquiries very assiduously. They have concluded that there is at present no grounds on which they can make an arrest.

'We have to follow the rule of law, there is insufficient evidence at this stage to effect an arrest, so no arrest can be made.' A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: 'Scotland Yard officers have made a comparison with information in the possession of the Australian authorities. There are at present no grounds for the metropolitan police service to effect an arrest.'

Mr Kalejs has seven days to lodge any appeal against the home secretary's deportation notice. He is staying at a Latvian retirement home in the village of Catthorpe in Leicestershire and has dismissed his accusers as 'liars and storytellers'.

Kalejs is believed to be planning to leave Britain voluntarily as soon as Thursday, having entered Britain via Birmingham airport on an Australian passport and having permission to stay until March.

Kalejs was joint second in command in the Latvian security auxiliary police, knownas the Arajs Kommando after its leader Victor Arajs. He was sentenced to life for war crimes after being tried in Germany. Kalejs served at the Salaspils concentration camp outside Riga, where Jews and political prisoners were executed or died due to appalling conditions.

After the war Kalejs gained Australian citizenship before moving to the US in 1959 from where he was deported in 1994 and Canada in 1997.

Zelda Chayat, whose family was murdered by the unit, called to Kalejs to be punished: 'War criminals should be punished and sent to jail to finish their lives there.

Mrs Chayat, who is Jewish, hid in a flat in Riga from 1941-4 with her husband who went to military academy with Kalejs. She said she heard a group of officers, including Kalejs, bragging about killing Jews shortly after two massacres in Latvia in November and December 1941.

webTitle: Love in the time of codgers

fields.headline: Love in the time of codgers
fields.standfirst: So Michael Caine and his ilk don't want leading ladies their own age. When will movies start to reflect real life, asks Caroline Sullivan
fields.trailText: So Michael Caine and his ilk don't want leading ladies their own age. When will movies start to reflect real life, asks Caroline Sullivan
fields.body:
'These days,' Michael Caine said last week, 'my fear of accepting a role where I get the girl is that the girl will look like Margaret Rutherford. I don't want a love scene with a woman who looks like me, for goodness' sake. I've always liked my women younger.'

Nice guy. And in his next film, Quills, the 66-year-old actor marries a 17-year-old who, in typical Hollywood style, has no misgivings about plighting her troth to a man half a century her senior, prostate trouble and all. Caine adds that he was inspired by Sean Connery's seduction of 30-year-old Catherine Zeta Jones in Entrapment: 'I saw Sean do that and thought: "What about me?"'

A number of his contemporaries have been thinking the same thing, even if they are not crass enough to voice it. Warren Beatty, 53, was paired with Halle Berry, 25, in Bulworth; craggy old Jack Nicholson wooed twentysomething Helen Hunt in As Good As It Gets; and 56-year-old Harrison Ford ended up with Anne Heche, 27, in Six Days, Seven Nights. It's a tradition dating back to Woody Allen obsessing over a teenage Mariel Hemingway in the 70s hit Manhattan. Aware of the raised eyebrows, Ford said: 'Every time I see somebody commenting on the difference between an actor's and an actress's age, I say to myself: "Hey, look around at life".' Yes, Harrison, look around at life. You'll find only ageing rock stars and Peter Stringfellow comport themselves with girls too young to remember any prime minister before Margaret Thatcher.

But let's forget life for a moment and ask what attitudes like Ford's and Caine's mean for actresses who have the rotten luck to be over 35. Sharon Stone, 41, lamented the lack of leading roles for women her age in a recent interview. It's as if the Hollywood establishment gets queasy at the idea of casting a fortysomething as a sexual being, she said. And this is Sharon Stone, venerated as one of the great beauties of our time. Presumably in a few years she'll count herself lucky to land character parts, which is what the equally glamorous Kathleen Turner is relegated to in a remake of Cinderella in which she plays the wicked stepmother. Turner, by the way, is 46.

Even Madonna, who was instrumental in opening the discourse on female assertiveness way back in the last century, is now described with that veiled insult 'ageless'. She is 41, which is enough for her to be lumped in with the much older Cher in a piece on 'groovy grannies' in the current issue of More! magazine. Late-thirtysomethings such as Jodie Foster and Kristin Scott Thomas must be glumly anticipating their transition from leading ladies to playing Gwyneth Paltrow's mother.

An actress's life as a leading lady is compressed into a few short years. The goalposts may have shifted since the old days of Hollywood, when 30 was the cut-off between glamour and character parts, but as Stone says, even the biggest stars are powerless in the face of the passage of time

So what about some role reversal? What if, say, the upcoming romantic blockbuster The End Of The Affair had teamed its 37-year-old star, Ralph Fiennes, with his real-life partner, the frankly middle-aged Francesca Annis? Yuk, Harrison Ford says: 'If it was an older woman and a younger man, that wouldn't be too much like real life.' Well, not real life as you know it, Harrison. But you'd look a sight more dignified with a woman your own age.

It's ludicrous that an unmade bed like Caine can make demands about the age of his co-stars and be taken seriously. (Would he consider the gorgeous Kim Basinger or Rene Russo, both 44, too geriatric?) The answer - apart from a change of attitude in which elderly actors see how implausible May-December romances are to viewers - could be that actresses turn down improbable scripts. Paltrow admitted playing love scenes with the oak-aged Michael Douglas in A Perfect Murder made her feel 'kind of creepy'. It might be a start towards a time when films imitate real life.

webTitle: The artist as drawn by his daughter

fields.headline: The artist as drawn by his daughter
fields.standfirst: What would Edward Ardizzone have made of the new editions of his Little Tim books as we approach the centenary of his birth? He would have loved them, his daughter, Christianna Clemence, tells Joanna Carey
fields.trailText:
Little Tim and the Brave Sea Captain, Scholastic, £9.99.
Tim and Lucy Go To Sea Scholastic, £9.99.
What would Edward Ardizzone have made of the new editions of his Little Tim books as we approach the centenary of his birth? He would have loved them, his daughter, Christianna Clemence, tells Joanna Carey
fields.body:
"He drew constantly - always carried a sketchbook, usually a publisher's 'dummy' - but, failing that, he drew on envelopes or the backs of cigarette boxes. Even his letters had drawings all over - I grew up thinking all correspondence was illustrated: when I went away to school I was surprised by the dull letters all the other girls received. Pa was always drawing. We just took it for granted - it was what he did."

Christianna Clemence is talking about her father, Edward Ardizzone. His self-portrait hangs on the wall behind her and bears quite a resemblance to her young grandson, Tom, who's visiting, and who waits patiently as we talk.

Edward Ardizzone (1900-1979) was one of the best-known, best-loved and most influential and important of all 20th century illustrators. Astonishingly prolific, his work includes watercolours, oils, prints, magazine illustrations including those for the Radio Times (which, in its heyday, was a marvellous showcase for illustrators) and, on a larger scale, the famous lithographs for the old J Lyons teashops, posters and even murals for an ocean liner. And, of course, he was a distinguished war artist. He illustrated more than 180 books - from Shakespeare, Dickens, Galsworthy to Walter de la Mare, Eleanor Farjeon and a delightful autobiography - and is perhaps best known for his Little Tim books, which grew from the stories he told Christianna and her brother as children.

They lived in London and Christianna - now 70 and a hugely entertaining storyteller herself - paints a vivid picture of the family home in Maida Vale, whose streets, shops, pubs, parks and raffish local characters are recorded with such affectionate relish in Ardizzone's work. Ardizzone worked at home; he had been a clerk in his father's firm, forever embellishing the accounts with drawings and doodles, and attending life classes at Westminster School of Art in the evenings, but he gave up that job to become a professional artist.

"He started with book jackets," says Christianna, "but money was scarce, so Ma, who was very beautiful and very tall, got a job as a fashion model and Pa looked after us at home while he worked. The house smelled deliciously of turpentine, and he sat at his desk up on a model's throne, on the first floor. With no garden, and a very dark nursery, my brother and I just larked around the studio; mostly he ignored our squabbles and screams, but he'd attend to the odd splinter, and now and again he'd say 'please don't lean out of the window!' or 'please don't climb on the roof'."

And did you obey? "Of course not - we couldn't hear him, anyway, if we were out on the roof. But it was perfectly safe - one of those huge Victorian houses where behind the parapet you could get access to all the different levels," she says briskly (and for a moment I wonder where her grandson has got to). And did he prepare your meals? "Oh, yes, he was a much better cook than our mother! Usually it was semolina and pineapple chunks... and he'd take us out to the park to play, and sometimes I walked down to the framers with him when he had exhibitions at the Leger Gallery. He read to us a lot at bedtime, but we'd always end up asking for "real stories" - ie, the ones he made up himself, and he'd say: 'Well, now ... let's see ... how does it go?' "

So with these exemplary "parenting skills" was he an early version of "new man"? "Absolutely not! Very old-fashioned in his ideas about women... no question of girls going to university - you just had to hope to get married!"

And, indeed, Christianna, as a little girl, had elaborate plans to secure a comfortable future by making friends with rich old gentlemen in Paddington recreation ground where their father took them to play... and that's what inspired the story Lucy Brown and Mr Grimes.

"In his innocence, it didn't occur to Pa that it wasn't a very good example for little girls, and the story had to be somewhat modified.

"Luckily, though, no one objected to the hair-raising situations from which Little Tim makes such heroic escapes - and it's the same benevolent Mr Grimes who so obligingly forks out for the steam yacht Evangeline, in which Tim and Lucy Go To Sea. Reading these stories with my sons was, for me, one of the major delights of parenthood - and the creation of them was clearly very important to Ardizzone.

"He talked about them a lot," says Christianna, "about the simple text, the structure, and the importance of a turning point in the narrative." And although the line and wash drawings, with that vigorous, distinctive hatching and cross-hatching seem so spontaneous, "he'd draw and redraw until he got it exactly right". Lucy and Tim were based on Christianna and her brother, so did they have to sit still to be drawn?

"Oh, no! He didn't draw from life except in formal life classes: he did all his drawing from memory, drawing what he'd seen half-an-hour before. And I have a theory that the speed and fluency of his drawing was partly due to the fact that he had a bit of a stammer - drawing was a much easier form of communication."

And it's that ease of visual communication that allows the pictures to tell so much of the story. Though packed with information, the detail is never fussy or laboured - gestures and facial expressions, however breezily suggested, are marvellously eloquent, the humour is gentle and his perfect understanding of composition, however dramatic, always conveys an overall sense of well-being.

In his illuminating book on Ardizzone, Gabriel White laments the fact that the artist spent so much time on children's books - as opposed to "general illustration" - but really, how lucky that is. Children brought up on these books will never forget the atmospheric vitality of his drawing, will always feel, at any stage of their life, that leap of recognition when they encounter his work - wherever it may be - in books, galleries or at the Imperial War Museum. And anyway, as Christianna points out, her father didn't make much distinction between work for children and work for adults - "he always treated us as equals - he would certainly never talk down or draw down to children." As with Tim and Lucy, whatever happened he simply expected them to rise to the occasion.

Calling to mind Hogarth, Rowlandson, Cruickshank and Daumier, Ardizzone's style has its roots firmly in the traditions of the 18th and 19th centuries; his work spans the greater part of the 20th century; and now, ensuring its accessibility in the new millennium, Scholastic is re-publishing all the Little Tim stories.

In order to create fresh, bright books rather than fusty facsimiles, they've used the latest technology to scan Ardizzone's original colour washes, with the black lines on a separate overlay. Christianna has been involved at every stage of this sensitive operation.

Two of the books are already published, and the rest will appear during 2000 - to celebrate the centenary of Ardizzone's birth. "It's astonishing! It all looks so crisp and lovely - only trouble is the modern scanners are so efficient they picked up all the underdrawing - and you could even see where the cat had walked across the drawing board. Drat that cat! as Pa would say. But they've removed the splodges and the result is wonderful!

"Oh, yes, Pa would have loved it."

 Little Tim and the Brave Sea Captain, Scholastic, £9.99.

Tim and Lucy Go To Sea, Scholastic, £9.99.

fields.headline: Readers on our readers
fields.trailText: What a miserable bunch of whingers. Just how many lavs would you need to deal with 2m people?
fields.body:
What a miserable bunch of whingers. Just how many lavs would you need to deal with 2m people? From the moment our little bunch of 60+ year olds were greeted by the friendly voices of the LT staff at London Bridge to being whisked back home from King's Cross at 2am with no hassle, the amiable, multicultural throng was the most optimistic phenomenon I have encountered in a long time. I am beginning to understand why the phrase 'Guardian reader' has taken on pejorative overtones.
Brian Blain
London

 Ever since whoever it was suggested a sample of gifts for the millennium child, the letters page has been full of smug scoffers, cynics and moaners. Yesterday out of 27 letters, 19 were moans and complaints more suited to the columns of the Telegraph. Has liberal guilt changed to liberal bile?
Anne Hughes
Seaford, E Sussex.
AnneHughes2@compuserve.com

 The magazine I edit is well-known for the bilious whingeing and moaning that fills its letters pages each month. Our most recent readership survey found that 35% of ours were also Guardian readers, streets (nay, broad leafy boulevards) ahead of any other daily. Your letters page gives a clear indication that things aren't going to change very much this century, are they?
Ian Anderson
Editor, Folk Roots magazine froots@froots.demon.co.uk

 One of the oddest things those of us from overseas find about the British character is your attitude to any form of success or achievement. You stage the biggest millennium celebrations in the world, have the biggest and best party in the spectacularly unique Dome, and cover the event with 30 hours of superb television. And what is everyone talking about? A few queues of disgruntled people and a handful of fireworks that failed to ignite. You really should be so proud of your successes  I know that I was proud to be with you all on the big night.
Robert Petric
Zagreb, Croatia

 Come on people, sort it out. Let's be thankful that it was only water ('yes, but acidic water') raining down on us, not bombs, and that at the very least the majority of us were able to watch the 'failures' in the knowledge that we could return to our homes, drink our champagne ('yes, but it was warm champagne') and make a toast to the fact that we saw in the new century happy, healthy and loved.
Katharine Holliday
Colchester, Essex

fields.headline: Summer schools for all 11-year-olds
fields.standfirst:
Extra classes aimed at easing transition from primaries

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government will this week reveal long-term plans to set up summer schools for all 11-year-olds as part of a scheme to smooth pupils' transition from primary to secondary education.
fields.body:
The government will this week reveal long-term plans to set up summer schools for all 11-year-olds as part of a scheme to smooth pupils' transition from primary to secondary education.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, will announce the first stage of the programme with a commitment to provide almost 2,500 summer schools this year, including 500 that will be geared to meet the needs of the most gifted. This should provide places for up to 100,000 children.

The summer holiday provision for 11-year-olds will be in addition to the adventure-style camps that the government is planning for all 16-year-olds, as reported yesterday.

Mr Blunkett will tell the North of England education conference in Wigan on Thursday that he is determined to tackle the slump in pupils' performance in their first two years of secondary school.

He has been alarmed by research showing that 40% of children end their first year of secondary education with lower levels of literacy and numeracy than when they arrived.

Mr Blunkett intends to address this decline by transferring some of the teaching techniques used in the literacy and numeracy hours in primary schools into the early years of secondary education.

The summer schools will be used to give 11-year-olds a better chance of making a smooth transition. The programme started in 1997 with provision at 50 secondary schools, expanding to 600 in 1998 and 1,300 in 1999. The policy was originally targeted at pupils who were thought unlikely to make the grade in English, maths and science at secondary school. But this year about a fifth of the planned 2,500 programmes will be geared towards particularly talented children and the range of ac tivities will be extended to cover music and the arts.

'We are going to do this in a way that projects our idea that eventually we will have a summer school place available for all children whose parents want it,' Mr Blunkett said.

When the programme first started, there were suspicions that it would be unpopular with teachers, parents and pupils who might see it as an infringement of their holiday.

'Teachers have thrown themselves into it with enthusiasm. Parents love it because their children have something to do instead of getting bored. And the children say they have enjoyed it,' Mr Blunkett said.

Other proposals for smoothing the transition to secondary education are expected to include transferring some pupils nearing the end of their last term in primary school to give them an early taste of the secondary experience. The government has also been impressed with experiments giving secondary teachers time in primary schools to assess their incoming pupils.

Mr Blunkett will also announce on Thursday his plans to help 16-year-olds make the transition to employment after school. He wants them all to experience summer camps to develop self-confidence and help them mature.

Camps running between June and September would offer outdoor trips including climbing and orienteering. Other options will include extended work experience and voluntary jobs. The scheme will be funded by national lottery money.
