fields.standfirst:
In one Birmingham primary school, women are studying alongside their children with 
the aim of being 
the next generation 
of teachers. 
Chris Arnot reports
fields.trailText: In one Birmingham primary school, women are studying alongside their children with the aim of being the next generation of teachers. Chris Arnot reports
fields.body:
Headteacher Ian Lane leads the way out through the Victorian red-brick portals of the handsomely restored Anderton Park School towards a cluster of huts which, he points out, "were due for demolition in 1949". Half a century on, and they're still being put to good use. Through the windows of one we can see year 6 pupils bent over their books. Another houses a computer course, another an A-level Urdu class and yet another a degree course.

Yes, this is a primary school and no, the ones studying for their degrees are not astonishingly precocious 11-year-olds. They are mothers or older sisters, for the most part, of pupils from Anderton Park or from any one of 25 schools here in Sparkhill or adjoining areas of inner-city Birmingham. Eight years ago, the schools came together to offer adults in the community the chance to study in close proximity to their children. In effect, they are all women who, for one reason or another, have not been able to fulfil their potential in further or higher education. "It would be unusual in an area like this for men and women to attend the same courses," says Lane.

And it is the women who have been particularly disadvantaged by cultural pressures. It could be that they have been expected to leave the sixth-form before completing A-levels. That was the case with Jusna Begum, 25, who came to Birmingham from Bradford for an arranged marriage. She now has two children, aged five and 16 months, so she appreciates the crche facilities. "It was hard to get back into education at first," she says. "As it's gone on, though, I've found it easier. And my husband has been supportive."

Tahira Hussein, 21, has no husband or children. But she does have strict parents who wouldn't allow her to go away to university or even to travel across Birmingham to study (a restriction that doesn't apply to her younger brother). "I've already done a BTec in computers," she says, "and when the chance to take a degree came up I said to myself, 'right, I'm going to do this.' I'm very committed. I might go into teaching."

The opportunity exists for anyone who completes the three-year course for a BA in Early Childhood Studies to go on to study for a Post Graduate Certificate of Education. Ian Lane could be forgiven for hoping that as many as possible of the 23 women who are just starting their second term will do just that. After all, Anderton Park has a problem that is not immediately evident.

On the face of it, the school has been transformed during Lane's 10-year reign. It's difficult to believe that the building itself was condemned as "dirty and smelly" by government inspectors in 1984. Since then, money has been forthcoming from the European Union, central government and the local education authority in Birmingham. Anderton Park was recently granted a charter mark by an assessor who proclaimed himself impressed by the discipline of the children and the dedication of the staff. So what's the problem?

Language. All but two mixed-race children among the 650 pupils come from homes where English is second to Punjabi in day-to-day conversation. Yet only three of the 23 teachers are Punjabi speakers. Since he was given control over his own budget, Lane has recruited 13 teaching assistants from the local community. Nine of them work in key stage 1, where 73% are at level 2 or above in reading - around the national average. By key stage 2, results are not so good. Just 55% of those leaving last summer achieved level 4. "The big problem is that our kids don't experience English at a higher level because their parents don't speak it at home," says Lane. "Their knowledge of common nouns and verbs is stuck at the level of nine-year-olds." Hence the need for more qualified bilingual teachers. "Local people should be part of the solution, so we're welcoming the talent that's already here," says community education development officer Peter Simpson. "There's too much of the cavalry riding in from outside." He shows the way into a small library. Expenditure on degree-level books is due to rise from £400 to £1,000.

Internet access should also increase this term, from one terminal to 16. Back in the hut, the degree-course women are finishing their break and preparing for the next session. The majority are Muslim. Nearly all are in traditional dress and two peer out through the slits in black "hijab" head-dresses. "When I taught here, 21 years ago, you didn't see many mothers at all," says the course co-ordinator, Julie Boardman from South Birmingham College. "They were in purdah. It was always fathers who brought their children to school."

Twenty one years from now it seems likely that many more mothers will not only be bringing their children to school, but staying on. As teachers.

webTitle: Heads launch attack on school bullies

fields.headline: Heads launch attack on school bullies
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Headteachers yesterday launched a crackdown on school bullying, warning that failure to combat violence, sarcasm, ridicule, racial abuse and sexual harassment could provoke a rash of litigation.
fields.body:
Headteachers yesterday launched a crackdown on school bullying, warning that failure to combat violence, sarcasm, ridicule, racial abuse and sexual harassment could provoke a rash of litigation. David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: 'Bullying can irrevocably damage the mental health of individuals. Ultimately, it could put the chool at risk of a claim for damages.'

The association is to circulate guidelines saying that all complaints should be taken at face value. 'If the victim of bullying considers themselves bullied, then prima facie bullying has taken place and must be investigated.'

Bullying can be:
physical - pushing, kicking, hitting, pinching or any form of violence or threats;
verbal - name-calling, sarcasm, spreading rumours, persistent teasing;
emotional - tormenting, threatening ridicule, humiliation, exclusion from groups or activities;
racist - racial taunts, graffiti, gestures; and
sexual - unwanted physical contact, abusive contacts.

Heads should watch out for telltale signs of bullying, such as children who are frequently absent or withdrawn, who often appear to lose possessions, are easily distressed and submit damaged or incomplete work. Signs of teachers suffering from bullying include low morale, high staff turnover and absenteeism.

The association said all schools should have an anti-bullying policy. Action might include requiring the bully to apologise to the victim and training to encourage bullies to modify their behaviour.

'There have been a number of high profile cases which have seriously affected the reputations of the schools,' Mr Hart said. In October, North Yorkshire education authority paid £6,000 to the parents of 18-year-old John Carnell who claimed his school had failed to prevent six years of bullying. Last month, research suggested that almost one in four primary pupils are bullied.

webTitle: Ask the audience - the way to a better degree

fields.headline: Ask the audience - the way to a better degree
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: First it was the ratings, and now it is the grades. Just as the introduction of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? boosted ITV's viewing figures, so have the methods of Chris Tarrant's quiz show improved the pass marks of students at one of Scotland's leading universities.
fields.body:
First it was the ratings, and now it is the grades. Just as the introduction of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? boosted ITV's viewing figures, so have the methods of Chris Tarrant's quiz show improved the pass marks of students at one of Scotland's leading universities.

Following the installation of a pilot scheme which saw Strathclyde university students being asked to use infrared handsets to choose whether answer A, B, C or D best fitted a question posed by lecturers, students have been achieving better grades.

Academics at the Glasgow-based university stop periodically during lectures to pose questions to students about what they have been telling them.

A selection of answers is displayed on a large overhead screen - similar to the one on the television show - and students are asked to choose the correct one using a handset installed in their seats. The results are flashed up and, if they all choose the correct answer, the lecturer carries on; if the majority err, the lecturer goes over the topic again.

Since the pilot project was introduced last autumn, failure rates in the university's mechanical engineering department have plummeted. The university is now considering expanding the programme across campus.

'I suppose it's a bit like the format of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?,' says Jim Boyle, of the mechanical engineering department. 'We've found students basically get bored in lectures and this allows them to become more involved in what's going on and it gives us feedback. Grades have improved, failure rates have dropped.'

The system was developed in Hong Kong following American research which showed young people have a shorter attention span because of overexposure to television and computer games.

Strathclyde's programme, which takes in classes in mechanical engineering and modern languages, is an attempt to address changes in the way students learn. 'They might not think there's much difference - they probably still think the lectures are boring - but for the MTV generation this is probably one of the best ways of learning. All the lecturers involved say they've noticed a difference in their students,' says Professor Boyle.

The handsets are currently used in classes of 150, although they can be used in much bigger lecture theatres. At £3,000 to install they are considered relatively cheap and, Prof Boyle believes, they will soon become commonplace in universities across the country.

Not all lecturers, however, are convinced. Owen Dudley-Edwards, a reader in history at Edinburgh university, claims computers are no replacement for more traditional academic methods. 'Computers and lecturing aids are interesting toys, but they are no substitute for the human stimulus that comes from a good lecturer on top form,' he said.

webTitle: These works of Heseltine are grandiose; desperate; empty

fields.headline: These works of Heseltine are grandiose; desperate; empty
fields.standfirst:
On the night, the Dome show was undeniably big... but also tacky

The Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The millennium moment, thank God, wasn't meant to last. It was great while it happened, a unique thrill, enormous fun, sent a shiver through anyone awake to witness it. The problem now is how to get away. For most countries, this may be quite easy. For one, it has been made very difficult. This is the work of the politicians who wanted to take possession of millenniumising, not just on December 31 1999 but for the whole year ahead. The way they did this in Britain, hoping to make retreat impossible, demands one final scrutiny.
fields.body:
The millennium moment, thank God, wasn't meant to last. It was great while it happened, a unique thrill, enormous fun, sent a shiver through anyone awake to witness it. The problem now is how to get away. For most countries, this may be quite easy. For one, it has been made very difficult. This is the work of the politicians who wanted to take possession of millenniumising, not just on December 31 1999 but for the whole year ahead. The way they did this in Britain, hoping to make retreat impossible, demands one final scrutiny.

From millennialist leaders everywhere, certain words were predictable. There would be resolutions and hopes and promises, on an epic scale. That is not merely the habit of professionals but was the demand, at this moment, of peoples. We want a better world, made by politicians forced to renew their routine vows with special extravagance. We like the sight of them taking advantage of a new-era spirit by loosening the shackles of third world debt. They surely had a duty to look back on a catastrophe-strewn century and sincerely pledge that its evils must never be repeated. Perhaps a tiny practical residue of this verbiage will remain.

But then, the morning after, normal life resumes, as we're mature enough to know it would. The setting of familiar words to heavenly music has but passing impact. The dateline doesn't alter the rules of engagement in the real world. By far the most meaningful event that occurred at the moment the century ended was the resignation of Boris Yeltsin, a truly ominous world-changer. Otherwise, while we don't begrudge the aspirational talk, and might like it to be true, we're well aware how little it means.

In Britain, the promise is different. The prime minister wants the millennium to go on and on. 'The fantastic thing is that millennium celebrations in this country go on for a year and not just today,' he warbled on Saturday. At the centre of this permanence is the Dome, where he, and I and 10,000 others, spent the previous night. Having been there at the moment for which it was built, I still think it's an emblem not of British brilliance - `the greatest show on earth,'' Mr Blair ventured - but of a desperate, empty, national grandiosity from which, because its origins were locked in political bipartisanship, there's been no escape.

Why did they do it? It carries awe. The size of the place is pretty breath-taking. Derelict land is occupied by a structure anyone may wonder at. Some of the zones are ingenious and new. The show, on the night, was tacky, but it was undeniably big. The tube stations on the way are triumphs of design. Now that the whole thing is done, it's obligatory to emphasise the positive, which everyone with a stake in its creation, from Michael Grade to BSkyB, has been frantically trying to do. At £750m, there certainly should be something positive, amid the vast political pretension.

But pretension dominates. The politicians' every word reeks of it. The place is meant to be far, far more than fun. 'We set out to create the biggest statement of confidence in Britain,' Michael Heseltine intoned, 'and we have done that tonight. We have created something magnificent... a success that billions of people round the world would have seen.' Blair called it 'a triumph of confidence over cynicism, boldness over blandness, excellence over mediocrity', questioning the patriotism of anyone who said otherwise. I don't know whether I find the absurdity or the menace of such common language the more repellent.

Yet sentiments like this were inevitable, as soon as politicians had agreed to make the monster Dome a public project. What first mattered to them, once they were committed to the huge exercise in architectural solipsism, was its completion.

Everything else was cast aside, beginning with even elementary care over arrangements to get there on the night. The politicians' panic concerned the possibility that the thing might not be finished, no matter who could or couldn't see it in time, after a night trapped for hours in railway queues. To Mr Heseltine, 'a few people being late' was a matter of insulting triviality.

As the passion that counted, completion also surpassed any serious concern for what, exactly, was being completed. From the start unable to describe the message of the Dome, except as a piece of national boosterism, the public men who insisted on it being built were no closer to its deeper meaning by the end - as anyone who goes there will quickly find. The unifying theme is sponsor-domination. There are some arresting exhibits, but these seem, in the scale of things, utterly beside both the political and financial point.

The scale required something which, within an idiom of pure display, untouched by artistic or any other coherence, was unattainable under the rules laid down by McDonald's and British Airways.

What seems important now is to try and forget about the Dome, and behave, as a public nation, as though the millennium itself is already evolving into just another year. This will be hard to do, because of the excesses of grandiloquence the politicians have indulged in. But amnesia is, actually, the way to rescue New Labour from its own folly: the impulse that compelled it, first, to semi-pledge, when Heseltine demanded it, continuity for the project, and then, after the 1997 landslide, to recoil from cancelling what many members of the cabinet knew to be pointless waste of immense resources - and thus sustain a project better fitted to the bellowing emptiness of a government on the verge of collapse than one freshly mandated to get to grips with reality.

For that is the irony of the Dome. Far from glorifying New Labour, it distracts from what the government is doing. Forced to up his rhetoric to heights of overheated vacuity, Mr Blair does his real project less than justice. This project is more solid than the Dome will ever be. Ersatz millennial permanence is precisely what new Britain did not need: Heseltine's poisoned pill, swallowed by successors who would do better to forget than celebrate their old naivety.

fields.headline: Sniper dies in embassy shootout
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian angered by Chechen war kills one and wounds six in attack on Russian building in Beirut

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: A Palestinian angered by Russia's military offensive in Chechnya fired rocket-propelled grenades at the Russian embassy in Beirut yesterday, killing a policeman and wounding six others before being shot dead by security forces.
fields.body:
A Palestinian angered by Russia's military offensive in Chechnya fired rocket-propelled grenades at the Russian embassy in Beirut yesterday, killing a policeman and wounding six others before being shot dead by security forces.

Army and police forces stormed a building in Beirut's Mazraa district from where the gunman had fired at the embassy. A woman hostage was later released unharmed.

One policeman was killed and two wounded in a shootout with the gunman. At least two passers-by were hurt trying to flee the area.

State television identified the gunman as a Palestinian named Ahmed Abou Kharoub and said a note was found in his pocket which read: 'I martyred myself for Grozny [the Chechen capital].'

'He [the gunman] said that he wanted to die a martyr and that it pained him not to have killed a Russian before he was shot,' the released hostage, a woman named Ina'am, said before being taken to a nearby police station.

Police later said Abou Kharoub was aged 30 and lived in the Palestinian refugee camp of Ain el Hilweh, near the southern port of Sidon. He was the father of four children and owned an electronics and computer hardware shop.

Relatives described him as a zealot with an extremist view of Islam and a lot of sympathy for the Chechen rebels.

'He would always say we must take revenge for the people in Grozny,' said a family member who refused to be identified.

Officers said they believed Abou Kharoub had acted alone but soldiers were combing the area for possible accomplices.

Security sources said the army found rocket-propelled grenade launchers and Kalashnikov rifles in the stormed building and were patrolling the area with armoured vehicles.

A Russian diplomat at the embassy, Andrei Avdeev, said there were no Russian casualties in the assault and that only the consular section was damaged.

The Mazraa area is in the Muslim sector of Beirut, where extremists have been sympa thetic with fellow Muslims in Chechnya who are fighting an onslaught by Russian forces.

Russian troops launched a military offensive in September to wrest control of the rebel republic of Chechnya after Chechen-based militants invaded a neighbouring region and were blamed for a string of apartment bombings in Russia.

fields.headline: Bug scare for Mafia killers
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Bug: special report
fields.trailText: An Italian court clerk switched on her computer yesterday and discovered that convicted mafia killers were the victims of the most shocking miscarriage of justice. Prisoners due for release next week should have been freed on January 10, 1900.
fields.body:
An Italian court clerk switched on her computer yesterday and discovered that convicted mafia killers were the victims of the most shocking miscarriage of justice.

Prisoners due for release next week should have been freed on January 10, 1900. Others awaiting trial would have to languish for a century before their day in court. Even for Italy's tardy judicial system, this was a record.

The panic lasted for as long as it took for a lawyer to shout 'millennium bug'. But administrative offices were closed for two hours while officials compared handwritten records with the computer files.

Ironically, the gaffe arrived on the debut of the judiciary's big reform: a new law aimed at purging the system's sloth.

So slow are the courts that most of the Italian politicians who were convicted of corruption remained free on appeal until their sentences lapsed.

The judicial computer hiccups - officially blamed on new software, rather than the millennium bug - deflated Italian pride at having confounded experts who branded Italy a Y2K basket case.

In another blow, Rome's preparations for the Vatican's holy year, which could attract more than 20m pilgrims, were assailed as inadequate. Traffic jams condemned thousands to spending millennium eve in their cars as roadworks churned up the city's streets.

fields.headline: Scots threaten revolt on refugees
fields.trailText: The Scottish government appears to be heading for its first big clash with Westminster over the treatment of asylum seekers under a new Whitehall dispersal programme.
fields.body:
The Scottish government appears to be heading for its first big clash with Westminster over the treatment of asylum seekers under a new Whitehall dispersal programme.

Ministers in the Edinburgh parliament are facing growing demands from influential back- benchers and Scottish church leaders to treat refugees more generously than does the home office.

Amid claims that the new immigration and asylum act contravened the United Nations convention on refugees, pressure is mounting for the Scottish executive to take control over new rules that could lead to 6,000 refugees arriving in Scotland this year.

Members of a parliamentary cross-party group on refugees believe that the executive should have the right to alter a controversial home office rule that will mean refugees receiving vouchers, rather than cash, to buy food.

In a motion submitted to the parliament, they are also calling for the Scottish executive, rather than the home office, to determine where the refugees should be housed.

Members of the group say that legal advice suggests they would have a right to influence part of the new act because of the implications for housing and social services, functions that are already devolved to Edinburgh.

Leaders of Scotland's main churches have added weight to the demands in a statement which describes the home office plans as a "disgrace to Scotland's sense of fairness".

The Rt Rev John Cairns, moderator of the church of Scotland's general assembly, and the Rt Rev John Mone, the Roman Catholic bishop of Paisley, are among the religious leaders claiming that the act contravened the UN human rights convention because it failed to treat asylum seekers with dignity and also wasted money through the voucher scheme.

Their statement, in partnership with Amnesty International and the Scottish Refugee Council, said that for the first time Scottish councils would only be able to offer support for refugees who had vouchers. At the moment, asylum seekers received cash help. They were urging the parliament to look closely at the legislation `and take steps to remedy the situation'.

Dennis Cannavan, the independent socialist MSP for Falkirk West, and a patron of the Scottish Refugee Council, predicted yesterday that the new parliament could be heading for its first big constitutional clash with Westminster over the issue. He claimed that the home secretary, Jack Straw, was trying to undermine devolution by interfering with housing and social services north of the border.

"We should be telling him 'hands off', these are devolved matters," Mr Cannavan said. "While Scotland should adopt a more generous attitude, there is also an important constitutional principle at stake here, quite apart from the need for a fair deal for the asylum seekers themselves."

Critics of the home office say a new support system, offering councils £150 a week for single people and £220 for a family, is inadequate and will not properly cover clothing, education and social care costs. Refugees will get food vouchers worth £35 each week, and £10 in cash.

Shona Robison, a Scottish National party MSP for north-east Scotland and a member of the cross-party refugee group, said lawyers suggested there was a case for a legal debate on the merits of not implementing the voucher scheme north of the border.

fields.headline: Shortchanged on debt
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has attracted much praise for his campaign to convince G7 governments to cancel $100bn of the debts owed them by some poor countries (Britain ends third world debt, December 20). But does he deserve this praise?
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has attracted much praise for his campaign to convince G7 governments to cancel $100bn of the debts owed them by some poor countries (Britain ends third world debt, December 20). But does he deserve this praise?

These debts were not being serviced anyway. Even if the other G7 nations follow suit, third world debt, which now stands at $2,500bn, will continue to grow. But there is a deeper reason to refrain from this congratulatory chorus. Since the beginning of the debt crisis in 1982, the IMF has averted sovereign default by using public money to underwrite western private-sector investments in high-risk, high-earning 'emerging markets'. Most of the bail-out money just crossed the street.

In a radical reversal of policy, the G7 governments are now, through the IMF, pressurising a number of severely debt-distressed nations to default on debts to private investors. Ecuador, which defaulted last November in face of a debt whose interest payments consume 41% of export earnings, was the first victim. Private investors are now punishing Ecuador, attempting to seize its foreign assets and locking it out of international capital markets. The consequences for all severely indebted countries are dire: higher interest rates for many (as investors price in the new risk), and a credit crunch for those in the worst position.
John Smith
Sheffield johncsmith@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Rank list
fields.trailText: The honours list (Letters, January 1) belongs to a time when monarchy was the apex of a coherent social pyramid. Those with an automatic right to be respected by everyone else selected a few ordinary people to be hoisted up to a rank usually somewhat below their own.
fields.body:
The honours list (Letters, January 1) belongs to a time when monarchy was the apex of a coherent social pyramid. Those with an automatic right to be respected by everyone else selected a few ordinary people to be hoisted up to a rank usually somewhat below their own.

Tam Dalyell should know better than to entertain this chimerical celebration of good works through elevation. He could point out to worthy but overlooked Labour activists that any feelings of exclusion are nothing more than the embarrassing symptoms of self-flattery. MPs are themselves implicated in its anti-democratic consequences. Labour backbenchers should be trying to invert the symbolic hierarchy of the Palace of Westminster.
Tom Snow
London

fields.headline: Boys in blue were great
fields.trailText: You say (Falconer apology for Dome fiasco, January 3) that people are blaming the Metropolitan police for delays encountered by Dome guests at Stratford on New Year's Eve. There is certainly no basis for this view.
fields.body:
You say (Falconer apology for Dome fiasco, January 3) that people are blaming the Metropolitan police for delays encountered by Dome guests at Stratford on New Year's Eve. There is certainly no basis for this view.

The professionalism and good humour shown by the police - and the other emergency services - in dealing with millions of partygoers in London was hugely impressive. They helped to ensure that the celebrations passed off successfully, peacefully and safely. We could not have asked for more.

The opening night at the Dome and the millennium celebrations all over the UK will be remembered for the extraordinary success that they were.
Charles Falconer
Minister of state, cabinet office

 Having not been invited to the Dome, I climbed a ladder and looked in through the window. I saw that they were all standing on their hind legs.
Chris Bocci
Bath

webTitle: Well, we had a good time

fields.headline: Well, we had a good time
fields.trailText: In response to Mr Hawksley et al (Letters, January 3), all I can say is that I didn't see any of the nightmare scenarios described. The only point where I encountered police crowd control was at Holborn tube station, where they did a great job of herding people in a trainload at a time, so everybody got on to the trains safely.
fields.body:
In response to Mr Hawksley et al (Letters, January 3), all I can say is that I didn't see any of the nightmare scenarios described. The only point where I encountered police crowd control was at Holborn tube station, where they did a great job of herding people in a trainload at a time, so everybody got on to the trains safely. The crowds elsewhere were unfailingly good-natured and really didn't need controlling. And the fireworks were stunning something that shouldn't be forgotten amid all the hubbub about the river of fire. The tubes were running, frequently.

I saw few intimidating drunks, and no children in tears. I didn't even see anyone peeing. My little group had planned ahead by not drinking vast amounts of tea and beer before going into town, anticipating the lack of facilities, and it seemed reasonable that others would have thought of this too.

The main thrust of the complaints appears to be 'I went to London to see in the year 2000, and it was crowded'. I'm sorry, but what did you expect? National disgrace? Give me a break.
Mike Knell
Leamington Spa, Warks

 I crawled out of bed after 2pm next day after spending an amazing New Year's Eve in central London. We ended up watching the fireworks display from a vantage point just outside the National Gallery, north of Trafalgar Square which sported two massive screens broadcasting TV shows, and had an excellent view of Big Ben. What a night! But one I will never forget. We saw five sets of fireworks going off from our viewpoint at Trafalgar Square. And the Hank Dogs 45-minute concert at a stage outside the Royal Festival Hall was sublime. Absolutely magnificent.
Kristiina Giscombe-Smith
London
lilactime53@netscapeonline.co.uk

 The public party by the river was bound to be a question of pot luck and we were some of the many who had a positive experience. We left Harrow on the Hill at 9.30pm after seeing the local scouts light their beacon on Harrow Weald Ride. We found a spot to the side of Southwark bridge where we waited in a friendly crowd occasionally jostled as newcomers surged towards the bridge. No, we did not see the river of fire nor, indeed, the water, but we had a splendid view of the fireworks raining down overhead. After the fireworks, to the amusement of the departing crowd, two young men, who had earlier scaled a building nearby, danced briefly in the nude on the majestic baroque portico. By 2am we were home and watching the review of our party on the river on the box.
Anne Swinson
Hatch End, Middx

 I hate to agree with the home secretary, but New Year's Eve was well organised and thanks should warmly go to Westminster city council's workers, who cleaned up after us all, to public transport workers and those behind the scenes. There was a great deal of goodwill and confidence about the future, with people chatting, singing and laughing and looking forward to 2000, too.
Andrew Edwards
Tidworth, Wiltshire

 I spent new year in the comfort of my own home surrounded by family and friends tucked away in Southport. We had our own spectacular firework display in the garden, followed by the display for the whole town. The champagne flowed, we played games till 6am and my sister-in-law stayed up to film the dawn at 8.10 in my back garden. London, Paris, New York? Next millennium, I'll do exactly the same.
Cath Baldry
Southport, Merseyside

 If the public had known that pissing on the ministry of defence was one of the attractions on offer (Letters, January 3), I'm sure there would have been even larger crowds in central London.
Chris Willis
London

webTitle: No place for religion in the real world

fields.headline: No place for religion in the real world
fields.trailText: Hugo Young observes that while churches are emptying in this country, materialism does not seem to be enough to fill the void that lack of religion leaves (Comment, January 1).
fields.body:
Hugo Young observes that while churches are emptying in this country, materialism does not seem to be enough to fill the void that lack of religion leaves (Comment, January 1).

I started life as an involuntary Catholic and progressed through a long state of active and then dormant eastern mysticism to a final realisation that any kind of religion is irrelevant to my existence and unnecessary for my happiness and well-being. I did not come to this position through sliding into a 'shallow norm' as he puts it, but by reasoning, intellectual thought and the observation of realities in the world around me.

In the end, as a snake sloughs off its skin, I sloughed off any need for religion, or the fear of loss or retribution that religion haunts believers with if they stray from the 'true' path. It seems to me that humanity is moving along an intellectual evolutionary path, with religion no longer adequate as an attempt to answer those questions about existence that have been with us for so long. There is nothing to be mourned in the loss of religion. That is not to say we should regard the greatest minds of many centuries who expressed themselves through religion as 'pathetically misunderstood'. They were simply working within the paradigms of their days and their legacy to humankind can never be in doubt. I would suggest that a suitable replacement for religion in our lives would simply be reality.

The realities being revealed to us by ecology, cosmology, biology, physics and other forms of human inquiry reveal far more wonders and insights than religion, ultimately obscurantist and dogmatic, ever could.
Marc Loewenthal
London
rainer@marcloe.freeserve.co.uk

 Hugo Young fails to mention the continuing status of the Bible as one of the world's bestsellers. William Tyndale's 1534 New Testament was the first scriptural text that was accessible to the English-reading public. We don't need a new religion, as Mr Young suggests. Humanity's yearning for spirituality can be satisfied through discovery of the radical, dynamic Christianity so eloquently expressed by Tyndale.
Alistair Budd
Elsah, Illionois, USA
akb@prin.edu

fields.headline: First sight of the bug
fields.trailText: Oh dear, it's started already: avaricious IT professionals extracted billions from gullible industry and worried public over non-existent millennium bug problem (Letters, January 3).
fields.body:
Oh dear, it's started already: avaricious IT professionals extracted billions from gullible industry and worried public over non-existent millennium bug problem (Letters, January 3).

It's a sad irony that after millions of man hours poring through computer programs line by line to correct any invalid date processing, the best result programmers could hope for was that absolutely nothing happened as the clocks rolled over to the new millennium.
Nick Holmes
Warwick
Nick_Holmes@uk.ibm.com

Whitney, Oxon
maog51@dial.pipex.com

fields.headline: We agree on the Holocaust
fields.trailText: Michael Rosen (Letters, December 31) and I are both on message concerning the centrality of genocide to the last century and its ever-present threat in the next. That's why I support the idea of a day to commemorate the victims of the Holocaust and inform about the horrors of genocide.
fields.body:
Michael Rosen (Letters, December 31) and I are both on message concerning the centrality of genocide to the last century and its ever-present threat in the next. That's why I support the idea of a day to commemorate the victims of the Holocaust and inform about the horrors of genocide.

It's also why I want redress for the victims of past war crimes and to see a permanent international court to try any future perpetrators. My effort to say too much in too few words must have created the wrong impression in Michael's mind.

The world largely failed the Jews during the Nazi era and neglected their demand for justice for years after. It is a fact that Jewish organisations fought to reverse this neglect, not all of them always with the purest of motives. Were it not for Jewish powerlessness in the mid-20th century and the refusal to accept the specific case which Jews have had for redress since then, this need would never have arisen.
David Cesarani
University of Southampton

fields.headline: A handicapped army
fields.standfirst: Blair, the over-ambitious peacemaker
fields.trailText: Leaks rarely occur by accident. The one which emerged on BBC radio yesterday, revealing the dissatisfaction and, in some senses, near-despair of two senior officers with the difficulties they had to contend with in Kosovo, looks less accidental than most.
fields.body:
Leaks rarely occur by accident. The one which emerged on BBC radio yesterday, revealing the dissatisfaction and, in some senses, near-despair of two senior officers with the difficulties they had to contend with in Kosovo, looks less accidental than most. But the overall message is clear and directed at politicians: you give us these dirty and difficult jobs to do, but you stint the resources needed to do them properly.

The list of complaints is formidable. Such a shortage of guns that they had to borrow from others. Radios which could not be used either because they were broken or because the Serbs listened in. A shortage of night vision equipment. Troops forced to buy camp beds and other apparent necessities because they were not supplied. Lines of command confused, fractured or over-stretched. Legal constraints and confusions making it near impossible to do the policing job the world supposed they were sent there to do. And most chilling of all, the conclusion that had the circumstances when they went in been less 'benign' - had President Milosevic not wound down, leaving no real resistance to their advance - the enterprise might have ended in failure. All that underlines the unwisdom, of which we complained at the time, of launching the bombing without any firm plans for ground action.

These complaints are addressed to Labour, since it was a Labour government which sent the 1st Battalion of the Parachute Regiment into Kosovo with lavish assurances that they had the total full-hearted support of everyone back at home. But they also apply to Conservative ministers under whom the steady reduction of defence spending began - in the belief, which has proved to be sadly misplaced, that the end of the cold war presaged a period of general peace.

There are only two ways out of this box. You either tailor commitments to what you spend, or you tailor spending to meet your commitments. Even those in total sympathy with his aspirations were troubled by Tony Blair's declaration that the allied intervention in Kosovo was the opening move in a whole new era when the international community would ride to the aid of the stricken and oppressed. Was there any sign of preparedness for that? How long would it take to achieve the necessary integration of command? And who, above all, would pay for it? The leak brings these questions urgently, back to the boil.

fields.headline: A new parental trap
fields.standfirst: Jack Straw should show compassion
fields.trailText: Three weeks ago a spokesman for the lord chancellor thought the British gay couple, who made legal history in the US when both men were registered as the parents of surrogate twin babies, would have no problem in having their legal breakthrough recognised in the UK. But that was before British immigration officials got to work.
fields.body:
Three weeks ago a spokesman for the lord chancellor thought the British gay couple, who made legal history in the US when both men were registered as the parents of surrogate twin babies, would have no problem in having their legal breakthrough recognised in the UK. But that was before British immigration officials got to work. The abominable 'no' men remained true to their tradition: never be flexible, follow the rules so long as the rules exclude, forget about humanity, care or compassion.

Even though the prospective birth of the twins was reported months ago, the home office wants more time. All it has granted the three-week-old twins is one month temporary admission. The exclusion department is clearly fearful of setting a precedent. In the words of a home office source: 'There are several ways in which they could be granted citizenship, but all of them are problematical.'

US law - even when made by the US supreme court - is not binding on the UK. Under British law, the babies' legal parents are the surrogate mother and her husband in the US, even though sperm from one of the British men was used to conceive the children.

Compared to the plight of countless immigrants turned away at the gate, the babies' future looks far from grim. Their two male parents are rich and have already engaged a leading law firm. They have the energy and resources to fight officialdom, as their legal suit in the US demonstrated. But there is another reason why they deserve to succeed: the need for more tolerance towards gay couples. Surrogacy is a legal and emotional minefield, but as up to 100 official surrogate babies are born to heterosexual couples in the UK every year, there is a valid case for extending the procedure to loving, stable gay couples. Options include: exemption, adoption, a dependency ruling. The key ingredient should be compassion and the twins' right to a clear sense of security.

fields.headline: Leaked reports fuel army row
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The government faced calls yesterday to set up an urgent inquiry after leaked army documents claimed that British troops were issued with 'unreliable' guns during Nato's successful operation to expel Serb forces from Kosovo.
fields.body:
The government faced calls yesterday to set up an urgent inquiry after leaked army documents claimed that British troops were issued with 'unreliable' guns during Nato's successful operation to expel Serb forces from Kosovo.

The Tories accused the government of trying to get 'defence on the cheap' after the devastating findings in the report which said that British soldiers were so badly equipped that they forced to buy their own camp beds.

The row broke out after classified army reports on the British contribution to last year's Kosovo operation, prepared by two senior army officers for the Ministry of Defence's comprehensive 'lessons learnt' exercise, were passed to the BBC. In a damning indictment of the army's lack of preparedness, the reports said that British soldiers were severely hampered by equipment and communications failures. These included:
 New 'light support weapons' which were writ ten off as 'unreliable and insufficiently robust';
 A shortage of night vision of equipment;
 Inadequate personal radios, with up to a third broken at any one time. Radio operators were forced to use codewords and 'nick numbers' to disguise sensitive security details from the Serbs;
 Ill-defined command lines which were 'confused and fractured'.

The reports were written Lieutenant Colonel Paul Gibson, commanding officer of the Parachute Regiment's 1st Battalion - the first British troops to enter Kosovo on 12 June - and by his commanding officer, Brigadier Adrian Freer, Commander of 5 Airborne Brigade.

Brig Freer concluded that if the Serbs had put up a fight on the day that Nato forces swept into Kosovo, British troops could have faced serious difficulties.

'It is the view of this headquarters that had the situation on 12 June been anything less than benign, there would have been command, control and communication difficulties which could not have been resolved by K-For headquarters,' the Brigadier warned.

The Tories immediately seized on the reports to call for an enquiry. Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, complained that the government was trying to 'get defence on the cheap'.

The Liberal Democrats, who were supportive of the Kosovo operation, also raised questions. Menzies Campbell, the party's defence spokesman, said: 'If these criticisms are well-founded they show a front line reality far-removed from the triumphalist daily press conferences of the MOD during the Kosovo operations.'

The Ministry of Defence, which pointed out that the Nato operation to expel Slobodan Milosevic's forces from Kosovo was a resounding success, said that the reports were meant to be critical.

'We always, after a campaign such as Kosovo, review the events as soon as possible and as critically as possible,' an MOD spokesman said.

Ministers are believed to be relaxed about the leaks which are likely to strengthen the hand of the defence secretary Geoff Hoon in his forthcoming negotiations with the Treasury over the MOD's next three year budget.

The new pressure on the treasury was highlighted by Bruce George, the Labour chairman of the commons defence select committee. 'If the government wishes to achieve its objectives then defence spending will have to rise beyond the rather miserable level to which it has sunk over the last 15 years,' he said.

The documents are believed to have been leaked by senior army officers, probably from Brig Freer's 5 Airborne Brigade, to draw attention to the inadequate equipment they have to cope with.

Both Lt Col Gibson and Brigadier Freer, who have been decorated for their service in Kosovo, will be directly affected by government plans to wind up the 5 airborne brigade and incorporate it into a new assault brigade as part of the government's strategic defence review.

Their reports also complained that paratroopers were so badly equipped that at one point they had to buy their own satellite receivers because there were not enough to go round.

There were also problems in the chain of command, with 'too great a gap' between commanders on the ground and the international K-For headquarters. This was seen as criticism of General Sir Mike Jackson, the British commander of K-for. Lt Col Gibson also complained that 'MOD spin doctoring' was an irritant. He said that the MOD was over sensitive about critical articles.

fields.headline: Cheerio, boyo
fields.standfirst: Victory in the valleys: a cultural revolution has put more women in positions of power. Helen Wilkinson gives three cheers for the feminisation of Welsh politics
fields.trailText: Victory in the valleys: a cultural revolution has put more women in positions of power. Helen Wilkinson gives three cheers for the feminisation of Welsh politics
fields.body:
Welsh Labour politics is typically defined by its macho culture: working men's clubs, rugby union, male voice choirs. But at the end of the 20th century, that culture collided with Welsh feminism and, in round one at least, Welsh feminism won through.

The turning point came last January when Anita Gayle, a feisty 59-year-old who was then General Secretary of the Welsh Labour Party, turned up at Cynon Valley's selection meeting to enforce the controversial twinning process for selecting Assembly candidates which the local party was refusing to implement. A voice from the back yelled: 'You're nothing but a feminist and a trollop' but Gayle was undeterred. She told the members in no uncertain terms that those not prepared to abide by the party's rules should leave.

The majority stayed and from that moment the twinning campaign - whereby two constituency parties jointly selected two candidates from a shortlist, one man and one woman, then allocated one to fight each seat - was won. Months later, the public delivered their verdict and a new, more feminised Wales was born, with an Assembly whose 40% female membership put it way ahead of the national trend. The Labour group in the Welsh Assembly enters the new millennium boasting more women than men and a cabinet that is, excluding leader Alun Michael, entirely equal. Moreover, Edwina Hart's position as economic secretary signals women's entry into jobs traditionally perceived as men's.

But it has not all been plain sailing. Many women who went for Assembly seats encountered hostility. Val Feld, former director of the Welsh EOC and now Assembly member for Swansea East, was one of a number of women who received poison pen letters during the selection process. Having spent her life defending other women against discrimination, she admits: 'I was shaken by the letters and by how undermined I felt.'

Resistance to women's involvement in politics remains high in certain areas and the fear is that this resentment may be coming home to roost in the run-up to the parliamentary selections, set to begin in a few weeks' time. There are mutterings that decisions about vacant safe seats are being stitched up in the all-male bars and clubs that litter the Welsh valleys. As Huw Lewis, Assembly member for Merthyr Tydfil, puts it: 'There are a lot of bitter and bruised men out there. Many simply cannot accept that a woman beat them and they won't forget that in a hurry.'

Backlash may be part of the story, but it is not the whole story. As Julie Morgan, MP for Cardiff North, puts it: 'Twinning changed the face of Welsh politics. The public have got used to seeing women in powerful positions and more and more women now realise that politics is for them.' Men, too, are part of this cultural revolution. Huw Lewis, Assistant General Secretary when the twinning campaign was launched, had reservations - until he saw ugly prejudices laid bare. 'It made me realise that without positive action, many of these women simply would not be where they are now.'

Success in the Assembly is giving Welsh feminists the confidence to focus on Westminster. Here the record is appalling. Of 40 Welsh MPs, just four are women (all Labour). This is well below the national average of 18% and four times lower than in the Welsh Assembly. The forthcoming selections for safe Labour seats offer an opportunity to double women's representation in Wales. Six seats are available: select a woman, goes the logic, and you are almost certain to deliver another woman to Parliament. Welsh Labour women's bid to beat the old boys' network is spearheaded by Julie Morgan MP, in tandem with the Labour Women's Network. They have already held one training day in Cardiff and two more are planned. Local women are putting themselves forward, often for up to three seats, even if they do not believe they have a chance of winning. Jessica Morden, 31 and new General Secretary for Wales, says more are standing than ever before and optimists speculate that traditional Labour strongholds like Caerphilly could surprise everyone, while Wrexham is hot favourite to select a woman.

Nevertheless, it would be unwise to overstate the extent of the cultural shift. Rapid feminisation coexists with deep-seated traditional attitudes. 'It's an awful thing to admit,' Anita Gayle says, 'but party members will accept women only with a degree of compulsion.' As Val Feld points out: 'You don't change patterns of behaviour and values overnight. There are positive signals in Wales, but it is still early days.' She favours renewed commitment to positive action at national level, but while constituency parties still have an obligation to produce 50:50 shortlists, experience suggests equality of opportunity does not result in equality of outcome. Three of the four Welsh women MPs currently in Westminster were selected through all-women shortlists and they are in marginal seats.

'The current system is flawed,' Julie Morgan says. 'There is a danger we will not capitalise on the gains of the Welsh Assembly and could end up with fewer female politicians in Wales after the next general election.'

The selections come at an important moment in Welsh political history and Wrexham, which kicks off the process, will be an important test of the party's feminisation. 'If women don't score well there,' Morgan argues, 'we still have time to organise ourselves and to raise our profile.' This is not victim feminism and why should it be? In spite of the trouble and strife, 1999 was a good year for Welsh feminism and democracy, and equality campaigners are determined to consolidate on their victory. At her retirement party last year, Anita Gayle was handed a T-shirt with 'I'm a feminist' on the front, 'And a trollop' on the back. The joke went down well, but then Gayle and many other Welsh women could afford to laugh. Last year, they won through in ways unprecedented in Britain. Whether they will still be smiling after the next parliamentary selections remains to be seen.

webTitle: Overstretched army struggles to fill new role

fields.headline: Overstretched army struggles to fill new role
fields.standfirst:
The military hope leaks will force an increase in funding to match ministers' ambitions for Britain to be Europe's peacekeeper-in-chief

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The picture painted by two of the British army's most senior commanders in Kosovo, of guns and radios which did not work properly, of confused lines of command and control, of intelligence not reaching those who needed it on the ground, of inadequate briefing about the law covering war criminals, was predictably seized on yesterday by opposition spokesmen to castigate the government.
fields.body:
The picture painted by two of the British army's most senior commanders in Kosovo, of guns and radios which did not work properly, of confused lines of command and control, of intelligence not reaching those who needed it on the ground, of inadequate briefing about the law covering war criminals, was predictably seized on yesterday by opposition spokesmen to castigate the government.

Yet they raise fundamental questions about the post-cold war role of Britain's armed forces which neither the previous Conservative government nor its Labour successor has been prepared to face . Tony Blair's rhetoric and his administration's foreign policy ambitions - with British forces playing the lead in Europe and in UN peacekeeping missions while maintaining the nuclear 'deterrent' - have not been matched by extra funding.

For months Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, and his predecessor, Lord Robertson, have been warning of overstretch. This spring, Britain's contribution to the K-For peacekeeping force will be cut to below 4,000 from its peak of 10,500.

For years, senior officers and ministry of defence civil servants have been complaining privately about the 3% annual 'efficiency savings' imposed on them by the treasury.

There will be many in the MoD today who will be only too pleased about the leaked reports of Lt Col Paul Gibson, commander of the 1st battalion of the parachute regiment, and brigadier Adrian Freer, commander of 5 airborne brigade.

Whatever the precise motives of the leakers, the MoD may hope the reports of inadequate equipment - many of which, including those relating to radios and guns, have been known for a long time - will put pressure on the politicians in general and the treasury in particular. The defence budget, is now about £21bn, compared with some £25bn six years ago.

There is little new in commanders complaining about their equipment. The army had to cannibalise Challenger tanks for spares during the 1991 Gulf war when it could only just deploy a single armoured division. Then infantry complained that their then brand new and expensive Heckler and Koch SA 80 rifles were prone to jamming.

According to figures released recently by the MoD, a third of the army's newest tanks and more than half its older models are not fully operational. The figures, obtained by Menzies Campbell, Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, suggest the army is having problems with its frontline armour, with implications that could be serious for its ability to take part in future military operations.

Only 65% of new Challenger 2 tanks were fully operational at the end of September. Last year all were fully operational. Only 39% of the army's older Challenger 1 tanks are fully operational, compared with 67% last year.

The figures are well below army targets. The MoD has declined to disclose the number of tanks unfit for military service. John Spellar, armed forces minister, told Mr Campbell the number of armoured vehicles held by frontline units and the number operational were classified.

The army has ordered 386 Challenger 2s, but probably fewer than 100 are in service. It has had 420 Challenger 1s; they are progressively going out of service. The figures show few of the ageing fleet of smaller armoured personnel carriers and combat vehicles meet readiness targets.

The MoD wants more than 250 Eurofighters for the RAF which may or may not be adapted to land and take-off from the navy's planned two new aircraft carriers. The navy's fleet of ageing surface ships badly need replacing and its budget shortfall has meant cancelling exercises. The ministry is also due to order a heavy lift transport aircraft, a decision on which has already been postponed.

These projects, costing tens of billions of pounds, will all be needed, says the ministry, to fulfil the government's ambitious plans for rapid reaction forces in an upheaval laid down in the 1998 strategic defence review. The 1999 defence white paper, published before Christmas, gave little hint of the troubles, or of the difficult and hugely expensive decisions ahead.

The army remains short of skilled technicians as well as modern and reliable equipment. It remains 5,000 short of its official trained strength of 109,000, while the navy is some 1,500 short of its notional strength of 40,000. An MoD 'performance report' released at the same time as the defence white paper showed that the army's training and recruitment agency reported only a 17% success rate in reaching its assigned targets.

Moves towards more effective European capabilities were driven by warnings from the US that it will not be prepared in a future European crisis to provide the 80% of the hardware and intelligence it did in the Kosovo war.

The main points of the reports include:

Weaponry

Troops had to borrow general purpose, long-range machine guns because many of theirs did not work properly, Lt Col Gibson says. The 'reliability, robustness and 'suppressive capability'' of the light support weapon used in Kosovo were 'insufficient'.

Soldiers were hindered at night by a lack of night vision devices for machine guns. 'There is currently not an in-service cupola weapon station bracket for the machine gun, which reduces the effectiveness of a considerable proportion of the brigade's firepower at night,' he added.

Communications

Battle communications were a hindrance to operations, particularly in Pristina. Radios were so insecure that the Serbs could hear everything that was said and codes had to be used to disguise sensitive security details.

One type of radio proved 'unworkable in towns' - but urgent requests for a secure replacement system went unanswered.

Meanwhile, the Clansman radio equipment, the personal radio used by the troops, proved old and 'increasingly unreliable', with up to 35% being repaired at any one time.

Legal powers

British soldiers were not told of their legal powers before arriving in Pristina, said Lt Col Gibson, and, when they got there 'appropriate advice was slow to arrive Advice often dodged the issue, referring the matter back to the judgment of the soldier on the ground.'

The report continued: There seemed to be a great fear both of adverse publicity and the possibility of future litigation.'

Lack of clarity about troops' powers meant suspected war criminals 'were often only held for a few hours before being released' while 'the Albanian community, in particular, meted out violence on Serbs, sure in the knowledge that the battle group was impotent to do anything to stop them'.

Command

'The gap between corps and brigade level was too great', said Brig Freer, with the intent of K-For commander 'not always transmitted with sufficient detail and coordinating instructions'. Even when detail from K-For was requested, 'it was not always forthcoming' - leading to 'improvisation at brigade level.

'The potentially damaging effects of confused and fractured command may have a damaging effect on morale as the practical expression is constantly changing orders and confusion. This may place individual soldiers in an invidious position.'

Equipment

Troops 'generally slept on the floors of buildings and were rarely able to shower' due to the lack of mobile shower units in Pristina, said Lt Col Gibson. Many bought their own solar shower bags and camp beds 'to improve their living conditions'.

Members of his battalion also bought their own lightweight global positioning satellite receivers to identify their positions at night, in bad weather or on difficult terrain.

Lt Col Gibson also suggests spin-doctoring of the Kosovo campaign by the MoD was an inappropriate use of resources. 'On the few occasions when adverse articles might have been written, there seemed to be... disproportionate command and staff effort expended over the potential implications of such articles. The reports said tactical intelligence was 'disappointing', adding: 'Considerable intelligence products were available to Nato but these were not disseminated to battle group level.'

Families found out about the initial deployment from the BBC 24 to 36 hours before soldiers had the decision confirmed by their chain of command.

Maximum Nato force in Kosovo
28,000 ground troops, 10,200 of them British

Other contingents
United States 4,500
Germany 4,400
France 4,100
Italy 2,400
Canada 700
Greece 500
Netherlands 400

Number of British troops still in Kosovo 4,000
Total cost of Nato bombing campaign $30bn
Cost to Britain Over £82m

Combined force
Two aircraft carriers, over 1,000 aircraft including 24 Apache attack helicopters.
Total of 38,004 sorties

UK contribution
48 aircraft, 1,618 sorties

President Slobodan Milosevic accepted peace terms on June 3.
Nine days later, Nato forces entered Kosovo and by June 20, all Serb forces had left.

webTitle: Golan settlers fear for future of green and pleasant land

fields.headline: Golan settlers fear for future of green and pleasant land
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The resumption of talks was made possible only by the expression of willingness by the Israeli prime minister to withdraw from most or all of the Golan, which Israel captured from Syria in 1967 in the six-day war. And that means that  most of the 17,000 Israelis who have settled on the Golan Heights would have to up sticks and start again elsewhere.
fields.byline: Ilene Prusher in Ma'ale Gamla, Golan Heights
fields.body:
From the Eastons' home, some things look and feel like the English countryside: rolling, green hills; the damp smell of a recent rain; muddy wellingtons; stables with names such as 'Rosie' and 'Alice' on the gates; and the sound of soft-spoken English.

Anne Easton grew up in Kent. James Easton's family left London for Essex when he was 14. They knew they did not want to raise a family in a town.

So it was not surprising that, five years after moving to Israel in 1972, they left their flat in Jerusalem for the Golan Heights, then viewed as a gorgeously pristine backwater that needed to be settled to enhance the security of the Jewish state. The Israeli Labour party was then sending many young activists there, telling them they were pioneers doing their national duty.

But the main attractions for the Eastons were the lush landscape and the prospect of a house with a decent garden. Six children and 15 horses later, they feel at home in this community of some 50 families on the southern tip of the Golan Heights - the crux of the dispute which Israeli and Syrian negotiators once again began trying to settle yesterday in Washington.

All here know that the resumption of those talks, defunct for the past four years, was made possible only by the expression of willingness by the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, to withdraw from most or all of the Golan, which Israel captured from Syria in 1967 in the six-day war. And that means that the Eastons, like most of the 17,000 Israelis who have settled on the Golan Heights, would have to up sticks and start again elsewhere.

It is a hard concept for the Eastons to swallow - and one they say they will fight as best they can.

Though she trained as a pharmacologist, in 1981 Mrs Easton took advantage of the wide open spaces and started training horses. She opened a therapeutic riding school that caters for disabled people.

'I grew up around horses in England, where it's part of the culture - kind of a religion,' says Mrs Easton, as she leads the last of the trotters inside for the afternoon. But the majestic view from the stables is a reminder that this a world away from the British Isles. Soaring mountains that are a patchwork of green forests, sandy dunes, and the snowcapped Mt Hermon present a topographical masterpiece that seems to combine the peaks of Europe with the deserts of Arabia. Up ahead are Syria and Lebanon. Below, to the west, is the sea of Galilee, sparkling like a sapphire on a sunny winter afternoon.

That is where Mr Easton spends his days, surveying the quality of fish life in the sea of Galilee at the Israel Oceanographic and Limnological Research Company. Since the study of lakes is his speciality - he is studying for a PhD in fish ecology - the quality of water in the Bible's famous lake that Israelis call the Kinneret is one of his biggest concerns about making a peace deal with Syria.

'I can see the Syrians building large pumping stations or taking water from the [river] Jordan after a peace agreement is reached, and no one will be able to stop them,' says Mr Easton. 'That could very seriously affect our water, and about 40% of the nation's supply is from the Kinneret. In an area where water is of major strategic value, it should be that they have absolutely no access to the Kinneret or the Jordan in the peace agreement.

'The problem is he [Mr Barak] has already given the Golan away.'

Not exactly. Even if Mr Barak signs a peace deal with the Syrian president, Hafez al-Assad, for the return of the Golan, he will have to get the approval of the majority of Israelis before he fulfils his side of the agreement. As a candidate, Mr Barak had volunteered that he would present the peace deal over the Golan to Israelis in a referendum.

But more hawkish politicians beat him to it. By law, any Israeli leader who wants to relinquish a part of Israel proper - including the Golan, which was officially annexed to Israel in 1981 - must bring the question to Israeli voters first.

Mr Barak has already begun assigning key officials in the Labour party to run a campaign to persuade the public of the wisdom of giving up the Golan in return for peace with Syria

and therefore with neighbouring Lebanon, where Israel has been embroiled in a war of attrition with guerrilla groups such as Hizbullah for more than 15 years. This year promises a battle for the hearts and minds of Israelis - many of whom, like the Eastons, say they want peace but want to keep the land they have come to call their own.

'I do think peace is important, but I don't think it's more important than anything else,' says Mrs Easton, offering mint tea and biscuits in a kitchen dotted with blue china cups that make a visitor feel closer to Staffordshire than Syria.

'It seems like all Syria is interested in is having the Golan back as a matter of respect. It's such a big sacrifice to make,' she adds. 'My parents are aghast. 'Give up your home?' You don't do that - certainly not in England.'

And yet, they and others here know that it will be hard to argue against a chance to end Israel's unpopular war in Lebanon, which has touched their lives as much as anyone else's. In recent years, they have been to several funerals of young soldiers from the community who have died in the fighting. Two of their children have been through the army, while two more are approaching the age of mandatory service.

And for their youngest, a 12-year-old son, the concerns are of any schoolboy: fears of losing friends when they have to move to a new place; a new school. But those are particulars that no one here wants to talk about. The Eastons say they cannot even think about where they would move if they are forced to leave, and are not interested in the national debate over compensation for lost homes.

'I don't know how you can compensate people for 25 years of living here,' says Mrs Easton. 'People have planted orchards. There is a real attachment to the land, and it's a tough life being a farmer.' Around their agricultural settlement, residents are still planting new mangos.

But such acts of denial of the political situation clash with what Mrs Easton says is an air of defeat. 'I must confess that there's a feeling of pessimism there that the race has been run,' she says.

However, the Golan Residents Committee has already launched a protest campaign to fight Mr Barak's plans. And some want to take it further than that.

'This used to be called the 'wild west' of Israel, because people chase around with horses and there are a lot of eccentric people here,' Mrs Easton says, 'and some people are ready to sit on the roof with a gun and refuse to leave.' But she and her husband believe most settlers here would not and should not resort to violence against their own soldiers.

'What I plan to do, in as civilised a way as possible, is to show people the importance of the Golan,' Mr Easton says. 'I think a lot of people here are like us. We'll put up as strong a fight as possible - but if the Israeli people decide we have to leave, then we'll go.'

webTitle: US urges foes to grasp 'huge opportunity'

fields.headline: US urges foes to grasp 'huge opportunity'
fields.standfirst:
Middle East peace talks Israel and Syria in detailed bargaining to end 50-year standoff

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Syrian foreign minister, Farouk Shara'a, began a second round of peace negotiations in the United States yesterday.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Syrian foreign minister, Farouk Shara'a, began a second round of peace negotiations in the United States yesterday.

The talks, dramatically revived last month after a four-year break, are expected to move from generalities to tough and detailed bargaining on territorial withdrawal, water, security, the 'normalisation' of relations, and a timetable for implementation.

The talks were a 'huge historic opportunity' at which 'very, very hard decisions' would have to be made, said the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright. The US was acting as a 'facilitator'; she would attend the negotiations every day and President Bill Clinton would come 'as often as necessary'.

The negotiations, at the secluded West Virginian resort of Shepherdstown, are expected to last a fortnight.

The Israelis appear to have lowered their hopes of a breakthrough - such as a 'framework agreement' - in that time. But Israeli and Arab commentators mostly agree that the chances for a settlement between the Jewish state and its most tenacious Arab neighbour have never been higher.

On the eve of the talks, Syria made it clear that it would not budge from its key territorial demand: a complete Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights and south Lebanon.

By complete withdrawal Syria has always meant withdrawal to the ceasefire line of June 4 1967. That would bring the Israelis down from the strategic high ground above lake Tiberias, and restore Syrian access to its northern shore.

On his way to Washington, Israel's foreign minister, David Levy, said that Syria had 'hardened its position in the past few days'. Haim Ramon, a minister in Mr Barak's office, said: 'We will not withdraw to the June 4 1967 borders.'

But Mr Barak said peace with Syria had 'a very painful, very hard price', but it was 'necessary' to pay it. This line is generally taken to imply a readiness to withdraw from virtually the whole Golan. He insisted, however 'on complete normalisation with both Syria and Lebanon'.

If, as many observers believe, the negotiations are moving into their make-or-break stage, a potent convergence of personal and political factors accounts for that.

Mr Clinton badly needs a foreign policy triumph. Mr Barak is under heavy pressure of his own making, chiefly because of his highly-publicised pledge to end the occupation of south Lebanon by July. If, to keep the pledge, he has to pull out unilaterally without an agreement, what had been a hell-hole for his soldiers could turn into a strategic nightmare for him. The Hizbullah guerrillas might simply move up to the Lebanese frontier, posing a greater threat than before.

But the motives of Syria's president, Hafez al-Assad, appear the most compelling. He made the key contribution to the revival of the negotiations and has insisted that Mr Barak publicly endorse the commitment supposedly made by the late Yitzhak Rabin to withdraw to the June 4 1967 line. But Mr Barak would not do so.

Significant, too, is the high level at which talks were resumed. In the past, the Syrians had balked at increasing the seniority of the interlocutors.

If Mr Assad believes - as may well now be the case - that a peace treaty will strengthen rather than weaken his regime, he obviously wants to achieve one before he hands over to his expected heir, his inexperienced son Bashar. At 71, and in poor health, Mr Assad has little time left.

But it may have been south Lebanon that finally swayed him. A unilateral Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon would greatly reduce any Israeli incentive to quit the Golan. It could also - if Hizbullah is not restrained - lead to massive Israeli attacks on Lebanese 'infrastructure', and that could spark large-scale Israeli-Syrian hostilities which Syria could not possibly win.
