The talks, dramatically revived last month after a four-year break, are expected to move from generalities to tough and detailed bargaining on territorial withdrawal, water, security, the 'normalisation' of relations, and a timetable for implementation. The talks were a 'huge historic opportunity' at which 'very, very hard decisions' would have to be made, said the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright. The US was acting as a 'facilitator'; she would attend the negotiations every day and President Bill Clinton would come 'as often as necessary'. The negotiations, at the secluded West Virginian resort of Shepherdstown, are expected to last a fortnight. The Israelis appear to have lowered their hopes of a breakthrough - such as a 'framework agreement' - in that time. But Israeli and Arab commentators mostly agree that the chances for a settlement between the Jewish state and its most tenacious Arab neighbour have never been higher. On the eve of the talks, Syria made it clear that it would not budge from its key territorial demand: a complete Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights and south Lebanon. By complete withdrawal Syria has always meant withdrawal to the ceasefire line of June 4 1967. That would bring the Israelis down from the strategic high ground above lake Tiberias, and restore Syrian access to its northern shore. On his way to Washington, Israel's foreign minister, David Levy, said that Syria had 'hardened its position in the past few days'. Haim Ramon, a minister in Mr Barak's office, said: 'We will not withdraw to the June 4 1967 borders.' But Mr Barak said peace with Syria had 'a very painful, very hard price', but it was 'necessary' to pay it. This line is generally taken to imply a readiness to withdraw from virtually the whole Golan. He insisted, however 'on complete normalisation with both Syria and Lebanon'. If, as many observers believe, the negotiations are moving into their make-or-break stage, a potent convergence of personal and political factors accounts for that. Mr Clinton badly needs a foreign policy triumph. Mr Barak is under heavy pressure of his own making, chiefly because of his highly-publicised pledge to end the occupation of south Lebanon by July. If, to keep the pledge, he has to pull out unilaterally without an agreement, what had been a hell-hole for his soldiers could turn into a strategic nightmare for him. The Hizbullah guerrillas might simply move up to the Lebanese frontier, posing a greater threat than before. But the motives of Syria's president, Hafez al-Assad, appear the most compelling. He made the key contribution to the revival of the negotiations and has insisted that Mr Barak publicly endorse the commitment supposedly made by the late Yitzhak Rabin to withdraw to the June 4 1967 line. But Mr Barak would not do so. Significant, too, is the high level at which talks were resumed. In the past, the Syrians had balked at increasing the seniority of the interlocutors. If Mr Assad believes - as may well now be the case - that a peace treaty will strengthen rather than weaken his regime, he obviously wants to achieve one before he hands over to his expected heir, his inexperienced son Bashar. At 71, and in poor health, Mr Assad has little time left. But it may have been south Lebanon that finally swayed him. A unilateral Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon would greatly reduce any Israeli incentive to quit the Golan. It could also - if Hizbullah is not restrained - lead to massive Israeli attacks on Lebanese 'infrastructure', and that could spark large-scale Israeli-Syrian hostilities which Syria could not possibly win.

fields.headline: The Outsiders
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText:
Bill Bradley
The Democratic outsider has been in the national spotlight for nearly 35 years, initially as a phenomenally successful basketball player and then as senator for New Jersey. Born in Missouri in 1943, Mr Bradley - like Bill Clinton - is a former Rhodes scholar at Oxford university.
fields.body:
Bill Bradley
The Democratic outsider has been in the national spotlight for nearly 35 years, initially as a phenomenally successful basketball player and then as senator for New Jersey. Born in Missouri in 1943, Mr Bradley - like Bill Clinton - is a former Rhodes scholar at Oxford university.

He is serious and dignified, prickly and private, and has always been a moderate. His fundraising abilities and contacts on Wall Street earned him the nickname 'Dollar Bill'. His disciplined, strategic approach - and the absence of other candidates - meant that he emerged in 1999 as a strong alternative to Mr Gore.

If Mr Bradley is elected president, his German-born wife will be the first foreign-born first lady in US history.

John McCain
The Republican outsider has been in the public eye for more than a generation as a war hero.

McCain was born in the Panama Canal Zone in 1936 and led a tearaway youth which he documents in his bestselling autobiography. He finished near the bottom of his class at Annapolis Naval College, became a navy flier, and on his 23rd raid over North Vietnam in October 1967 was shot down over Hanoi.

For the next five and a half years, he was held at the 'Hanoi Hilton', where he was tortured. He returned to the US in 1973.

Elected to the House of Representatives from Arizona in 1982, McCain won a senate seat there four years later.

He is married to Cindy, his second wife and has seven children from his two marriages.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Happy New Year, cherished readers, and welcome to a special, souvenir edition of the Sidelines of Hope.
fields.body:
Happy New Year, cherished readers, and welcome to a special, souvenir edition of the Sidelines of Hope. Oh! The Minnellium. Ah! That snuggly moment of tender oneness shared by all peoples across the globe. Was it the beginning? Was it the end? Was it somewhere in between? Where in between and was that place somewhere with portaloos or not? And ooh! The blazing, fazing, a-mazing fireworks that symbolised the dawning of a sparkling new era in which everything is nice and not nasty. Dah! The ickle babies that lit up the skyline from Sydney to Sydenham. (Can I go home now?) Well, wake up, suckers. You've got gout and there are no more Bank Holidays until April. It's going to rain all month and the only thing you've got left to look forward to is the short-lived excitement of buying your mid-afternoon packet of Minstrels.

At least Sidelines of Joy is in good company: Liz Hurley's festive spirit also appears worn a little thin. A few days after being voted Babe of the Century by those people we used to call 'Internet anoraks' but now call 'Start-up millionaires' and 'Sir', Hurley turned on her closest rival, Marilyn Monroe. 'If I were as fat as Monroe, I'd kill myself,' she told readers of Allure magazine. And how right she is to put lardy old Marilyn in her place. Monroe, who has all but faded from public consciousness, offered us pork scratching in comparison to the (low fat) ostrich steak that is la Hurley. Her outstanding performance in Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me, her gripping relationship with the charismatic and similarly talented Hugh Grant, and her devilishly sexy habit of showing her pants in public mark her out as an icon of our age. We're surprised anyone bothered to vote for Monroe at all.

webTitle: Primary campaigns hot up as key votes near

fields.headline: Primary campaigns hot up as key votes near
fields.standfirst:
Frontrunners face possible upsets in early contests

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: After months of build-up, the political contest to succeed Bill Clinton as United States president at last gets down and dirty this week.
fields.body:
After months of build-up, the political contest to succeed Bill Clinton as United States president at last gets down and dirty this week.

Three weeks before the first important nomination battle in the Iowa caucuses, followed by New Hampshire's primary a week later, both the Democratic and the Republican frontrunners are staring possible upsets in the face.

On the Democratic side, the former New Jersey senator Bill Bradley has been leading the longtime favourite, Al Gore, in all the recent New Hampshire polls. In Iowa, where Mr Gore has a big lead, the surging Bradley campaign has begun to pour up to $800,000 (£500,000) into a three-week television advertising blitz in an attempt to inflict a devastating early double defeat on the vice-president.

The contest is equally hard fought on the Republican side. George W Bush, the Texas governor whose $69m campaign bank balance has helped make him seemingly unstoppable, is trailing in New Hampshire behind the Arizona senator John McCain, while hanging on to a solid but fraying lead over his rival elsewhere.

Yesterday, the two Democratic contenders traded big theme speeches ahead of a candidates' debate in New Hampshire tomorrow and in Iowa on Saturday. Mr Gore and Mr Bradley also have two debates scheduled this month, while the Republican candidates face five debates.

Mr Bush is expected to play a powerful card when Elizabeth Dole, who dropped out of the Republican contest last October, gives him her endorsement in a swing through the two states today. In a year in which both parties are tipped to choose women as presidential running-mates, Mrs Dole's move could make her a likely vice-presidential nominee if Mr Bush wins the Republican candidacy.

Nevertheless, after months in which a Gore-Bush contest next November had seemed a foregone conclusion, there is now the serious possibility that both men could suffer defeats in the coming weeks which would throw the whole 2000 election wide open.

Following a deceptive holiday lull, all the candidates will be back on the campaign trail again today, beginning the last and most crucial phase of an intensive contest in which the traditional months-long battle for the US party nominations has been compressed into a winter timetable which means that the winners are likely to be known by mid-March.

The critical first test for the candidates comes in the Iowa caucuses on January 24, when registered party supporters cast votes in open meetings which place a premium on prior organisation. For that reason, Mr Gore, with his prodigious organisational base, is the favourite to defeat Mr Bradley there. Mr Bush, who has been campaigning assiduosly in Iowa for months, is likewise odds-on to win there, especially as Mr McCain has decided not to enter the contest until New Hampshire on February 1.

The challenge to Mr Bush in Iowa is most likely to come from the millionaire Steve Forbes, whose bottomless purse gives him an advantage over the other hopefuls in the Republican race. In a crafty move, however, the McCain campaign is quietly working for a write-in vote for their man, who is officially not an Iowa contender. His aides believe that if Mr McCain runs a 'surprise' second in a state where he has not even campaigned, his campaign will receive a nationwide boost.

Days after Iowa, the focus returns to New Hampshire, which has again seen off challenges to its unique status as the first presidential primary state in the political calendar. With its history of quixotic upsets, defeat for either Mr Gore or Mr Bush in New Hampshire would be more embarrassing than fatal. For the challengers, on the other hand, success in New Hampshire is a precondition for victory this year.

Iowa and New Hampshire are 'must-win states for Bradley and McCain' said William Mayer, editor of a new book on the nomination process. 'If they don't win those, the race is over.' This year, however, the early contests will be quickly followed by a speeded-up schedule of further primaries which place a premium on funding and organisation, and which have been arranged in this manner to favour party establishment candidates like the two frontrunners. The timetable is especially harsh on Mr McCain. If he wins in New Hamsphire, he faces a succession of Republican contests during February in South Carolina, Michigan, Arizona, North Dakota and Virginia, which will stretch his resources to the limit. On the Democratic side, by contrast, New Hampshire is followed by a month-long gap preceding the probably decisive 'Super Tuesday' contests on March 7.

After New Hampshire, March 7 is D-Day for both parties. On that day, both will hold primaries in New York, California and 10 other states which will irreversibly shape the delegate counts for their conventions this summer.

webTitle: F-words persuade Warren Beatty not to run

fields.headline: F-words persuade Warren Beatty not to run
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Warren Beatty stripped the American presidential campaign of its only hope of a patina of glamour yesterday when the movie star finally made it plain that he will not be a candidate.  Beatty indicated that three 'f-words' were behind his decision: a desire to retain his freedom; an unwillingness to make a fool of himself; and the fear that he might do more to damage than promote the liberal causes he supports.
fields.body:
Warren Beatty stripped the American presidential campaign of its only hope of a patina of glamour yesterday when the movie star finally made it plain that he will not be a candidate. Beatty indicated that three 'f-words' were behind his decision: a desire to retain his freedom; an unwillingness to make a fool of himself; and the fear that he might do more to damage than promote the liberal causes he supports.

The Hollywood actor, director and producer - active in Democratic politics for more than 30 years - rules himself out of a run for the White House in his first interview on the subject since he started flirting with it six months ago.

'I feel good about speaking up,' he says in the February edition of Vanity Fair. 'I wouldn't feel good if I hadn't. It seems to me that the effect has been positive, that I've not yet made too much of a fool of myself - at least, I don't think I have.'

He goes on: 'I have not diminished the importance of the issues. One has to be very, very careful not to be an unwitting party to making what most people consider to be unfashionably liberal ideas appear to be more unpopular than they really are.'

Beatty, an early victim of Clinton fatigue, says that much of his message might fall on deaf ears: universal medical cover; action against exploitation of workers; and rebuilding the schools system and raising teachers' pay.

But even though a poll found that, of putative presidential candidates, only property tycoon Donald Trump and rightwing Republican Pat Buchanan were viewed more negatively, the star said he might run at a later date.

webTitle: Spate of new stamps upsets philatelists

fields.headline: Spate of new stamps upsets philatelists
fields.trailText: Britain's philatelists threatened to bite the hand that feeds them yesterday when they warned the Post Office that they would close their albums for ever from December 31 1999 if it continued to issue an excess of sub-standard stamps.
fields.body:
Britain's philatelists threatened to bite the hand that feeds them yesterday when they warned the Post Office that they would close their albums for ever from December 31 1999 if it continued to issue an excess of sub-standard stamps.

The threat came as the Post Office prepared to release 48 new millennium stamps this year, a collection that leading stamp collectors claim puts quantity before quality.

Peter Jennings, a fellow of the Royal Philatelic Society, said that the glut of stamps had caused many collectors to question the worth of continuing the hobby, and that some had decided the end of the 20th century was an opportune time to lay down their eyeglasses.

Between 1840 and 1900 the Royal Mail issued 214 different stamps but now produce more than that number every three years.

'They are issuing too many new stamps and a lot of collectors have used December 31 1999 to stop their collections and say they won't be buying any of the stamps issued in the year 2000 and beyond,' said Mr Jennings.'To safeguard the hobby of philately the Royal Mail needs to listen carefully to the views of stamp collectors and issue fewer new stamps,' he said.

Mr Jennings's comments come three days before the Post Office issues its first stamp of the 21st century, a first class stamp bearing a white portrait of the Queen on an olive background, a design which some have hailed as refreshingly retro in feel. 'It is a good, distinctive colour and a bold design,' said Mr Jennings. 'My personal opinion is that I hope it will persuade new collectors to start this hobby with the first stamp of the year 2000,' he said.

The batch that has raised the collectors' ire includes scenes intended to commemorate the flurry of activity that has greeted the new millennium. Stamps released this month will bear images of Muncaster Castle in Cumbria which has just entered its third millennium, the Scottish Seabird Centre in Berwick, and the Torrs walkway in Derbyshire. Stamps featuring the tower blocks of Croydon, south London, and Mile End Park in east London are due for release later in the year.

A Post Office spokesman said: 'We have been using some of the leading designers in the country and the stamps have been widely praised in this country and around the world'.

Last November the Post Office issued designs by artists including Bridget Riley, Ralph Steadman, David Hockney and Peter Blake.

'Tony Blair named Royal Mail stamps as one of the designs of the millennium and they are on display in the dome, so they have won a lot of plaudits,' said Mr Simpson. 'This is an individual's point of view and not in any way representative of a wider body of opinion. The stamps we have been issuing have been very successful and there's no doubt they will continue to be successful.'

webTitle: Odd couple heads race for city status

fields.headline: Odd couple heads race for city status
fields.standfirst: Brighton and Hove is bookies' favourite as 39 towns squabble and cajole to earn Queen's favour in a competition shrouded in mystery
fields.trailText: Brighton and Hove, until recently rival twins trading regular insults, emerged yesterday as the frontrunner in the race to become the first city of the new millennium.
fields.body:
Brighton and Hove, until recently rival twins trading regular insults, emerged yesterday as the frontrunner in the race to become the first city of the new millennium. The newly unified borough, New Labour's model council on the south coast, is the 4-1 favourite out of 39 towns bidding for city status in a competition shrouded in mystery.

No one is quite sure when the final decision will be made, still less the procedure used by the Queen, on the advice of the home secretary, to create Britain's 59th city.

Lavish videos, websites, and endless stunts have formed part of the armoury of contestants, ranging from the comical to the magisterial. Harsh words have been spoken, verbal grenades thrown - particularly along the M4 between Reading (12-1) and Swindon (16-1) - as competitors enter the final straight.

Brighton and Hove even used a relay team of cyclists to present its 'people's bid' - contained in a wooden box crafted by a local sculptor - to the home office.

That failed to impress Milton Keynes (12-1) the country's fastest-growing town, which has long insisted on calling itself a city even without official status. 'I always think a town with 'and' in the middle of its name is trying to make itself bigger, and better than it actually is,' stormed Kevin Wilson, leader of Milton Keynes council.

Since the home office announced that one town would be elevated to city status early in 2000, many contenders have taken comfort from the reluctance of most bookies to give any odds. 'It's far too imprecise,' said Ladbrokes. 'How on earth can you make a judgment?'.

That did not stop William Hill gingerly entering the fray yesterday with a table of odds, although its spokesman, Graham Sharpe, admitted: 'It's a race without a course and with no form guide.' Nevertheless, punters had waged up to £1,000. Some, Mr Sharpe suspected, were members of campaign teams attemping to bolster the standing of individual towns.

Luton, which has been labelled a northern-style industrial town which somehow found itself in the south, surprisingly came second favourite with odds of 8-1. Bill McKenzie, its council leader, was not surprised. He believes Luton's charm lies in its ordinariness. 'Anyone who comes here can make their way in life. OK, it might not be leafy laned, south-east suburbia - a Virginia Water in Bedfordshire - but it has an honest, can-do attitude and is very representative of Britain today.'

His only problem is that Milton Keynes, a few miles down the M1, is also challenging hard. With a 210,000 population, it has been identified by planners as a major growth point which could mean its population doubling to almost half a million in the first quarter of the next century.

Kevin Wilson, its council leader, said the town that only became a borough in 1974 could soon have a population bigger than Liverpool (452,000 and falling fast). 'I can't think of a better way of celebrating the millennium than by giving a new town city status for the first time.'

He has even enlisted the support of the jazz musician John Dankworth and his wife Cleo Laine, who live in a village on the outskirts of the town. Dankworth recently wrote that MK had matured from what seemed a 'disordered mass' into a sensitively planned metropolis 'with more than a few touches of brilliance'. Built on a grid system, with wide boulevards and few definining features apart from a newish ecumenical church, it certainly has detractors. Simon Fanshawe, the broadcaster and entertainer, would probably be one of them. He chairs a ''rainbow coalition'' pushing Brighton and Hove's bid. 'We've brought together a group of bright bunnies, not the great and the good, or the middle-aged and the worthy, but the active and the significant.'

Brighton might have been a fading resort a few years ago, but it had become the natural capital of the south coast, attracting 'the talented, the quirky, the imaginative'.

What about Hove, now part of the same local authority? 'Well, it was a bit of Rhodesia on the south coast, but now it's even got a Labour MP,' said Fanshawe, who graduated from Sussex university 25 years ago. But some would dispute his assertion that the 'two towns are naturally joined together'.

Further north, along the booming M4 corridor, Reading and Swindon are proving that New Labour harmony has its limits. The two towns almost came to blows when Swindon was portrayed, in a national advertisement, as a pastoral idyll rather than an old railway town made good.

Martin Salter, MP for Reading West, was forced to apologise to his Swindon counterparts when he told his local paper he had 'every sympathy for everyone who has to live in Swindon... the River Thames in Wiltshire is little more than a ditch.'

The newly unified borough, New Labour's model council on the south coast, is the 4-1 favourite out of 39 towns bidding for city status in a competition shrouded in mystery. No one is quite sure when the final decision will be made, still less the procedure used by the Queen, on the advice of the home secretary, to create Britain's 59th city. Lavish videos, websites, and endless stunts have formed part of the armoury of contestants, ranging from the comical to the magisterial. Harsh words have been spoken, verbal grenades thrown - particularly along the M4 between Reading (12-1) and Swindon (16-1) - as competitors enter the final straight. Brighton and Hove even used a relay team of cyclists to present its 'people's bid' - contained in a wooden box crafted by a local sculptor - to the home office. 'I always think a town with 'and' in the middle of its name is trying to make itself bigger, and better than it actually is,' stormed Kevin Wilson, leader of Milton Keynes council. 'It's far too imprecise,' said Ladbrokes. 'How on earth can you make a judgment?'. webTitle: Cancelled parole left one costly inmate with Maze all to himself

fields.headline: Cancelled parole left one costly inmate with Maze all to himself
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: At least one terrorist prisoner in Northern Ireland will be pleased to see more than 120 republicans and loyalists return to the Maze this morning after 12 days' festive parole. Mark McGuckin has been left alone in the sprawling prison complex 10 miles from Belfast.
fields.body:
At least one terrorist prisoner in Northern Ireland will be pleased to see more than 120 republicans and loyalists return to the Maze this morning after 12 days' festive parole. Mark McGuckin has been left alone in the sprawling prison complex 10 miles from Belfast.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, took the unprecedented step of allowing parole to all convicted prisoners, even those who did not qualify. Included were bombers, murderers and gunmen.

He refused it to five Loyalist Volunteer Force inmates on remand, but they were able to celebrate Christmas on the outside after winning high court challenges in Belfast.

Three of them might have wished they had never bothered. They were attacked in a row between the LVF and the Ulster Volunteer Force eight days ago but were allowed to continue their parole after the authorities decided they had been victims rather than instigators of the fight in Portadown, Co Armagh.

So the Maze, only a couple of years ago home to up to 800 terrorists, would have had no inmates over Christmas for the first time. As Finlay Spratt, chair of the Prison Officers Association, said yesterday: "Changed times indeed."

But McGuckin, 38, serving life for murder on the LVF wing of the prison, lasted only a day on the outside before he was arrested after a pub fracas in his home town of Cookstown, Co Tyrone. He was charged with assaulting two police officers and possessing cannabis, refused bail and returned on Christmas Eve to his cell.

It cost the taxpayers a pretty penny. A cook was brought in to prepare his Christmas turkey meal, with costs estimated at £2,000. One report suggested the additional cost of guarding him over the holiday period came to almost £20,000.

The prison service said 30 staff were required at the Maze at any time over Christmas. Most would have been needed, even if all prisoners were out, to maintain the security of the 130 acre site. But four more prison officers were required to guard McGuckin, on holiday rates of pay.

Five of the eight four-winged H-blocks at the Maze, formerly called Long Kesh, are still in use. Only a handful of prisoners are in each, with paramilitaries still refusing to share a block with those of another group.

So far 308 convicted terrorists have been freed through the early release scheme, which hugely boosts remission rates. The deal is a cornerstone of the Good Friday agreement.

Fewer than 130 prisoners remain, and under the deal they will be freed in July as long as ceasefires hold. The Maze is expected to close soon afterwards, although one block could be made into a museum.

One worrying feature is a spate of fires at Maghaberry prison, which houses those convicted of terrorist offences committed after April 10 last year, the date of the agreement. Inmates objecting to the harsher regime have been involved in a series of disputes, and the fire brigade had to douse another blaze yesterday.

McGuckin, then in the UVF, was jailed for life two years ago, one of five men convicted for their role in the murder of George Scott, 32, of Cookstown. One of his co-accused said the UVF attack was a punishment beating gone too far.

Three masked men clubbed Scott to death in the living room of his home in September 1996 while his girlfriend was forced to stay in the kitchen.

webTitle: Spice Girl Mel G splits from husband

fields.headline: Spice Girl Mel G splits from husband
fields.trailText: Spice Girl Mel G, née B, may soon be reverting to her maiden initial after it emerged yesterday that she is to separate from husband, Jimmy Gulzar, after a 15-month marriage that produced one daughter.
fields.body:
Spice Girl Mel G, née B, may soon be reverting to her maiden initial after it emerged yesterday that she is to separate from husband, Jimmy Gulzar, after a 15-month marriage that produced one daughter.

The couple tried to save the union with a family Christmas at their mansion in Little Marlow, Berkshire, but the attempted rapprochement ended in failure when Mel, 24, left the house following a New Year's Day row, taking 10-month old Phoenix Chi with her. She is believed to be staying with her father, Martin Brown, in her home town of Leeds.

On Sunday evening a joint statement was released to the effect that despite attempts to make the relationship work the couple would separate, though they would 'remain good friends'.

"It is an incredibly emotional experience, it is trau matic for both of them," added a spokesman.

The pair met in 1998 when Gulzar, 31, was hired as a backing dancer for the Spice Girls' 1998 UK tour, and after a seven-week romance during which Phoenix-Chi was conceived, Gulzar proposed. The couple was married at Little Marlow in September 1998 wearing matching gold outfits and amid tight security after the publishing rights to the wedding were sold to a magazine.

At the time Mel was convinced the marriage would last. "We'll be together forever. Oh yes forever. That's what you do it for in the first place isn't it?"

Within eight months however things had started to go wrong and the pair moved into separate wings of their £2.5m home. Space failed to ease the strained relationship and a custody battle over Phoenix-Chi began, with Gulzar consulting lawyers in an attempt to stop her accompanying her mother to America before the couple sought the help of a marriage guidance counsellor.

"We have been through hell and back, but we have something worth saving. We've been given the perfect chance to make our marriage work and we're going to do just that," Mel said at the time.

webTitle: Europe finally files beef ban suit

fields.headline: Europe finally files beef ban suit
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: The European commission will file its European court of justice case against France's continued ban on British beef today, a day later than promised and nearly a week after Paris lodged its countersuit against the commission.
fields.body:
The European commission will file its European court of justice case against France's continued ban on British beef today, a day later than promised and nearly a week after Paris lodged its countersuit against the commission.

The court in Luxembourg confirmed yesterday that France had filed a counteraction last Wednesday asking it to overturn the commission's decision to lift the EU embargo on British beef imports. A court spokesman said the suit argued that the commission had failed to take into account new French evidence on the possible health risks of British beef and had broken the EU's principle of safeguarding human health even when evidence of risk was not clear cut.

In Brussels a commission spokesman said the launch of the EU's proceedings against France, expected yesterday, had been delayed because the complicated legal documentation had to be approved by the legal services. The documents were expected to be delivered to Luxembourg tomorrow, he said. 'That is when the action will begin.'

The embarrassing tit-for-tat, which could see France in the dock at the same time as it assumes the rotating EU presidency in July, follows the lifting of the EU's three-year ban on sales of British beef last August.

Member states declared themselves satisfied with the strict safety measures put in place by British farmers after the government's admission of a possible link between bovine spongiform encephalopathy and a new form of the human brain disorder Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is so far believed to be responsible for the deaths of 48 people. Despite protracted negotiations, France has refused to lift the ban, citing 'significant if unquantifiable risks' to consumers from eating British beef.

The spokesman also said the commission would decide in the next few days whether to try to speed up the European court proceedings against France - which could well take up to two years - by asking for interim measures. He said this was a complex process which would involve the commission giving up some of its procedural rights. 'There are extremely stringent rules, and the commission would request interim measures only if it believed it had a serious chance of obtaining them.'

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Police seek help over sex attacks  | Bogus milkman is suspect killer
fields.body:
Police seek help over sex attacks
Police in Edinburgh yesterday appealed for witnesses in two cases of sexual assault on millennium night. A New Zealander aged 19, due to go home after working in the city as a waitress, fought back when attacked by a man who offered to escort her to a police station, while a Danish tourist, 23, was indecently assaulted by a man who offered a lift.

Travellers defy expectations
More than 1,500 travellers yesterday complied with a police request to leave Great Yarmouth in Norfolk. They had had a peaceful holiday in 400 caravans parked near the front, confounding residents' fears there would be trouble.

Bogus milkman is suspect killer
Police on Merseyside suspect that a bogus milkman may be the murderer of Marjorie Keating, 83, found battered to death at her home in Bootle on Sunday. Detectives said she apparently struggled with a burglar - possibly the same man, with tatoos on the fingers of his left hand, who last week had talked her into handing over £13.

Gales bring power cuts
More than 10,000 homes in Orkney, Shetland, the Western Isles and the Highlands were temporalily without electricity yesterday when winds of more than 100 mph blew down power lines. From Russia for art lovers Art treasures from St Petersburg will go on display in London this autumn. Russia has agreed to create an outstation of the Hermitage at Somerset House, with an opening show devoted to Catherine the Great.

fields.headline: New Listener online
fields.trailText: One of the great names in magazine publishing will be reborn this month when the BBC uses the internet to relaunch the Listener.
fields.body:
One of the great names in magazine publishing will be reborn this month when the BBC uses the internet to relaunch the Listener.

Closed nine years ago after 62 years of distinguished coverage of the arts, culture, politics and media, the Listener is to be revived as part of BBC plans to exploit a sharp growth in demand for online magazines. Plans to publish a cyberspace version are understood to be at an advanced stage, with January 27 pencilled in as a target date for the title's first appearance.

The title will carry cartoons and columns as well as articles. The editor is understood to be Giles Wilson, the chief feature writer for BBC News Online.

Last night Bob Eggington, project director at BBC News Online, confirmed the plans.

'We expect magazine-type publications on the internet to be a big thing in the UK in the next 12 months,' he said. The BBC had a 'wonderful' brand in the Listener.

Mr Eggington indicated that the publication would appear as a one-off edition, giving the BBC the chance to assess demand before committing itself to regular publication.

BBC sources indicated that the revival was a further example of how the BBC's online plans would accelerate under the command of Greg Dyke, the incoming director general, who also wants to press ahead with an internet sports site.

The online Listener will include interactive features, and allow users to access audio and possibly video broadcasts.

BBC executives are expecting US online magazines to expand rapidly in Britain. One suggested that the US magazine salon.com would launch a version aimed at Britons.

The Listener was launched in January 1929 and by 1948 had a circulation of 153,000. It published pieces by, among others, WH Auden, Bertrand Russell, EM Forster, Dylan Thomas, Bernard Shaw, AJP Taylor, George Orwell and Philip Larkin. Editors included Anthony Howard, Alan Coren, Russell Twisk and Peter Fiddick.

But it was closed after circulation fell to 17,000 and losses hit £1m as advertising fell in the recession.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.standfirst: Terrestrial
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Vets In The Wild 8pm, BBC1

So why are Trude Mostue and Steve Leonard of Vets' School fame so popular? Perhaps it's because, as they drive around Zimbabwe in the cringingly-named vetmobile, there's something engagingly enthusiastic about the duo. It's as if they can't quite believe their luck at getting paid to visit a crocodile farm (where Leonard, armed only with what looks like a dirty dishcloth, gamely subdues a croc) and assist with a biopsy on a sick elephant. Blue Peter for grown-ups.

Life And Death In The 21st Century: An Horizon Trilogy 8pm, BBC2

In truth, the emphasis here is firmly on life, the prospect of vastly lengthened life in the forthcoming century to be exact. Already, scientists have found genes that allow fruit flies to live longer, and are tantalisingly close to understanding the biological processes that limit our own lifespans. Could it be that we will one day become immortal? The first in a thought-provoking series detailing cutting-edge research in controversial medical areas.

Murder Rooms: The Dark Beginnings Of Sherlock Holmes 9pm, BBC2

Sir Arthur Conan Doyle took the inspiration for Holmes from his lecturer at Edinburgh University, Victorian pathologist Dr Joseph Bell. That's the starting point for this two-parter directed by Paul Steed (A House Of Cards). Like Holmes and Watson, Bell (played with a cool ambiguity by Ian Richardson) and Doyle (Robin Laing) are soon investigating a series of grisly crimes in an intriguing drama.

Au Pairs 9.30pm, BBC1

This documentary begins optimistically enough with Nicole, Zoe and Donna jetting off to help out families abroad. But it soon becomes clear that the three are, to a greater or lesser degree, out of their depth. Wiser council, for instance, might have suggested to Nicole that striking up a phone friendship with her employer's ex-wife was a lousy idea. On the other hand, you really wouldn't wish any of the young women's employers on your worst enemy. Frightening.

webTitle: Hague off the hook as Tory MP denies plans to defect

fields.headline: Hague off the hook as Tory MP denies plans to defect
fields.trailText: William Hague won a brief respite yesterday when the maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, denied that she was planning to defect to the anti-European United Kingdom Independence party.
fields.body:
William Hague won a brief respite yesterday when the maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, denied that she was planning to defect to the anti-European United Kingdom Independence party.

Amid speculation that Mrs Gorman, MP for Billericay, was planning to jump ship, she issued a brief statement saying: 'I have absolutely no plans to apply for membership of the UK Independence party.'

Her intervention, after recent disclosures that she has been in discussions with the UKIP, gave some comfort to the Tory leadership still reeling from Shaun Woodward's defection to Labour. However, her terse statement, which failed to criticise the UKIP or praise her own party, did little to dampen speculation that she might eventually defect.

The MP is understood to be angry with Mr Hague after she was blocked from contesting the Tory nomination for London mayor. Membership of the UKIP could provide her with a useful platform in May's mayoral election.

Nigel Farage, the UKIP chair-man who is one of the party's three Euro MPs, insisted last night that he was still involved in negotiations with Conservative MPs and peers, and he was confident that at least one would jump ship. Mr Farage refused to name the MP believed to be one of the 'whipless eight', the hardline Eurosceptics who had the Conservative whip withdrawn by John Major in 1994.

Mr Farage said: 'I think things will happen over the next couple of weeks. I think that because there is a large element now in the Conservative party who are very unhappy with Hague's policy of being in Europe and not run by Europe. They realise that that is not coherent, that the simple choice is that we are either in the European Union and we make the best that we can of it, or we come out.'

A defection from the Eurosceptic wing of the Tory party would represent a serious blow to Mr Hague who is still recovering from Mr Woodward's defection to Labour.

Conservative Central Office dismissed as 'speculative reports' suggestions that the Ruislip Northwood MP, John Wilkinson, had also been in discussions with the UKIP.

The prospect of Tory defections came amid renewed splits in the UKIP. Michael Holmes, the party's leader, who has been at loggerheads with Mr Farage, said he had not authorised any meetings with disaffected Tory MPs. 'It is when our party has decided its future that that will be the time to have discreet contacts with people who are, perhaps, dissatisfied,' he said.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.standfirst: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Before Sunrise (Richard Linklater, 1994) 8pm, FilmFour

Ever-so-sweet love story which has American traveller Ethan Hawke and chic Parisian Julie Delpy (pictured) meeting on a train in Vienna, then spending the 15 hours before his flight home together. There's a bit of Linklater's Slacker in the couple's encounters with Viennese odd-bods, but it's centred on their mutual discovery: poignant and beautifully played.

Lolita (Adrian Lyne, 1997) 10pm, Sky Premier

A fairly decent attempt to film Nabokov's indecent novel about a man's love for an under-age nymphet, and the whole emotional trauma of love. In raising the girl's age by a couple of years Lyne undermines the book's satirical intent, but he stays closer to the novel than Kubrick's 1961 version. And there are some fine performances Ð Jeremy Irons as the bemused and distressed Humbert; Frank Langella the shadowy Quilty, and Dominique Swain a seductive Lolita.

Room at the Top(Jack Clayton, 1959) 12.55am, Sky Cinema

Muck-and-brass northern drama adapted by Oscar-winning Neil Patterson from John Braine's novel about working class anti-hero Joe Lampton. Brillcreemed Laurence Harvey is cynical and sneering but Simone Signoret is the class act, also nabbing an Oscar for her discarded mistress as Joe nips up the ladder to a proper marriage. A groundbreaker in its candid treatment of sex, it inspired films such as Saturday Night And Sunday Morning and This Sporting Life.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.standfirst: Radio
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
The narrow tightrope many of us walk when our emotions are disrupted is explored by Dr Gillian Rice. In Excess (9.0pm, Radio 4) deals first with love and jealousy, particularly the worrying phenomenon of stalking. About half such episodes involve one-time partners, often with a history of domestic violence. But many others spring from what is known as erotomania, where stalkers convince themselves that their victims are passionately in love with them.

Campbell Burnap launches a six-part series on the remarkable career of the jazz cornetist Bix Beiderbecke. A middle-class lad who never learned to read a stave, his stunning musical talent emerged on the family piano at the age of two. But as implied in the title, Bix Ð The Romance And Reality (10.0pm, Radio 2), mythology has long taken over. Fortunately we get bags of the recordings in which, to quote one startled admirer, Beiderbecke's cornet delivery was "like shooting bullets at a bell".

fields.headline: The 'real' Sherlock Holmes
fields.standfirst: A new BBC drama about the origins of the world's most famous detective mixes fact and fiction until they are indistinguishable. It has always been a popular technique for writers but Maxton Walker thinks there are hidden dangers
fields.trailText: A new BBC drama about the origins of the world's most famous detective mixes fact and fiction until they are indistinguishable. It has always been a popular technique for writers but Maxton Walker thinks there are hidden dangers
fields.body:
I blame William Shakespeare. Now there was a man who knew how to play fast and loose with the facts when it suited him. Take poor Richard III, for example. Does anybody now imagine him as anything other than a great malevolent bottled spider? And tonight a two-part BBC serial Murder Rooms (9pm, BBC2) Ð which purports to reveal the origins of Sherlock Holmes Ð reinvents the early years of the great detective's creator, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, with a similar healthy disregard of the known facts.

The premise is ingenious. In Edinburgh in 1878, young medical student, Conan Doyle, catches the eye of a brilliant surgeon-cum-detective called Joseph Bell (played by Ian Richardson) and becomes his assistant. After helping Bell, who is on the trail of a local serial killer, Conan Doyle is inspired to create the world's most famous detective.

It's a producer's dream: a Sherlock Holmes mystery and high-class costume drama rolled into one, without the need to go through the palaver of reinventing the detective for the small screen. But there's one problem: Murder Rooms is mixture of fiction and supposition.

The starting point is accurate enough. Joseph Bell was one of the sources for Holmes, the young Conan Doyle did work as his out-patient clerk, and Bell did do covert work for the Crown. But the rest is a largely a product of scriptwriter David Pirie's imagination. We are still left with a supposed historical drama which is little more than a Holmes pastiche. And that is worrying for a number of reasons.

As Shakespeare shows, mixing fact and fiction is nothing new, but there are ways of pulling it off. The Beatles' films, the BBC version of Arthur Smith's play An Evening With Gary Lineker, and the soon-to-be-released film, Being John Malkovich, all use the conceit of having famous people playing themselves in scripted drama. I dabbled in the same genre last year when I wrote a play (another Edinburgh-based murder mystery) featuring a fictionalised version of the author Iain Banks in which the real Banks played 'himself'. But although such productions blur the boundary between reality and artifice, there's no danger of misleading anybody; audiences are in on the joke from the start.

Murder Rooms is different. Reinventing the lives of people who are dead and gone is positively dangerous. Many viewers will believe it's an accurate depiction of Conan Doyle's early years. But Sherlock Holmes was a fictional creation, undoubtedly influenced by Bell, but still a character that owed everything to Conan Doyle's imagination. Murder Rooms implies that Holmes was a virtual clone of Bell. Moreover it suggests that many of the key elements of the Holmes stories landed in Conan Doyle's lap while he served as the surgeon's assistant.

In fact, it goes even further, implying that Holmes's creation was an angst-driven attempt to invent an idealised version of Bell after the surgeon made a fatal blunder in the course of an investigation. This in turn only reinforces the misconception that writers' ideas are always drawn directly from their own experiences (do people really believe writers are incapable of making things up?).

But why are writers attracted to such a strange genre in the first place? Well, for a start, writing fiction about real authors is great fun. Even better, there's no need to search for a suitable 'voice'; you can just appropriate your subject's. And, in an age when post-modernism is so highly prized, there's nothing more guaranteed to impress the critics than a few in-jokes for the cognoscenti. Murder Rooms is riddled with them; vignettes from many of the Holmes stories crop up (adding to the impression that Conan Doyle was merely recording his experiences with Bell). The truth is very different. After Holmes had become famous, Bell would contact Conan Doyle with suggestions for stories, which, the author noted, were 'not very practical'.

There is, incidentally, a real oddity in Murder Rooms, derived from the fact that it's based in Edinburgh rather than London. The atmosphere, themes and even the plot owe as much to the work of the great Robert Louis Stevenson as to Conan Doyle. The fact isn't lost on the producers who litter the script with references to, most obviously, Jekyll and Hyde.

Murder Rooms is unlikely to be the last strand of such a suspect brand of fiction. Ironically, given Shakespeare's flaky record in the accuracy department, it's intriguing to reflect that the success of Shakespeare In Love has probably done as much to validate the genre; it also tells the 'story' of the writer's early life in a form derived from the writer's own output. But how many people are now walking around in the mistaken belief that they are privy to the tortured genesis of Romeo And Juliet?

Ultimately, we have a clever, atmospheric and entertaining piece of work (Richardson is superb), and one might argue that this represents something of a saving grace. In the end, though, one doubts that the great Sherlock Holmes, a celebrated champion of truth, could possibly have approved of something that depends so heavily on deception.

webTitle: The old ones are the best

fields.headline: The old ones are the best
fields.trailText: Charles Sturridge's Longitude sailed triumphantly home on Channel 4, rounding off one of the most satisfying new dramas the channel has produced in years. This must partly be due to the presence of Michael Gambon and Jeremy Irons, better than whom TV doesn't really get, elegantly sidestepping the rule that equates acting with shouting, and turning in a brace of performances as nicely balanced as one of John Harrison's clocks.
fields.body:
Charles Sturridge's Longitude sailed triumphantly home on Channel 4, rounding off one of the most satisfying new dramas the channel has produced in years. This must partly be due to the presence of Michael Gambon and Jeremy Irons, better than whom TV doesn't really get, elegantly sidestepping the rule that equates acting with shouting, and turning in a brace of performances as nicely balanced as one of John Harrison's clocks.

But this wasn't just actors' television; for once, the script, the design, the whole conception of the drama aimed high and managed to be simultaneously thrilling and mentally engaging. The Board of Longitude, like a bunch of television executives in 18th-century full-bottomed wigs, squirmed and prevaricated every time the divinely gifted Harrison presented new evidence of his scientific success. "But according to our focus groups", one can almost hear them saying, "audiences won't understand this kind of thing at all".

Highlights came thick and fast: Rupert Gould (Irons) mentally disintegrating in the 1930s while John Harrison (Gambon) was forced by a sceptical board to dismantle his precious clock; Harrison Junior (Ian Hart) trudging around the paradisiac West Indies in a tricorn straw hat; Brian Cox as Lord Morton embodying every blinkered old bugger who ever tried to strangle an original idea at birth. Only in one respect did the drama falter - in writer/director Sturridge's simplified equation that the "goodies" must all be blunt and northern (Harrison Junior inexplicably maintained a Yorkshire accent despite living in London since infancy) while the "baddies" were all rich southern ponces in wigs.

That aside, Longitude unfolded like the best-crafted fiction, cunningly drawing parallels between its two time-zones, between Harrison's quest for vindication and Gould's troubled search for mental peace. It's hard to believe that Sturridge, and Dava Sobel, on whose book the piece was based, could stumble upon such a satisfying story hidden away in history. The final shot, pulling back from the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich to reveal the Millennium Dome squatting on the horizon, was a coup de thtre.

ITV's Bank Holiday offering Forgive And Forget was a mixed blessing, a drama with its heart firmly in the right place but undermined by some drastic dips in plausibility. Handsome young plasterer David (Steve John Shepherd) lived at home with his folks and cherished a sexless devotion to his best friend Theo (John Simm), a mature student and general slacker. The serpent entered Eden in the shape of Hannah (Laura Fraser), who, like all love interests in this kind of thing, was a photographer living in a groovy east London loft. Poor David, baffled by his jealousy, fled to Soho and picked up a young man who looked not unlike his beloved. For David, despite the fact that he outbutched everything on the screen, was gay.

Thenceforth the tale unfolded with its own kind of logic: David scuppered Theo's relationship, then came out on live television, was chucked out by his family and beaten half to death with a scaffolding pole by his former friend. Writer Mark Burt's laudable intention was obviously to show that gay men and straight men differ only in their desires, that they can/should be men first and foremost. This just doesn't ring true. That David should have reached his mid twenties - growing up in London, mind - without having made a few gay friends isn't likely, nor is Theo's sudden lapse into homicidal homophobia.

David's inarticulate masculinity pointed at his ordinary blokishness, but let's face it, how many quiet, brooding gay men have you met? The choice of soundtrack - mostly Paul Weller and the Lighthouse Family - only emphasised the utter lack of gayness in David's character. Perhaps if his dawning self-realisation had been accompanied by a growing taste for Madonna, he might have come to life more convincingly. For all that, Forgive And Forget was affecting and involving, and entirely redeemed by an audacious homage to the potter's wheel scene in Ghost, with Shepherd and Simm in the Swayze/Moore roles, the clay replaced by rendering plaster. Unchained Melody did not break forth, but the slow-motion spurts of water erased any doubts about the scene's latent eroticism. A shame that David, like many a gay protagonist before him, was left outcast and bleeding at the end of the show.

fields.headline: Shaike Weinberg
fields.standfirst: Inventive spirit behind landmark museums of Jewish history from Washington to Jerusalem
fields.trailText: 'I am Weimar,' said Shaike Weinberg, who has died aged 81, 'a little adulterated by the Middle East'. In that typically succinct formulation, he condensed the arc of a productive and many-sided life.
fields.body:
'I am Weimar,' said Shaike Weinberg, who has died aged 81, 'a little adulterated by the Middle East'. In that typically succinct formulation, he condensed the arc of a productive and many-sided life.
Born in Warsaw, educated in Weimar Berlin, he carried into the culture of Israel the questioning and cosmopolitan socialism which was one of the best legacies of the emancipation of the Jews in Europe. Whether running a challenging theatre or creating a succession of pioneering museums, his principled inventiveness kept everyone around him honest. Berlin sharpened his wit and shaped his politics; he was very proud of his father's library of first editions of Marx, Lassalle and a collected Heine.
In 1935, he and his family emigrated to Palestine. For 20 years he worked on left-wing kibbutzim. He fought in the Hagana against British rule, then in 1942 became a British army sergeant in the Jewish Brigade. He led his troops - many of whom had lost families in the death camps - from Italy across the Austrian border. With the help of British intelligence, accounts were settled with known Nazi killers.
Shaike's administrative and technical skills were first recognised in 1956 in the office of the Israeli prime minister, where he set up the country's first public computer. In 1961 he was asked by a group of talented actors to lead Tel Aviv's Cameri theatre, which they were forming as a modern alternative to the Habimah theatre.
For 16 years he ran the Cameri, in the stamp of Brecht's Berliner Ensemble and Jean Vilar's Théatre National Populaire, creating a company to stage world classics and encourage new playwrights. One of them, Hanoch Levin, moved from dramas of playful fantasy to angry satire, as a giddy triumphalism succeeded the victories of the 1967 six-day war. Informing through emotion and delight, the result kept its visitors honest about their dispersed ancestors.
It was the pre-eminence of this work in Tel Aviv that led Shaike, after capturing the history of Jerusalem in a museum tucked into the city's ancient walls, to Washington, and the creation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.

The museum should bring to life the historical narrative of an unequalled slaughter, but not become an exclusive memorial. And while being a metaphor for all genocide, it should plant its universality in the specifics of the holocaust.

fields.headline: Sven Berlin
fields.standfirst: Bohemian artist at odds with the avant-garde establishment of St Ives
fields.trailText: Sven Berlin, who has died aged 88, was a dancer, painter, sculptor, poet, and writer of fiction, biography and autobiography. As one of the last great British bohemians, he established a reputation in the conservative environment of postwar St Ives, with his long hair, beard, eccentric dress and earring.
fields.body:
Sven Berlin, who has died aged 88, was a dancer, painter, sculptor, poet, and writer of fiction, biography and autobiography. As one of the last great British bohemians, he established a reputation in the conservative environment of postwar St Ives, with his long hair, beard, eccentric dress and earring.
Sadly, his fame was never matched by his reputation as an artist. Although his name remains familiar within modern British art, his work is not widely known.
Berlin grew up in a conventional suburban household in south London, his name deriving from his Swedish ancestry. During the 1930s, he pursued a successful career as an adagio dancer, partnered by his first wife. In 1938, he committed himself to his first love, painting, taking Henri Gaudier-Brzeska and Van Gogh as models of the artist as outsider.
As a wartime conscientious objector, he worked on the market garden established by the art critic Adrian Stokes in Carbis Bay, outside St Ives. Here he met Ben Nicholson, Barbara Hepworth and the Russian Constructivist Naum Gabo. Berlin, however, remained resolutely humanist and romantic in his conception of art - he was a great admirer of the local, untrained painter Alfred Wallis. When Wallis died in 1942, Berlin published an essay on him in Horizon magazine, and in 1949 produced Alfred Wallis: Primitive, a touchingly personal account of the artist and his work.
Having rejected his stance as a conscientious objector, Berlin joined the D-Day landings, but his experience led to a breakdown and he returned to Cornwall to find restitution through his art and the burgeoning group of younger artists in St Ives. From that time, the redemptive and spiritual power of art and nature would remain his guiding principles. He began to carve, often from the resilient and difficult local granite, but consciously resisted the abstraction of Hepworth.
This was a time of change in St Ives and, with Peter Lanyon, John Wells and Bryan Wynter, Berlin founded the Crypt Group of modern-minded young artists. There were exhibitions in St Ives and London, and in 1948 Patrick Heron generously compared Berlin to Gaudier. He was a founder member of the important Penwith Society in 1949, but soon left in opposition to attempts by Nicholson and Hepworth to turn it into an abstract group. This break, he would later claim, led to his exclusion from the mainstream of British art, and 15 years later, these tensions provided the focus of his fictionalised autobiography, The Dark Monarch.
Berlin and his second wife, Juanita, left Cornwall in 1953 on a horse-drawn wagon, settling in the New Forest, where, at first, they lived as gypsies. In 1970, Berlin moved to the Isle of Wight, and five years later settled near Wimborne, where he remained with his third wife, Julie.
During the 1950s, his work was included in a series of group exhibitions at Tooth's Gallery in London and, in 1960, he was the subject of a film by John Boorman. The 1980s saw a revival of interest in his work in St Ives.
Many of Berlin's publications drew upon personal experience, particularly his account of the war and its aftermath, I Am Lazarus (1961). More recently, he produced two volumes of what he dubbed his 'autosvenography': The Coat Of Many Colours (1994) and Virgo in Exile (1996). His writing displayed the continuity of his thought: rich in imagery and metaphor, it is suffused with his belief in the abstract, in mystical forces that guide both nature and humankind.
Sven was undoubtedly vain, and could be combative. But he was generous in spirit, in his promotion of other forgotten artists and poets, and in his encouragement of younger people like myself. Into his 80s, he still spent the summers carving out-of-doors and, even when that proved too demanding, he did not cease to paint or write.
Despite persistent disappointments, he worked without bitterness and with honesty and integrity.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Roger Bromley, professor of cultural studies, Nottingham Trent University, writes: Gwyn Jones (Obituary, December 21) was charming, elegant and eloquent, but also terrifying when your turn came to 'translate' from the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, and had forgotten to wear your gown.
fields.body: Roger Bromley, professor of cultural studies, Nottingham Trent University, writes: Gwyn Jones (Obituary, December 21) was charming, elegant and eloquent, but also terrifying when your turn came to 'translate' from the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, and had forgotten to wear your gown. In time, we students at Aberystwyth learned to mutter incomprehensibly for a few moments, avoiding all eye contact until, in exasperation, Jones would take up the book to read his own spirited and theatrical version of the text. In the more relaxed atmosphere of the seminar, his wit, warmth and friendliness became more apparent. It was during this time that I was made aware of how valuable an interdisciplinary approach could be. Many years later, in the 1980s, colleagues were surprised to hear me defending the teaching of Anglo-Saxon, at a time when it was becoming increasingly unfashionable. I explained that much of my understanding of cultural studies came from hours spent in a small, stuffy, book-lined room in the old King Street building in Aberystwyth, not daring to enter unless fully prepared and widely read. Gwyn Jones was influential in shaping my early career with advice, references and numerous acts of kindness (including the odd pint in the Boar's Head). Always patrician-looking, sometimes his advice was of a similarly forbidding nature - like having to cover the range of English literature from the earliest times to the contemporary if I ever hoped to get a lecturing post. His high standards and scholarly thoroughness were designed to inspire our ambitions, not his.

webTitle: It's proving a lengthy Good Friday

fields.headline: It's proving a lengthy Good Friday
fields.standfirst:
Mediation in Ireland seems to be best done by avoiding deadlines

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Once again our attention is on the clock. But in Northern Ireland is it a matter of counting down or counting on? General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning, is still trying to mediate a timetable for disarmament. He has already indicated that he was prepared to set out a timetable to put pressure on the paramilitary organisations to dismantle their armouries.
fields.body:
Once again our attention is on the clock. But in Northern Ireland is it a matter of counting down or counting on? General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning, is still trying to mediate a timetable for disarmament. He has already indicated that he was prepared to set out a timetable to put pressure on the paramilitary organisations to dismantle their armouries.

As a mediator, he should pause at this moment in the process and reflect on the recent strategies employed by his two predecessors, Tony Blair and former US Senator George Mitchell.

Since the ceasefire was implemented by paramilitaries on both sides of the sectarian divide in 1996, the peace talks agenda had been narrowed down to two main issues: setting up a representative government and ensuring that violence never again threatens the democratic process.

The first attempt at trying to implement the 1998 Good Friday agreement failed last July because Blair, in the role of `honest broker'', tried to impose time deadlines and force a decision. When he realised that neither party had a 'Plan B' for peace, he fudged the stalemate by asking the parties back to the table in a 'review' two months later. This time, the process concluded with an agreement. But only after it was extended long past its original schedule of 10 days by the tenacity of the mediator, George Mitchell, who was willing to withstand despair as long as the parties did not desert the process.

The hallmark of mediation is that the parties own the solution, it cannot be imposed on them. As Mitchell noted, 'decommissioning has to be a voluntary act'. The parties have to want to cooperate before they can conclude on a verifiable solution.

Few who have been seriously following the peace process over the past 18 months would question the resolve of either Sinn Fein or the Ulster Unionists to finally take the gun out of politics. No one really walked away from the negotiation table as long as the armed struggle was in abeyance. Since both sides had already conceded that a military solution was not possible by either of their paramilitary forces, continuing the dialogue, however long it took, was the only way to find a solution everyone can live with. It was not so much a question of finding a 'Plan B' as of reworking 'Plan A', adding a footnote here and there so that neither side had to decide between the humiliation of defeat and escalation to violence.

Mitchell's control of the agenda as a 'neutral facilitator' became apparent in the final weeks of the talks through the 'stage-managed' public comments of the negotiators on the possible outcome, made before he released the findings of his review. In short, he did not appear to be forcing the issue.

By threatening to resign from the power-sharing government by next month if there is no start to IRA decommission, David Trimble and the Ulster Unionists have unmistakably anchored their opening bargaining position. That was expected of them. But if he gives in to this brinkmanship, or sets a deadline of his own, de Chastelain will compromise his neutrality... and force an outcome that no one is really prepared for.

There is still much creative room for the IRA to demonstrate their ability to lay down their arms. The general's job is to help suggest a way out that all sides can live with. He needs to create the recognition that the solution is not a matter of what can be proven, it is a matter of what can be believed. Perception is reality in this situation because the vast majority of the people of Northern Ireland want to believe that the violence has ended. For them, there is no turning back.

The threat of violence is only real when there is willingness to use it. It can be exercised by anyone at any time, by one bomb or a thousand bombs. The final number of weapons each side holds is no longer important. The US and Russia still hold vast quantities of nuclear weapons, but the threat of their use has all but disappeared. The cold war ended after nearly 50 years without a shot being fired directly at the other side, or one side having to surrender to the other. President John F Kennedy once noted that 'civility is not a sign of weakness, but sincerity is always subject to proof'. In the mediation process, that proof is reserved for the parties, who alone determine when they walk away. When mediators impose time deadlines on negotiations they are in effect making their own positional statement which, even when done with the best of intentions, implies that their priority in the process is their own ability to engineer a successful outcome.

 Samuel Passow is head of research for the Centre for Dispute Resolution

webTitle: Black tide swamps chic French resort

fields.headline: Black tide swamps chic French resort
fields.trailText: Unemployed teenagers from Paris worked alongside politicians and celebrities yesterday as a tide of oil from the sunken tanker Erika washed up on one of France's most idyllic spots, Ile de Ré
fields.body:
Unemployed teenagers from Paris worked alongside politicians and celebrities yesterday as a tide of oil from the sunken tanker Erika washed up on one of France's most idyllic spots, Ile de Ré. Stinking gobs of black sludge pockmarked the beaches of the west coast island, a favourite holiday destination of the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, and many celebrities.

'It's a catastrophe, a horror, a nightmare,' said the author Madeleine Chapsal, a regular summer visitor who returned to help in the clean-up along with a former justice minister, Jacques Toubon, and others. 'Most of us were here to see in the New Year in peace and tranquillity,' she said. 'Instead we witnessed first the massacre of half the island's trees in the storms, and then the monstrous arrival of the first black wave.'

Ile de Ré has become the southernmost point of a 250-mile stretch of France's Atlantic coast to be contaminated with oil from the Maltese tanker, which sank off Brittany on December 12 with 25,000 tonnes of oil on board. Along the coast, thousands of volunteers have joined soldiers, ecologists and other professionals to shovel big, jelly-like black slabs into sacks, and scrub rocks by hand.

More than 18,000 crippled seabirds have been recovered from beaches regularly voted the best in France. Only 15% will survive, said experts at a centre in Lorient that has handled 5,000 in the past week. 'Each one that dies is another little blow,' said Olivier, a soldier spending five days of his New Year holiday at the centre. 'When you have them in your hands, you talk to them. You see these little things fighting. When they're going to die, you see it in their eyes'

The spill is an economic disaster for many resort towns. Hotels have reported mass cancellations, and oystermen have seen orders plummet.

As volunteers return to work, concern is growing about the rest of the Erika's oil. Over 15,000 tonnes is thought still to be in the two halves of the stricken vessel, chartered by the Franco-Belgian oil company TotalFina to carry heavy refined oil from Rotterdam to Leghorn, Italy. An underwater robot monitoring the wreckage jammed on Sunday and stopped relaying images. A second camera should be in place within days, but experts fear any further deterioration in the weather could lead to another big spill. TotalFina's managing director, Thierry Desmarest, has argued that the company is not liable, but last week pledged £4m to help with the clean-up and pump-out of the Erika.
fields.bodyText: Unemployed teenagers from Paris worked alongside politicians and celebrities yesterday as a tide of oil from the sunken tanker Erika washed up on one of France's most idyllic spots, Ile de Ré. Stinking gobs of black sludge pockmarked the beaches of the west coast island, a favourite holiday destination of the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, and many celebrities. 'It's a catastrophe, a horror, a nightmare,' said the author Madeleine Chapsal, a regular summer visitor who returned to help in the clean-up along with a former justice minister, Jacques Toubon, and others. 'Most of us were here to see in the New Year in peace and tranquillity,' she said. 'Instead we witnessed first the massacre of half the island's trees in the storms, and then the monstrous arrival of the first black wave.' Ile de Ré has become the southernmost point of a 250-mile stretch of France's Atlantic coast to be contaminated with oil from the Maltese tanker, which sank off Brittany on December 12 with 25,000 tonnes of oil on board. Along the coast, thousands of volunteers have joined soldiers, ecologists and other professionals to shovel big, jelly-like black slabs into sacks, and scrub rocks by hand. More than 18,000 crippled seabirds have been recovered from beaches regularly voted the best in France. Only 15% will survive, said experts at a centre in Lorient that has handled 5,000 in the past week. 'Each one that dies is another little blow,' said Olivier, a soldier spending five days of his New Year holiday at the centre. 'When you have them in your hands, you talk to them. You see these little things fighting. When they're going to die, you see it in their eyes' The spill is an economic disaster for many resort towns. Hotels have reported mass cancellations, and oystermen have seen orders plummet. As volunteers return to work, concern is growing about the rest of the Erika's oil. Over 15,000 tonnes is thought still to be in the two halves of the stricken vessel, chartered by the Franco-Belgian oil company TotalFina to carry heavy refined oil from Rotterdam to Leghorn, Italy. An underwater robot monitoring the wreckage jammed on Sunday and stopped relaying images. A second camera should be in place within days, but experts fear any further deterioration in the weather could lead to another big spill. TotalFina's managing director, Thierry Desmarest, has argued that the company is not liable, but last week pledged £4m to help with the clean-up and pump-out of the Erika.

webTitle: High turnout in Croatia's first post-Tudjman poll

fields.headline: High turnout in Croatia's first post-Tudjman poll
fields.trailText: Croatia's electorate turned out in large numbers yesterday to vote in the country's general election, amid indications that a centre-left alliance of opposition parties was well placed to end the long rule of the national conservative Croatian Democratic Union
fields.body:
Croatia's electorate turned out in large numbers yesterday to vote in the country's general election, amid indications that a centre-left alliance of opposition parties was well placed to end the long rule of the national conservative Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ).

In the small town of Samobar, about 30 miles west of Zagreb, allegiances appeared to be squarely behind the coalition of Social Democrats and Social Liberals, which has promised to expedite democratic and economic reforms. 'The ruling party has stolen everything from us,' said Jadranka Pfeifer, a sociologist who voted for the HDZ, led by the late president, Franjo Tudjman, at the elections in 1995 and 1997. 'A new period must start now.'

Although snow lightly covered most of the country, warm sunshine encouraged 60% of its 4.2m registered voters to visit the polling stations, according to early reports. 'It's a contest between generations and classes,' said Vanja Rebic, a 29-year-old medical student, after he cast his ballot in Zagreb. 'The elderly and rural population are more inclined to keep the status quo, the young and urban population are prone to change.'

Fifty-five parties are running for about 150 parliament seats in the sabor, Croatia's lower house of parliament. The exact number of seats will depend on the size of the expatriate turnout, which began in earnest on Sunday, in 47 countries outside Croatia.

A key issue in the election has been the economy. Unemployment is over 20% and the average wage is £260 a month in a country where the prices of basic goods are similar to those in Britain. In Samobar, the glass and cement factories have both been closed and half-hearted attempts to privatise them have concentrated economic power in the hands of the businessmen who are close to the ruling party.

The election was also seen as a quiet, but significant, milestone for the members of Croatia's slowly returning Serbian community. Before independence, they represented 12% of the population, but 100,000 still live in exile in Yugoslavia or in Bosnia. Milorad Pupovac, a moderate Serb and an MP, believes many more will return if the opposition wins. 'Everyone in the country expects that a new government would be better for all citizens of Croatia, including those of the Serb minority,' he said.

At least as important as this election for the future of Croatia is the presidential election, which is due in three weeks' time. The opposition has pledged to try to change the constitution to transfer some of the vast presidential powers to parliament. But unless it wins both two thirds of the parliamentary seats and the presidential race, radical reforms such as those will be difficult for it to achieve.
