webTitle: Race row as police beat up comedian

fields.headline: Race row as police beat up comedian
fields.trailText: A hugely popular young French comedian and television presenter of Moroccan origin was recovering in hospital yesterday after allegedly being beaten unconscious by police late on New Year's Day.
fields.body:
A hugely popular young French comedian and television presenter of Moroccan origin was recovering in hospital yesterday after allegedly being beaten unconscious by police late on New Year's Day. The incident is bound to increase tensions between France's notoriously heavy-handed police, who have been found guilty of brutality and even torture in recent European court rulings, and the country's large north African community.

The anti-racist group SOS-Racisme lost no time in condemning a 'revolting act that reveals the shameful practices of police officers who clearly believe themselves above the law'. The group said the police 'had it in for an Arab who has managed to succeed'. Jamel Debbouze, aged 23, the hero of a generation of young immigrants for his rise to stardom from a depressed council estate north of Paris, had just completed a sell-out run of one-man shows and was on his way home.

A police source said that Mr Debbouze, driving a Mercedes carrying his brother Karim and his assistant, Nadia Mourine, had ignored a traffic policeman's instructions to steer clear of a convoy of heavy transporters carrying Paris's millennium ferris wheels from the Champs Élysées. 'He was driving fast and dangerously,' the source said. 'He was asked for his papers while the car was stopped at a red light, and refused. Things seem to have got heated when he was told to get out of the car.'

Ms Mourine said the policemen had ordered Mr Debbouze to drive through a red light, and had then dragged him out of the car violently when he replied: 'You should ask a little more politely.'

'The cop opened the door and dragged Jamel out, threw him out. He slammed him against the car three times,' she said. 'Then there was a crowd of traffic cops around him, one hit him on the neck with a walkie-talkie and another in the stomach with a truncheon. Jamel fainted, he just fell to the ground.' Police investigators questioned the officers involved and are today expected to interview Mr Debbouze - who has yet to file a complaint.

fields.headline: Topless Mussolini excites Italy's fascists
fields.trailText: A rightwing Italian politician has sparked uproar by producing a calendar of Benito Mussolini to mark year 78 of the fascist era
fields.body:
A rightwing Italian politician has sparked uproar by producing a calendar of Benito Mussolini to mark year 78 of the fascist era. Concerned that memories of his hero might fade in the third millennium, Mario De Cristofaro has commissioned a publishing house to make 2,000 calendars, distributed free, 'so that the young would not forget and the old would remember' the dictator.

The 12 pictures of the duce show Mussolini as a baby, on his wedding day, marching on Rome, saluting, smiling, scowling and gathering the harvest, when he appears topless. Each month is adorned with slogans from 1922, when the fascists gained power.

Mr De Cristofaro, a Puglia regional commissioner for the National Alliance, has delighted some members and mortified others who have tried for years to distance their party from its fascist legacy.

The newspaper Quotidiano di Lecce called for Mr De Cristofaro to be prosecuted, while the mayor of Lecce, Adriana Poli Bortone, dismissed him as an eccentric.

Gianfranco Fini, leader of the National Alliance, yesterday did not comment on an embarrassment which undermined his efforts, such as visiting Auschwitz, to shunt his party to the centre. Mr Fini craves the respectability which could help his party eclipse Silvio Berlusconi's Forza Italia as the largest member of the opposition rightwing coalition.

The National Alliance is a direct descendant, via the post-war Italian Social Movement, of Mussolini's party. Shunned by other parties for almost five decades, it has since 1994 won support from poverty-stricken southern regions such as Puglia, in the heel of the boot of Italy.

webTitle: A new horizon fro Dr Ho's palace

fields.headline: A new horizon fro Dr Ho's palace
fields.trailText: The Jumbo Palace floating restaurant moors in Manila bay, part of casino tycoon Stanley Ho's grand strategy to capture the gambling market in the Philippines.
fields.body:
The Jumbo Palace floating restaurant moors in Manila bay, part of casino tycoon Stanley Ho's grand strategy to capture the gambling market in the Philippines.

One floor of the garish four-storey structure, previously a tourist attraction in Hong Kong, will become a floating casino.

Dr Ho, Macau's gaming magnate for more than 35 years and a vigorous 76-year-old who has just fathered another child, plans to take advantage of the liberal gambling laws in the Philippines. His operations will target the 'high rollers' who can easily risk - and lose - thousands of dollars at the tables.

Church leaders have denounced the arrival of the palace but Dr Ho has the backing of President Joseph Estrada, who hopes it will attract more foreign visitors to the country.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Fatal fallout of hijack drama
At least 18 people died in violence across Kashmir yesterday as tension between India and Pakistan mounted in the wake of last week's hijack drama.
A landmine, intended for security vehicles, ripped through a vegetable market in Srinagar in Indian-ruled Kashmir, killing 15 people and wounding about 25. On the Pakistani side of Kashmir, in Muzaffarabad, Indian mortars killed at least three people and injured seven.
Reuters, New Delhi

Fatal fallout of hijack drama
At least 18 people died in violence across Kashmir yesterday as tension between India and Pakistan mounted in the wake of last week's hijack drama.
A landmine, intended for security vehicles, ripped through a vegetable market in Srinagar in Indian-ruled Kashmir, killing 15 people and wounding about 25. On the Pakistani side of Kashmir, in Muzaffarabad, Indian mortars killed at least three people and injured seven.
Reuters, New Delhi

Floods force out slum dwellers
Venezuelan authorities forced hundreds of people to leave their homes in slum settlements of Caracas yesterday, warning that more lives could be lost in landslides caused by continued heavy rains.
Up to 50,000 people were killed and about 400,000 made homeless last month when flash floods and mudslides struck the Caribbean coast.
Reuters, Caracas

Religious clashes in Egypt
Gunbattles between Muslim and Coptic Christian villagers in Egypt killed 20 people and wounded 33, the Egyptian interior ministry said yesterday.
But a Coptic human rights activist said the death toll had risen to 27 after five people died in hospital from injuries and two were killed in their homes. The battles flared in al-Kosheh, 250 miles south of Cairo.
Reuters, Cairo

Refugees sent back to Haiti
The US coast guard is shipping more than 400 refugees back to Haiti amid protests from community activists and Miami's mayor, Alex Penelas.
All but four of the 411 migrants who arrived during New Year's Day on a boat were headed back to Haiti yesterday. Four Haitian women - three of them pregnant - were brought ashore for medical reasons, but were expected to be returned later.
AP, Miami

Israeli inquiry into Weizman
Israel has begun an inquiry into allegations that the president, Ezer Weizman, accepted more than $450,000 from a French Jewish millionaire while Mr Weizman was an MP.
Mr Weizman has confirmed receiving substantial sums of money from his long-time friend, Eduoard Seroussi, but his office insists that the donations fell within the law.
Reuters, Jerusalem

Police search for ETA bomb
Spanish police arrested three suspected members of the Basque guerrilla group ETA yesterday, and were reported to be searching for a possible car bomb in the northern city Bilbao. Spain's national police - on alert since ETA announced the end of a ceasefire a month ago - also raided a flat in Bilbao that contained weapons and explosives, according to state radio.
Reuters, Madrid

Neo-Nazi attack in Sweden
Swedish police were questioning up to 50 witnesses yesterday about the murder of a 19-year-old man of Turkish origin, believed to be the latest victim in a wave of neo-Nazi crimes in Sweden. Three men will appear in court today in connection with the killing.
Reuters, Stockholm

Ousted leader arrives in Paris
The former Ivory Coast president, Henri Konan Bedie, arrived in Paris yesterday from Togo, his base since being ousted by a military coup on December 24.
A French foreign ministry spokesman said Mr Bedie, his family, and three ministers who had followed him to Togo had been issued with French visas on Sunday.
Reuters, Paris

Anarchists bomb Athens
A firebomb yesterday seriously damaged a Jordanian embassy car and two other vehicles, but a bomb planted outside a Greek bank failed to explode, Athens police said.
A group calling itself Anarchist Faction for Subversion claimed responsibility, saying it was in support of suspected terrorist Avraam Lesperoglou, jailed on Christmas Day.
AP, Athens

fields.headline: Basic instincts
fields.standfirst: Take 36 people (14 single adults among them), ship them out to an uninhabited, Hebridean island, film them for a year, and what do you get? A 'unique social experiment' (so says the BBC), or another docusoap with sex, a good bust-up and a strong weather twist? Sally Weale meets two of the castaways
fields.trailText: Take 36 people (14 single adults among them), ship them out to an uninhabited, Hebridean island, film them for a year, and what do you get? A 'unique social experiment' (so says the BBC), or another docusoap with sex, a good bust-up and a strong weather twist? Sally Weale meets two of the castaways
fields.body:
If you were to find yourself stranded on a remote, uninhabited Hebridean island, lashed by icy Atlantic seas and battered by storm-force gales, Peter Jowers is exactly the sort of companion you might hope to stumble across at the other end of the beach.

Tall, bearded, capable, with a Robinson Crusoe-style golden earring, he seems like a man who would thrive in the sort of conditions that would leave most of us floundering. He looks more like a castaway than Oliver Reed ever did, even in the mundane surroundings of Gloucester station where we arrange to meet. But whether he will make entertaining, popular television is another matter - he's more Open University than Changing Rooms.

Jowers and his wife Sheila are among a group of 36 men, women and children whom the BBC has shipped out to the deserted Scottish island of Taransay for a year to take part in Castaway 2000 - a television series which can be seen either as 'a unique, social experiment', as the BBC describes it, or the latest in a long line of fly-on-the-wall 'docusoaps' with a strong weather twist, depending on your point of view.

Last week, while the rest of us were lying low, recovering from Christmas and making final plans for millennium celebrations, the fledgling islanders arrived at their new home, welcomed by winds of 140mph which blew off the roof of one of the sleeping quarters. Jowers, I imagine, leapt unthinkingly to the rescue, organising alternative arrangements and fixing the damage. After months of intensive interviews, tests and survival exercises, the TV production team thinks Jowers could become the father figure in the community, pivotal to its survival. After a couple of hours with him, I think they're probably right.

Until last week, the Jowers lived an industrious, slightly alternative, Good Life existence in the Gloucestershire village of Westbury-on-Severn. Sheila, 51, quietly spoken and darkly pretty, worked as a teacher in art and design at the Royal Forest of Dean College; Peter, 52, was employed in the school of politics at the University of Western England, specialising in development, environmental policy, ecology and sustainable futures.

They lived with three other families in Adsett Court, a beautiful 16-acre estate not far from the banks of the River Severn which they bought collectively in the 70s; they grew their own vegetables, kept chickens and converted their home from the outbuildings surrounding the gracious main house. Together they ran a local arts organisation and festival. Their three daughters, Mehalah, 23, Jessie, 21 and Henrietta, 19, had all left home to go to university, and they were beginning to consider starting a new adventure together.

'I was thinking of buying a hill farm,' says Peter, who grew up on a smallholding on the Island of Mersea in Essex. 'I want to spend my last 25 years on a hill looking at sheep and planting hedges.'

Then, last February, they noticed a small article about an opportunity to spend a year on a deserted Hebridean island. 'I thought, God that sounds wonderful,' says Sheila. They wrote a letter and barely gave it another thought, then in June she received a call inviting them to attend interviews at a Bristol hotel. There was psychological and psychometric testing, and a week of survival exercises in the Welsh mountains, orienteering, white water rafting and killing chickens for supper (not unlike the Jowers' family camping holidays, according to Peter). Then came confirmation that they were among those selected to take part in the experiment. They were delighted, but Peter was unsurprised.

'I always felt we would. We had gone with a suck-it-and-see attitude,' says Peter, whose self-confidence could put a few noses out of joint on the island. 'Because of the life I've led there was nothing that seemed difficult at all. I enjoyed it very much. I think it gave us both a great deal of confidence. It made us realise we have some skills, that we could cope with different situations.'

But what makes anyone want to give up a year of their lives to spend it with strangers on an overgrazed island without trees, abandoned by its own inhabitants 30 years ago? (Even the puffins have disappeared, killed by mink which escaped from neighbouring Harris.) 'What appealed to me was to be somewhere totally different and to be in touch with the elements,' says Sheila. 'Other people are amazed that anyone should want to go and spend time in a windswept wet place, but I love the idea of the changing light and the wind and the sky. To get to know it in depth, the darkness, no roads, no cars.

'I was very excited and pleased [to be chosen], but that night I suddenly had doubts. How can I really walk out for a year - from my family, from the children?' Each member of the community is allowed only two visitors on one weekend for the whole year; there are no telephones, no email - only letters every two weeks and a VHF radio for emergencies. The next morning she told Henrietta, their youngest, she had decided she couldn't do it. Her daughters persuaded her to go but she's still worried that her eldest girl, who has fallen in love, will get married while she's away. 'We've forbidden them to do anything drastic.'

Peter's key worry is how the group will get on. There's already been tension and disagreement between them - and that's before they even set foot on Scottish soil. (Jowers, it turns out, intervened and managed with some skill to resolve the dispute.) 'My experience of 36 people is that we will have to resolve some conflicts. There's bound to be romance (there are seven single men and seven single women among the group), but I think it will be problematical. It will be very intense. Anything could happen on that front.'

The Jowers have other reservations too - they don't mind killing chickens, digging compost toilets and withstanding 140mph winds, but they are concerned how it will all be interpreted in a television series. They don't watch TV themselves, but having applied to take part in the project, they made a point of watching an episode of Paddington Green, which is made by the same production company, Lion Television.

'The first question we asked was, 'Are we just puppets on the editing floor?'' says Peter. The producers managed to reassure them - but no matter how worthy the production company's intentions, it seems obvious that a good bust-up, a nervous breakdown or an illicit relationship make 'better telly' than a harmonious, successful sociological experiment.

Executive producer Jeremy Mills rejects any suggestion that the project is little more than a bigger and better docusoap in the tradition of Hotel, Paddington Green, Airport and Children's Hospital, all of which he has been involved with. 'What is a docusoap? It has become a pejorative term to encompass a whole range of documentaries,' he says. 'The only common thing is you take a number of people and you follow their stories over a number of weeks. Castaway 2000 is a completely different project altogether.'

He argues it is less entertainment than a scientific experiment, (though there must be a pretty sizeable entertainment factor to justify the £2m-plus budget). The first four films, Mills says, bear no resemblance to a docusoap - they cover the selection process showing viewers how and why the panel of experts, including the likes of Lucy Irvine, herself a former castaway, former SAS survival expert Lofty Wiseman and psychologist Cynthia McVey, chose those taking part in the project. (Importantly, although the television producers were allowed a vote on who would go and who wouldn't, it was ultimately the experts' decision.)

But what about the larger-than-life characters that usually steal the show? Who's going to be Taransay's answer to Maureen from Driving School? 'The one thing we did say in this whole thing was that we would not go for extremes,' says Mills. 'It would be very easy and cheap quick-fix entertainment to have a couple of larger than life figures but we didn't want to do that. These days you can turn up in a street, shout 'we want someone to be filmed' and you will get people coming out of their doors to take part. But they are usually the wrong people. We've gone for people in the middle range. Three of the most interesting people on the island are people who did not want to be filmed.'

Peter and Sheila Jowers are nothing like the normal docusoap fodder. They are interesting people who are genuinely interested in creating an alternative community for the 21st century, rather than enjoying 15 minutes of fame. Who knows, it might even make interesting television.

 The first of four Castaway 2000 programmes is due to be broadcast January 18 on BBC1 at 9.30pm. A second series showing a record of the year will be shown in January 2001.
fields.bodyText: If you were to find yourself stranded on a remote, uninhabited Hebridean island, lashed by icy Atlantic seas and battered by storm-force gales, Peter Jowers is exactly the sort of companion you might hope to stumble across at the other end of the beach. Tall, bearded, capable, with a Robinson Crusoe-style golden earring, he seems like a man who would thrive in the sort of conditions that would leave most of us floundering. He looks more like a castaway than Oliver Reed ever did, even in the mundane surroundings of Gloucester station where we arrange to meet. But whether he will make entertaining, popular television is another matter - he's more Open University than Changing Rooms. Jowers and his wife Sheila are among a group of 36 men, women and children whom the BBC has shipped out to the deserted Scottish island of Taransay for a year to take part in Castaway 2000 - a television series which can be seen either as 'a unique, social experiment', as the BBC describes it, or the latest in a long line of fly-on-the-wall 'docusoaps' with a strong weather twist, depending on your point of view. Last week, while the rest of us were lying low, recovering from Christmas and making final plans for millennium celebrations, the fledgling islanders arrived at their new home, welcomed by winds of 140mph which blew off the roof of one of the sleeping quarters. Jowers, I imagine, leapt unthinkingly to the rescue, organising alternative arrangements and fixing the damage. After months of intensive interviews, tests and survival exercises, the TV production team thinks Jowers could become the father figure in the community, pivotal to its survival. After a couple of hours with him, I think they're probably right. Until last week, the Jowers lived an industrious, slightly alternative, Good Life existence in the Gloucestershire village of Westbury-on-Severn. Sheila, 51, quietly spoken and darkly pretty, worked as a teacher in art and design at the Royal Forest of Dean College; Peter, 52, was employed in the school of politics at the University of Western England, specialising in development, environmental policy, ecology and sustainable futures. They lived with three other families in Adsett Court, a beautiful 16-acre estate not far from the banks of the River Severn which they bought collectively in the 70s; they grew their own vegetables, kept chickens and converted their home from the outbuildings surrounding the gracious main house. Together they ran a local arts organisation and festival. Their three daughters, Mehalah, 23, Jessie, 21 and Henrietta, 19, had all left home to go to university, and they were beginning to consider starting a new adventure together. 'I was thinking of buying a hill farm,' says Peter, who grew up on a smallholding on the Island of Mersea in Essex. 'I want to spend my last 25 years on a hill looking at sheep and planting hedges.' Then, last February, they noticed a small article about an opportunity to spend a year on a deserted Hebridean island. 'I thought, God that sounds wonderful,' says Sheila. They wrote a letter and barely gave it another thought, then in June she received a call inviting them to attend interviews at a Bristol hotel. There was psychological and psychometric testing, and a week of survival exercises in the Welsh mountains, orienteering, white water rafting and killing chickens for supper (not unlike the Jowers' family camping holidays, according to Peter). Then came confirmation that they were among those selected to take part in the experiment. They were delighted, but Peter was unsurprised. 'I always felt we would. We had gone with a suck-it-and-see attitude,' says Peter, whose self-confidence could put a few noses out of joint on the island. 'Because of the life I've led there was nothing that seemed difficult at all. I enjoyed it very much. I think it gave us both a great deal of confidence. It made us realise we have some skills, that we could cope with different situations.' But what makes anyone want to give up a year of their lives to spend it with strangers on an overgrazed island without trees, abandoned by its own inhabitants 30 years ago? (Even the puffins have disappeared, killed by mink which escaped from neighbouring Harris.) 'What appealed to me was to be somewhere totally different and to be in touch with the elements,' says Sheila. 'Other people are amazed that anyone should want to go and spend time in a windswept wet place, but I love the idea of the changing light and the wind and the sky. To get to know it in depth, the darkness, no roads, no cars. 'I was very excited and pleased [to be chosen], but that night I suddenly had doubts. How can I really walk out for a year - from my family, from the children?' Each member of the community is allowed only two visitors on one weekend for the whole year; there are no telephones, no email - only letters every two weeks and a VHF radio for emergencies. The next morning she told Henrietta, their youngest, she had decided she couldn't do it. Her daughters persuaded her to go but she's still worried that her eldest girl, who has fallen in love, will get married while she's away. 'We've forbidden them to do anything drastic.' Peter's key worry is how the group will get on. There's already been tension and disagreement between them - and that's before they even set foot on Scottish soil. (Jowers, it turns out, intervened and managed with some skill to resolve the dispute.) 'My experience of 36 people is that we will have to resolve some conflicts. There's bound to be romance (there are seven single men and seven single women among the group), but I think it will be problematical. It will be very intense. Anything could happen on that front.' The Jowers have other reservations too - they don't mind killing chickens, digging compost toilets and withstanding 140mph winds, but they are concerned how it will all be interpreted in a television series. They don't watch TV themselves, but having applied to take part in the project, they made a point of watching an episode of Paddington Green, which is made by the same production company, Lion Television. 'The first question we asked was, 'Are we just puppets on the editing floor?'' says Peter. The producers managed to reassure them - but no matter how worthy the production company's intentions, it seems obvious that a good bust-up, a nervous breakdown or an illicit relationship make 'better telly' than a harmonious, successful sociological experiment. Executive producer Jeremy Mills rejects any suggestion that the project is little more than a bigger and better docusoap in the tradition of Hotel, Paddington Green, Airport and Children's Hospital, all of which he has been involved with. 'What is a docusoap? It has become a pejorative term to encompass a whole range of documentaries,' he says. 'The only common thing is you take a number of people and you follow their stories over a number of weeks. Castaway 2000 is a completely different project altogether.' He argues it is less entertainment than a scientific experiment, (though there must be a pretty sizeable entertainment factor to justify the £2m-plus budget). The first four films, Mills says, bear no resemblance to a docusoap - they cover the selection process showing viewers how and why the panel of experts, including the likes of Lucy Irvine, herself a former castaway, former SAS survival expert Lofty Wiseman and psychologist Cynthia McVey, chose those taking part in the project. (Importantly, although the television producers were allowed a vote on who would go and who wouldn't, it was ultimately the experts' decision.) But what about the larger-than-life characters that usually steal the show? Who's going to be Taransay's answer to Maureen from Driving School? 'The one thing we did say in this whole thing was that we would not go for extremes,' says Mills. 'It would be very easy and cheap quick-fix entertainment to have a couple of larger than life figures but we didn't want to do that. These days you can turn up in a street, shout 'we want someone to be filmed' and you will get people coming out of their doors to take part. But they are usually the wrong people. We've gone for people in the middle range. Three of the most interesting people on the island are people who did not want to be filmed.' Peter and Sheila Jowers are nothing like the normal docusoap fodder. They are interesting people who are genuinely interested in creating an alternative community for the 21st century, rather than enjoying 15 minutes of fame. Who knows, it might even make interesting television.  The first of four Castaway 2000 programmes is due to be broadcast January 18 on BBC1 at 9.30pm. A second series showing a record of the year will be shown in January 2001.

fields.headline: Charity begins in Costa Rica
fields.standfirst: 'Hang on! You're having the holiday of a lifetime at my expense...' John Cunningham on the problem of sponsored trips for good causes
fields.trailText: 'Hang on! You're having the holiday of a lifetime at my expense...' John Cunningham on the problem of sponsored trips for good causes
fields.body:
New century, new challenge. Trek through the Amazon rainforest, go white-water rafting on the Zambezi - or is horse-riding in Mongolia more your thing? Or perhaps an encounter with the 'real' Cuba the lazy tourists never see - on a bike?

No wonder offbeat 'challenges', arduous and expensive though they are, have claimed the smart holiday slot. They offer a unique feel-good factor: apart from a registration fee of around £200, they're free - if you can persuade friends and colleagues to sign up for a sponsorship package of at least £2,500. Two thirds of this goes to charity; the rest pays for your trip. With your new year resolution to adopt a less indulgent lifestyle wavering in the face of the January sales, there's never been a cannier moment for charities to pitch their fundraising holidays.

Numbed by winter desolation, thousands of us will be sending off for brochures, offering adventures which cunningly mix altruism with exoticism. Packed with jazzy photos, cool prose and 24-hour enquiry hotlines, these brochures are as seductive as those of the big tour operators - except that the word 'holiday' is taboo.

Though the number of trips is limited, exclusive destinations are added every year: the Inca trail in Peru has to be next summer's plum choice. Your friends and workmates will be anything but bored with your anecdotes and snaps - and impressed that you've raised at least £1,500 for one of the 40 or so charities that run sponsored events.

Indeed, the brochures are almost too successful: it's the lure of faraway places, the chance of moving through picturesque landscapes, meeting remote tribes and seeing ecological rarities that attracts customers. 'I don't think people who do this sort of thing are driven by a particular cause. The charity is secondary to the challenge,' says John Scourse of Guide Dogs for the Blind.

Even so, in the post-trip euphoria, only a curmudgeonly colleague would dare to mutter that while you have indeed raised an impressive amount for a good cause, you've managed to get a 10-day freebie out of it - funded by sponsors who might not have been so generous had they realised this was part of the deal.

Challenge holidays were the charity world's big idea of the 90s, and chimed brilliantly with the mood of the decade: don't feel guilty about a form of fundraising that's got a built-in bonus for the participants, who work hard to raise the cash and commit themselves to weeks of fitness training for the journey.

But there are growing concerns that it's not always made clear to backers that only two thirds of the money goes to a good cause. It's even less in some cases: Mencap will get just over half of the proceeds of a cycle ride in Costa Rica this year. Airfares, hotels, food, guides and assistance for the cyclists will absorb an alarming 45% of the money raised. Mencap's Sarah Joseph says it's the first time they've been to Costa Rica, and setting up a new destination is costly. Even so, she agrees they've reached the limit with 45%.

The Institute of Charity Fund Managers is so worried about challenges that it is drafting a code of practice to allay public misgivings about an idea that's brought a cash bonanza to many less well-known causes, and attracted younger volunteers to organisations that depend on declining numbers of mostly ageing helpers.

Ironically, the code will be launched just as some charities are forecasting that the popularity of challenge trips will peak in the next year or two. 'There is a need for a code, so that nobody can be under any illusion about how a trip is financed,' says Janet South, who chairs the working party compiling the guidelines. Though most organisations tell participants to spell out how the scheme works to their sponsors, 'there is a chance of a donor saying to a participant, 'Hang on. You're having the holiday of a lifetime at my expense.''

The code will also advise charity officials, who insist that they need groups of 80 or 100 to make a sufficient profit, to consider the damage big numbers could cause in environmentally sensitive areas. It will also suggest that charities should pay for projects to help local people, so they're giving something back to the third world destinations they use.

Many blameless charities already do all of this, but to forestall criticism are keen to explain themselves. After all, they have a lot to lose. Take Sense, the National Deafblind and Rubella Association. The chances are you haven't heard of it, as Stephen Bromberg, head of communications, admits. There are about 23,000 cases of this double disability in the UK. Because this is a relatively low number, says Bromberg, 'We're not a glamorous cause like cancer or homelessness.' Two years ago, Sense decided to join the new wave of fundraising, and started with a trek to Nepal. It was instantly successful. 'So far, we've made close to £1m net profit. That's money we wouldn't normally see.'

No criticisms have been made of Sense, but Bromberg says they have to be totally upfront about what is involved. He's defensive about the effort involved: participants 'are climbing mountains, trekking over heavy terrain. It's not an endurance test, but it's not a holiday either.'

Of course, charities face a dilemma here. If the hike, canoe journey or horseback trek was too arduous, there would be few takers. And if they dwelt on the poverty of rural Vietnam or Morocco rather than the friendliness of villagers, those on challenge trips would feel like guilty intruders. But it is all presented in the context of wonderful scenery and exciting adventure.

Cuba, one of the first big successes, illustrates the difficulty of what happens when a once-exotic destination becomes too popular. 'We became famous for our Cycle Cuba programme in 1998,' says Mark Astira of the National Deaf Children's Society. The charity has taken 700 people there, making a significant net profit of £750,000 in an annual income of £3m. However, challenge-takers form a fickle segment of the travel market: they want to be wooed with new alluring places every season. 'It's revolutionised our organisation, but I don't think there's any more growth in it. We're stuck on about 400 people this year.'

The word is the same from Guide Dogs for the Blind, where John Scourse says: 'We're planning for challenge events to peak in 2001. Our gut feeling is that there's got to be a limit to this one.'

The challenge bubble is under pressure from two sides. South agrees that exotic destinations lose their rarity value when too many charities go there. She also says sponsors will become weary. 'Early on, it's a novelty. But when the same person comes back a second time asking you to be a sponsor; or when the fifth person knocks on your door with the same request...'

Astira completes the picture: 'There's nothing like a charity for murdering a good idea,' he says ruefully. It's a motto the multimillion world of fundraising would do well to remember. So thinking caps on, while the rest of us prepare to put our hands into our pockets - yet again.

fields.trailText: Where's the fire? There isn't one.
fields.body:
Where's the fire? There isn't one.

Gory accident? Nope.

Lurid abduction? If only.

So who is calling the emergency services? People sitting on their mobile phones and inadvertently dialling 999 with their buttocks, it seems.

What? Is this a bad joke? Not when the number of accidental calls has risen to 80,000 per year. The rise in mobile phone usage has unexpectedly clogged up 999 switchboards as people squish their handsets into bags and back pockets.

Haven't these people heard of keypad locks? Apparently not. 'We're beginning to be run a bit ragged,' said Sir Paul Condon, Metropolitan Commissioner, wearily.

Damn, no wonder I can't get through when I want a taxi. That's precisely the kind of flippancy that costs lives. Of the 2m 999 calls received in London per year, the number of 'inappropriate time-wasting' ones among them is rising.

Don't tell me: 'Which emergency service do you require - manicure, pedicure or tarot card reading?' If only it were that plausible. Last year, South Yorkshire Police received 999 calls from a man reporting that two squirrels were fighting in his garden, a woman who was having trouble with her knitting, and a couple who had handcuffed themselves together and lost the key.

Any others? Thames Valley Police received similar calls registering paranormal activity, sightings of Elvis and requests for taxis.

I bet that got the blue sirens wailing. Not likely. The police have begun diverting eccentric callers to a pre-recorded message advising them to get a life - sorry, to ring the station's front desk.

Do say: 'Hurry up, I think there's an intruder downstairs.'

Don't say: 'Do you do pizza delivery?'

Not to be confused with: Tourist information, directory enquiries, the speaking clock, your mum.

fields.headline: The fugitive
fields.standfirst: Ritt Goldstein is the only American in the world seeking political asylum. He fled to Sweden after years of alleged harassment by police. Here he explains how it feels to start his third new year on the run
fields.trailText: Ritt Goldstein is the only American in the world seeking political asylum. He fled to Sweden after years of alleged harassment by police. Here he explains how it feels to start his third new year on the run
fields.body:
Ritt Goldstein was a justice of the peace and a millionaire when in 1995 he became heavily involved in a campaign to reform the US police. He was, he claims, immediately subject to a campaign of police harassment - his home and office were ransacked, his car tampered with, his life threatened. He felt that living in the US was like living in a concentration camp. Finally, in the summer of 1997, he flew to Sweden, where he now lives underground, having run away from a refugee reception area.

My third New Year's Eve underground brings a frozen landscape of iced forests and snow-covered vistas. The sun will occasionally appear, its shimmering, crystalline beauty given an illusion of warmth, but the thermometer dips to minus 35 degrees. It doesn't take long for the cold to bite at your extremities, the air tickling your nose as it freezes any moisture it encounters. Yet harsh as this life may be, it remains infinitely preferable to the life I endured in the States, the life to which I know I would be returned if the Swedish police were to arrest and deport me.

In July 1997, I stood at New York's Kennedy Airport clutching a ticket to Sweden. I called a few friends to make my farewells, thinking this may be the last time I would see my home. As hard as things were in America, it was not easy to say goodbye.

But my life as a refugee had really already begun in my home country after I had organised a police accountability hearing in my home state of Connecticut and my home and offices were destroyed in retaliation. That year, I spent the holidays alone at a hotel, virtually under siege. I found myself increasingly alone.

Those in stronger minority communities have often come together against acts of police abuse - remember the riots that followed the beating of Rodney King? But mainstream America has never mobilised when the target of abuse is someone white and well-off. It is paradoxical that, in a country in which many believe police abuse has reached epidemic proportions, so many victims become increasingly isolated and are treated as lepers.

In the summer of 1997, I began to realise just how isolated I'd become. Life's most simple pleasures - a home, a relaxed meal, companionship, shopping, even a walk in the park - were denied me. Unpredictable daily assaults left me a ghost among the living. My world was steadily being destroyed and there was nothing I could do to stop it.

Those few friends who had stood by me now urged me to flee, for my own safety. Eventually, the realisation that there was no possibility of domestic protection led me to begin the journey I continue today.

At many points, all that had kept me going was the thought that I had to endure, not for myself, but for the same reasons others throughout history have found ways to endure for their country - it was very difficult to leave. On the plane, safe for the first time in recent memory, I made an effort to put the past behind me. I arrived at Stockholm's Arlanda airport knowing no one, but I contacted a local chapter of Amnesty International and the following week met with their Swedish section. With their help, I found legal counsel and became acquainted with the political asylum issues I faced. Then, shortly after my arrival in Sweden, I applied for political asylum. I was informed that many who do so are immediately incarcerated and sent back on the earliest plane, but I was fortunate in that I had masses of evidence of what had happened to me in the States.

While awaiting the outcome of my application, I was assigned a place in the Carlsund refugee camp outside Stockholm. Carlsund is a processing centre for refugees entering the country (I had entered as a tourist). I was later told it was the best of the country's camps. It is made up of low-lying brick buildings, set among greenery and groves of mature trees. That summer, wild flowers grew everywhere and as I watched children playing along the wooded pathways, I reflected that, compared with many of those in America's inner cities, they were lucky.

At Carlsund, organised recreation, a gym, cooked meals and clean facilities were provided. I was assigned to a room in a dormitory called Club. Except for those refugees who were held in a unit called X-House, we were free to come and go as we pleased; many, like me, travelled regularly to Stockholm.

After a few weeks of 'processing', I and many others were transferred to Flenn, a camp where the showers reeked of human waste and conditions can best be described as difficult. Everything that Carlsund was, Flenn was not, although, in all fairness, I did find many of the staff both sensitive and deeply committed.

Most of the other refugees at the camps were from Iraq, Iran, the former Soviet Union, the Balkans, Africa and Afghanistan. I was the only American, of course, and more than a few of both camps' residents were not fond of the States. Many, notably the Afghanis and Iraqis, expressed a belief that they had become little more than pawns in America's political struggles and they harboured deep-felt resentment.

My first days had some interesting moments, but even across the barriers of culture and language, understandings can be reached. In Carlsund and later Flenn, I soon found myself on friendly terms with a number of other refugees. Although my background was very different from their own, we shared a common bond in that we had escaped those who had sought to kill us. We considered ourselves members of a special club. When it appeared that I might be deported, there were those among them who provided a way to contact local activists, affording me a chance to escape the fate my return to the US would mean.

In mid-September of 1997, after preparations had been pursued with the refugee group FARR (the Swedish Network of Asylum and Refugee Groups), I left Flenn and made my way to a pre-arranged location in Stockholm. Officially, I was in the city for a visit; when, days later, my asylum application was rejected, I entered life underground.

I had been given the name and phone number of a young activist who had offered to shelter me. I called him and we arranged to meet at a subway station. Instead I was met by another activist and my circumstances reviewed, in detail, before I was finally allowed to meet my prospective host. Those working in the underground here are careful: they do not like to make mistakes.

In Sweden, for asylum seekers facing deportation, going underground is the only option. Since October 1997, I have been hidden by activists all around the country. What that means is living and travelling with people who only minutes before were strangers, moving regularly to avoid detection and living in the shadows as a virtual fugitive. The Swedish police have an order for my arrest and deportation.

In those first days, I stayed in Stockholm with groups of young activists; I slept on couches and in closets, but I was free. Since then, I have lived in a typical Swedish home, in a dilapidated house in the woods, even in a 50-room castle.

It is surprising how many people I have met here who share a commitment to seeing justice done and who have chosen to help. My hosts have ranged from the young and struggling to comfortably-off, middle-aged professionals. Living as an underground exile, the only reason I am alive today is because of them. As an American, I stand out, so most opportunities for 'off the books' employment are denied me and I exist on the generosity of others. People I have never met but who have become familiar with my circumstances have taken considerable risks and expended more than a little time, effort and money on my behalf. Through the 'little victories' their sacrifices have brought, I am able to continue.

Here in underground exile, one is forced to acknowledge that everything you ever knew and worked for has effectively been stolen from you, even your name - I must live under an assumed one. The press has noted that I was once a self-made millionaire, having built a successful business in addition to a police reform movement, but now, as a non-person in hiding, I have no opportunity to start anew. Having a driver's licence, a bank account or a business all require that a person officially exists - I do not.

He was, he claims, immediately subject to a campaign of police harassment - his home and office were ransacked, his car tampered with, his life threatened. He felt that living in the US was like living in a concentration camp. Finally, in the summer of 1997, he flew to Sweden, where he now lives underground, having run away from a refugee reception area. My third New Year's Eve underground brings a frozen landscape of iced forests and snow-covered vistas. The sun will occasionally appear, its shimmering, crystalline beauty given an illusion of warmth, but the thermometer dips to minus 35 degrees. It doesn't take long for the cold to bite at your extremities, the air tickling your nose as it freezes any moisture it encounters. Yet harsh as this life may be, it remains infinitely preferable to the life I endured in the States, the life to which I know I would be returned if the Swedish police were to arrest and deport me. In July 1997, I stood at New York's Kennedy Airport clutching a ticket to Sweden. I called a few friends to make my farewells, thinking this may be the last time I would see my home. As hard as things were in America, it was not easy to say goodbye. But my life as a refugee had really already begun in my home country after I had organised a police accountability hearing in my home state of Connecticut and my home and offices were destroyed in retaliation. That year, I spent the holidays alone at a hotel, virtually under siege. I found myself increasingly alone. Those in stronger minority communities have often come together against acts of police abuse - remember the riots that followed the beating of Rodney King? But mainstream America has never mobilised when the target of abuse is someone white and well-off. It is paradoxical that, in a country in which many believe police abuse has reached epidemic proportions, so many victims become increasingly isolated and are treated as lepers. In the summer of 1997, I began to realise just how isolated I'd become. Life's most simple pleasures - a home, a relaxed meal, companionship, shopping, even a walk in the park - were denied me. Unpredictable daily assaults left me a ghost among the living. My world was steadily being destroyed and there was nothing I could do to stop it. Those few friends who had stood by me now urged me to flee, for my own safety. Eventually, the realisation that there was no possibility of domestic protection led me to begin the journey I continue today. At many points, all that had kept me going was the thought that I had to endure, not for myself, but for the same reasons others throughout history have found ways to endure for their country - it was very difficult to leave. On the plane, safe for the first time in recent memory, I made an effort to put the past behind me. I arrived at Stockholm's Arlanda airport knowing no one, but I contacted a local chapter of Amnesty International and the following week met with their Swedish section. With their help, I found legal counsel and became acquainted with the political asylum issues I faced. Then, shortly after my arrival in Sweden, I applied for political asylum. I was informed that many who do so are immediately incarcerated and sent back on the earliest plane, but I was fortunate in that I had masses of evidence of what had happened to me in the States. While awaiting the outcome of my application, I was assigned a place in the Carlsund refugee camp outside Stockholm. Carlsund is a processing centre for refugees entering the country (I had entered as a tourist). I was later told it was the best of the country's camps. It is made up of low-lying brick buildings, set among greenery and groves of mature trees. That summer, wild flowers grew everywhere and as I watched children playing along the wooded pathways, I reflected that, compared with many of those in America's inner cities, they were lucky. At Carlsund, organised recreation, a gym, cooked meals and clean facilities were provided. I was assigned to a room in a dormitory called Club. Except for those refugees who were held in a unit called X-House, we were free to come and go as we pleased; many, like me, travelled regularly to Stockholm. After a few weeks of 'processing', I and many others were transferred to Flenn, a camp where the showers reeked of human waste and conditions can best be described as difficult. Everything that Carlsund was, Flenn was not, although, in all fairness, I did find many of the staff both sensitive and deeply committed. Most of the other refugees at the camps were from Iraq, Iran, the former Soviet Union, the Balkans, Africa and Afghanistan. I was the only American, of course, and more than a few of both camps' residents were not fond of the States. Many, notably the Afghanis and Iraqis, expressed a belief that they had become little more than pawns in America's political struggles and they harboured deep-felt resentment. My first days had some interesting moments, but even across the barriers of culture and language, understandings can be reached. In Carlsund and later Flenn, I soon found myself on friendly terms with a number of other refugees. Although my background was very different from their own, we shared a common bond in that we had escaped those who had sought to kill us. We considered ourselves members of a special club. When it appeared that I might be deported, there were those among them who provided a way to contact local activists, affording me a chance to escape the fate my return to the US would mean. In mid-September of 1997, after preparations had been pursued with the refugee group FARR (the Swedish Network of Asylum and Refugee Groups), I left Flenn and made my way to a pre-arranged location in Stockholm. Officially, I was in the city for a visit; when, days later, my asylum application was rejected, I entered life underground. I had been given the name and phone number of a young activist who had offered to shelter me. I called him and we arranged to meet at a subway station. Instead I was met by another activist and my circumstances reviewed, in detail, before I was finally allowed to meet my prospective host. Those working in the underground here are careful: they do not like to make mistakes. In Sweden, for asylum seekers facing deportation, going underground is the only option. Since October 1997, I have been hidden by activists all around the country. What that means is living and travelling with people who only minutes before were strangers, moving regularly to avoid detection and living in the shadows as a virtual fugitive. The Swedish police have an order for my arrest and deportation. In those first days, I stayed in Stockholm with groups of young activists; I slept on couches and in closets, but I was free. Since then, I have lived in a typical Swedish home, in a dilapidated house in the woods, even in a 50-room castle. It is surprising how many people I have met here who share a commitment to seeing justice done and who have chosen to help. My hosts have ranged from the young and struggling to comfortably-off, middle-aged professionals. Living as an underground exile, the only reason I am alive today is because of them. fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Y2K website up for auction
fields.body:
Y2K website up for auction The web address year2000.com, until now a site for information on the Y2K computer bug, has been auctioned by owners who said they hoped to find it 'a good home''. Now the sellers - Peter de Jager, a Canadian consultant, and the Tenagra Corporation, a Houston-based marketing company - are waiting to see if two $10m offers through the eBay online auction are genuine. The price would be a record for a web address, exceeding the more than $7.5m paid for business.com in November. But Cliff Kurtzman, chief executive of Tenagra, said he was not spending the money just yet. 'There have been many incidences of pranks,' he said. 'But we are optimists. We received two bids at $10m, and we think there is a fair chance that one or other is real.'

More firms going bust Business failures hit a five-year high in 1999, and the picture is expected to get worse before it improves, business information group Dun & Bradstreet reports today. Unscrupulous firms are likely to use fictitious problems with the millennium bug as an excuse for delaying payment to cash-starved business, says the group. 'The cheque has been lost in the computer could be as familiar an excuse as the cheque has been lost in the post,' warns D&B senior analyst Philip Mellor. Partly as a result of this, the total number of business collapses is expected to rise during the first half of this year before falling in the second half. During 1999, 43,365 companies went bust or were wound up, a 12% increase on 1998, as the economic slowdown of 18 months ago worked its way through the system. The south east suffered lightly, with a 6.9% increase in failures, while Wales saw an increase of 26.1% and the East Midlands suffered a 24.8% rise. During the last quarter of 1999, the bounceback from the economic slowdown of late 1998 was evident, with the total starting to edge down again, D&B reports.

fields.headline: Hanging tough
fields.standfirst: With shows like Sensation! and Monet in the 20th Century, Norman Rosenthal has revolutionised the Royal Academy. He talks to Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: With shows like Sensation! and Monet in the 20th Century, Norman Rosenthal has revolutionised the Royal Academy. He talks to Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
Backstage at the Royal Academy might make a gripping docu-soap in the tradition of the Royal Opera exposé, The House. And the star would undoubtedly be Norman Rosenthal, exhibitions secretary since 1977, and a bit of a character. When I meet Rosenthal before opening time at Burlington House he sets everything up in the most theatrical way. The press officer can't find him. His secretary says that often before the exhibitions open you'll find him in one of the rooms enjoying the art. And there he is, artfully slumped on a leather couch in front of a wall of Van Dyck portraits.

'I come here every morning and walk around talking to these people,' he says. 'That's my privilege, a fantastic privilege.'

The Royal Academy is a perverse British institution, and Norman Rosenthal is a perverse institutional figure. You can't imagine him anywhere else. The Tate would never have put on Sensation!, the exhibition of Charles Saatchi's collection the Academy mounted in 1997: how could the Tate have allowed Saatchi to stamp himself on history in that way? But Rosenthal had no qualms about importing all this stuff into the sacred halls of Burlington House, and for many Sensation! is the defining exhibition of young British art, not only here but in America. In his office is a framed front page of the New York Post leading with mayor Giuliani's attempt to ban the show last year.

'I was at the opening [at the Brooklyn Museum]. All the glamorous people were there - Hugh Grant' But, he says, no protesters at all. 'I was almost disappointed. The whole thing took place not in real people's experience but in the cliches of politicians and journalists. That's so boring. Art is beyond that.'

This denial of a desire to create a stir is frankly unbelievable. Rosenthal is the epitome of the art curator as showman, an instigator of huge blockbuster exhibitions that make bold statements about contemporary art and art history and address those statements to a broad public. The titles of his exhibitions capture the scale of his ambition. A New Spirit in Painting (1981), British Art in the 20th Century (1987), Zeitgeist and Metropolis (both 1991). Then of course there was the Royal Academy's smash hit of last year, Monet in the 20th Century. The Monet exhibition (which he programmed rather than curated) looked disturbingly like a prophecy of what art will become in the 21st century: less an art exhibition than an anthropology of class and taste in contemporary Britain as it exploded into a must-see event that systematically filtered through as many people as possible.

Rosenthal's shows have helped to define British culture now, making the exhibition a phenomenon, a public ritual. They have prepared the way for the great exhibitions set to dominate cultural life in 2000 - the show at the Dome, the new displays of modern art opening at Tate Modern in May, not to mention huge shows at the Royal Academy beginning with this month's 1900: Art at the Crossroads, a massive survey of the art scene 100 years ago.

Since he became exhibitions secretary more than 20 years ago, Rosenthal has turned the Royal Academy into a venue for event art. Buzz, hype, noise, crowds are what this purportedly posh and staid organisation thrives on. When I bring up Monet, Rosenthal seems almost embarrassed by the show's popularity - 'It is to me a rather marvellous mystery as to why Monet has this status.' But did an exhibition that turned into such a people-moving machine give audiences a chance to be with the art in the silent, contemplative way Monet surely expected? Well, for one viewer there was solitude aplenty. 'For me Monet was a great privilege. Another reason I love to do exhibitions is to be alone with them. You know, I feel like an amazing collector.'

He interrupts the interview to debate with the director of the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambridge, who is enjoying a private view of the Van Dyck, about whether - as Rosenthal believes - the Flemish portraitist was one of the five greatest artists ever. The man from the Fitz says no, not really. Rosenthal comments that he never studied art history formally. He studied history at Leicester University in the 60s but got a summer job at Agnew's, the art dealers, and worked on the catalogue for a Van Dyck show. From that point on he became addicted to art, including contemporary art. 'I don't accept the idea that art is over and past ages were better or worse, because they were just different. I think those who are only involved in contemporary art miss out and those who are only involved with the world of Old Masters miss out.'

Rosenthal's distinctive sensibility also has roots in his background. His parents were German and Czech Jewish immigrants. When he became exhibitions officer at the ICA in 1973 his knowledge of German meant he was sent abroad to programme the German Month. Rosenthal brought over Joseph Beuys, one of the artists he feels most deeply about. He has what he calls a second life in Berlin (as well as a wife and children in Madrid) and has programmed exhibitions in Germany with his friend Christos Joachimides.

The exhibition that made his name and turned the RA from a fusty institution to one of the world's great exhibition spaces was Post-Impressionism in 1979, a highly influential show that popularised revisionist approaches to art history. Post-Impressionism was a label coined by the critic Roger Fry to describe the modern art that came between Impressionism and Picasso. Rosenthal's exhibition deconstructed the idea of this 'movement' by revealing the huge range of art being made in France in the period and showing that it was plural and very complex.

The upcoming 1900: Art at the Crossroads, which he has co-curated with an international team including the art historian Robert Rosenblum, is a similarly deconstructive survey. It displays the massive range of art at the beginning of the modernist era, from the sublime (Cézanne, Picasso, Matisse) to the ridiculous (some amazingly naff salon artists). It may be fascinating, or it may just be exhausting. 'We're trying to demonstrate that at that moment many options were open to the world of art,' says Rosenthal. This desire to illustrate a 'moment' is what he says all his exhibitions do. Not to say one artist is better, one movement more significant, but to 'gather', as he puts it, art's rich history.

The strength of Rosenthal's work as a curator is that it makes art feel important and public and exciting - an event, something everyone has to engage with, or in the case of Sensation!, argue about. A good Royal Academy show is like one imagines a Paris salon in the 19th century to have been: art at the centre of city life. The danger of blockbuster exhibitions is that they might kill the thing they love. If you don't argue for one artist or movement being more important than another, you end up reducing art to a consumer choice. And there's one art for the curator and those lucky enough to attend a private view, another for the people queuing in the rain and paying for a Monet brioche.

'One thing about the Royal Academy is that one is always condemned to be grand,' admits Rosenthal. 'The Royal Academy is a great tribune,' he says in an oddly archaic turn of language, 'and one has to treat it like that. The rooms are so noble and splendid and so grand.' His exhibitions play this up and relish it. Spectacle, scale and sensation are what you get. He's a showman and he feels an empathy with another showman, Damien Hirst, whom he praises for hugely expanding the audience for contemporary art in Britain. This year Rosenthal plans another big contemporary art show, another attempt to define the zeitgeist - from the man who once staged an exhibition called Zeitgeist.

It's time for the Royal Academy to open its doors, and a couple of curious heads peep into Rosenthal's lair. 'The punters are arriving', he says, 'so maybe we should withdraw.'

 1900: Art at the Crossroads runs from January 16 till April 3 at the Royal Academy, Burlington House, Piccadilly, London W1 (0171-300 8000).

fields.headline: Electrolux hit by £18m trading scam
fields.trailText: Rogue trading in foreign currencies has blown a £17m hole in the accounts of Electrolux, the consumer appliances giant, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Rogue trading in foreign currencies has blown a £17m hole in the accounts of Electrolux, the consumer appliances giant, it emerged last night.

The company stunned the Stockholm stock exchange with a statement blaming an employee of its internal banking division for the losses. 'Electrolux has initiated an investigation with the help of its auditors and legal advisers and will take all appropriate legal actions,' the company said.

Unauthorised speculations in foreign currency began on the employee's own initiative early last year, and, as losses mounted, he increased his trading activity while taking action to hide from his superiors what was going on, Electrolux said. The employee worked in Germany, hitherto the base for the group's internal banking activity, managing liquidity, short-term borrowing and the foreign exchange transactions needed to finance German imports.

In the wake of the scandal, Electrolux said it would now centralise all forward-contract trading at its treasury department in Stockholm.

The losses are thought to total about 55m marks, and Electrolux said it was unsure as to the extent of its insurance cover against rogue trading.

While modest in comparison to some of the losses run up by rogue traders such as Nick Leeson of Barings bank (£800m) and Sumitomo's copper dealer Yasuo Hamanaka (£2bn), the affair is likely to shake confidence in Sweden's traditionally well-regulated and smoothly-running industrial and financial machine. It will also raise questions about the efficacy of financial regulation in Germany, which is bidding to be the financial centre for the so-called 'euroland' single-currency bloc.

Last night the company - the world's largest maker of household appliances - was not available for further comment.

fields.headline: My da's a star!
fields.standfirst: Bibi van der Zee discovers an artist in the family
fields.trailText: Bibi van der Zee discovers an artist in the family
fields.body:
I grew up surrounded by etchings by my mysterious grandfather, who had died when my mother was only six. Like my sister, I found them rather gloomy - full of churches and ruins and bridges and all the things that grown-ups seemed to find interesting, instead of clowns and bright colours and dogs.

So it was a tremendous shock to find myself recently at a posh launch party in London's Bond Street, with a book called FL Griggs: The Architecture of Dreams on sale, and all over these walls the same etchings that my mother owned, but with expensive price labels beside them.

As the guests talked about 'a neglected English visionary', 'the upholder of the great English rural tradition', blah blah blah, it slowly dawned on me that my grandfather - 'Da' - must be famous. When one of the curators of the Griggs exhibition now on at the Ashmolean in Oxford told me that a 1974 show of Da's work had been the museum's 'most successful exhibition ever', the realisation was complete.

I don't think I'd ever looked closely at the dark pictures that Da specialised in. His biographer, Jerrold Northrop Moore, says that Griggs should be rated in the same way as Chopin: as a specialist of genius, Chopin's instrument being the piano, and my grandfather's being his etching tools. But Da also specialised in subject, refusing, as far as I can see, to work on anything except landscape, refusing even to acknowledge the existence of colour, and certainly refusing to admit the presence of the modern world. Although the period in which his reputation was at his highest, between the two world wars, was a time of incredible social upheaval, his etchings could have been made in a monastery. There are no motor cars, no factory chimneys, no city bustle: instead he imagined another England, building huge castles and medieval cities from ruins. I can see not a single reference to the 20th century in his entire output.

My mother had told us that he was associated with the arts and crafts tradition: he moved to Chipping Camden at the turn of the century partly because of its association with the movement, and was supported and encouraged throughout his career by Sidney Cockerell, who had been William Morris's secretary.

As children we loved hearing the romantic bits of his life: how he met my grandmother and got engaged after five weeks, and wrote in his diary 'Too great a gift'; how he bankrupted himself buying Dover's Hill near Chipping Camden to preserve it from having a hotel put on it, and then gave the hill to the National Trust; how he further impoverished himself by building a house (New Dover's House) and insisting that every single detail, every stone, every shelf, be perfect in accordance with his love of medieval England.

Seeing his work in the Ashmolean (it is not a very big exhibition, just a corner of the museum) brings home the obsessiveness of his work. He has hatched in the stones and turrets and gargoyles of every building with an attention to detail that could almost be seen as obsessive. But the biography brings home another side of his life: the man I never knew, because my mother had so few memories of him.

His father was a baker, and Da was sacked from his first job as a clerk to a flour miller for 'filling up the ledgers with sketches and caricatures'. There's a terrifying bit on page 58 where he proposes to some woman called Winifred: for a split second visions of parallel universes whirl around my head, where my grandfather married this woman, never met my grandmother, never had my mother and I never existed. Luckily she chucks him a few pages later.

He sounds like an odd man, an interesting man: JB Priestley, a friend, described him as 'a Catholic, a medievalist, a craftsman who would have all men craftsmen, a thorough hater of all things modern.' My mum always talked about the brilliant games he would set up for her and her sisters and brother. My grandmother remained a widow for 50 years after his death. It is odd, 34 years after someone has died, and taken their jokes and crankinesses and preoccupations with them, to suddenly want to meet them. Odder still to find that you like them.

webTitle: The magical feet of ballerina Sarah Wildor

fields.headline: The magical feet of ballerina Sarah Wildor
fields.standfirst: They may look effortlessly graceful on stage, but dancers suffer for their art, and the feet bear the brunt, writes Judith Mackrell
fields.trailText: They may look effortlessly graceful on stage, but dancers suffer for their art, and the feet bear the brunt, writes Judith Mackrell
fields.body:
Two hundred years ago, fashionable ballet circles took the view that dance movements executed below the waist were somehow more vulgar and less beautiful than those above. Legs and feet constituted the 'mechanical part' of the art, while the face and arms expressed its 'soul'.

Not surprisingly, this opinion hasn't lasted, for what most obviously distinguishes dance from the other performing arts is that it gets around on its feet. Music, singing, acting and reciting can all be done on the spot. Dance, uniquely, makes beauty out of covering ground, which is why dancers' feet are objects of such fascination.

The ballerina's foot, in particular, is a breed apart from the ordinary mortal's. Her pointed toe is a potent image of her erotic and exotic otherness. It is the miraculously fine base on which she balances, creating the gravity-defying illusion that allows her to transform into sylph, princess or superwoman. It is the exquisite instrument with which she articulates the detail of classical footwork, and it is the source of intense dramatic contrast - stabbing the floor, caressing the air, quivering with a kind of blind physical intelligence.

Yet it's also a valiantly hard-working body part. On this small, complex construction of bone, muscle and tendon the entire weight of the dancer frequently has to rest, and the foot pays a price. Professional dancers are usually loath to show them to outsiders, for the damage and distortion can be shocking.

Strip away the ballerina's satin slipper and you'll often find a mess of bunions, blisters, corns and crooked toes. Sarah Wildor, principal dancer with the Royal Ballet, says wistfully: 'My feet might have been quite nice if I hadn't been a dancer.' Her special source of martyrdom is the corns that grow between her toes, due to the pressure placed on the bones. She trims the corns to keep them under control, but she has 'a really horrible soft one, between the fourth and fifth toes' whose only effective treatment would be an operation to shave the bone.

If dancers' feet are studied through a medical scan, even worse damage becomes visible. Lucy Haith, head of physiotherapy at the Royal, says such a scan will show up all areas of potential or actual stress fracture to the bone and, while a normal person's should reveal none, a classical dancer's will typically reveal several. 'Dancers bear their weight through the tips of two toes - the big toe and the second toe - and obviously we weren't designed to do that,' she says. 'But stress fractures are caused not only by dancing on point but also by jumping. Athletes have highly designed shoes to absorb the shock of landing; dancers wear nothing to minimise the impact.' Add to this the frequent hazard of tendinitis (inflamed or swollen tendons) and you have a chiropodist's nightmare.

The Royal, like any sensible ballet company, doesn't encourage suffering. Dancers are instructed to get their feet, or any part of their body, looked at as soon as they feel any pain. Yet ever since Marie Taglioni and her early-19th-century sisters first hoisted themselves up on the tips of their toes, masochism has been part of the ballerina's image. We read with awe of Taglioni being drilled by her father to fainting point in order to master the technique of toe dancing, of Anna Pavlova exiting the stage and leaving a trail of bloody footprints.

In Taglioni's era, dancers didn't even have blocked shoes to support their endeavours, merely lines of darning to stiffen the toes of their slippers. Today's ballerinas have slightly more to stand on. The boxed toe of the modern shoe is constructed out of tightly packed layers of wadding and shellac that provides a tiny platform on which to balance. But while this greatly enhances the technical possibilities of pointwork, it doesn't magic away the pain.

Wildor admits that her feet are 'agony really. During a performance the pain is the last thing on my mind but when I come off stage my feet are killing me.'

Darcey Bussell agrees that 'you basically numb your mind to the pain'. She has an easier time than Wildor - 'I can go for up to three days without my feet really hurting' - but she has a nasty bunion, which she has to keep strapped up and frequently bleeds, and the inevitable blisters where her skin is rubbed raw.

For prepubescent ballet students the blood that's drawn from their first chafing, wobbling efforts to stand on point is, however, a mark of maturity. Bleeding blisters and bunions are the stigmata of the profession, and the most enthusiastic fans covet the worn, stained shoes in which a favourite dancer has performed.

So crucial is the ballerina's point shoe to her image that when early 20th-century choreographers rebelled against ballet they danced in bare feet. No longer shod in delicate satin, no longer poised in the act of flight, Martha Graham and other pioneers of modern dance proclaimed themselves women of the earth. Their bare feet were firmly on the floor, providing leverage for the dancers' bold, blunt, passionate moves. They were also styled in stark opposition to classical feet, flexed rather than pointed, placed parallel rather than turned out. For years, modern choreography was popularly referred to as barefoot dancing, for that naked, unadorned foot symbolised the emotional and physical frankness of the whole aesthetic.

In the 60s, when a new wave of minimalists aimed to democratise dance, the look of the foot was crucial. Graham's bare foot had a religious high tone about it, so 60s dancers wore sneakers and rarely stylised their feet into flexed or pointed shapes. The image was casual and functional. Then in the 80s, when choreographers invented the urban, gutsily physical style of Eurocrash, the Doc Marten became the footwear of choice. Dancers shod in these tough, clunky shoes could stamp and kick as hard as they liked, and the noise they made added dramatically to the energy of their moves.

Yet the use of the foot as percussive instrument is as old as dance itself. Black African dance, tap dance, clog dance, Irish dance, south Asian dance - all these genres work the feet as a drumming accompaniment. While ballet dancers aim for an otherworldy silence, many other dancers wear shoes to maximise their noise. The metal caps favoured by tap and Irish dance are contrived to rap out every shuffle, tap and stamp as loudly as possible - with productions such as Riverdance using a miked stage to intensify the sound.

Many south Asian dancers wear bells around their ankles for a similar effect, yet it's amazing how much sound they can produce from stamping out their percussive moves with bare feet. Choreographer Shobana Jeyasingh says that stamping is the wrong verb: 'What we do is more like clapping - we clap the air with our feet.' To do this correctly the feet have to be relaxed, so that they feel no pain. However, it requires a tremendous amount of power and some dancers suffer from fallen arches as a result. Others find knees and lower backs are affected by the strain.

In fact, they can't wear shoes at all. Most south Asian dance forms originated in the temples, where shoes were removed as a mark of respect. Even today, it's considered sacrilege to dance in shoes, and this ban gave Jeyasingh huge problems when her company took part in the grand parade in Paris marking the bicentenary of the French revolution. She couldn't let her dancers go barefoot down the Champs Elysées, yet she could hardly put them in trainers. She compromised by putting them in tiny slipperettes, which were camouflaged by patterns of henna.

When word got out in Indian dance circles, Jeyasingh was castigated by some diehard purists - and her dilemma oddly reverses that of revolutionary ballet choreographer Mikhail Fokine in 1907. He had created a ballet in which the dancers were to perform barelegged and barefoot, but the management of the Imperial Ballet in St Petersburg thought this such an affront to the dignity of the artform they forced the dancers into tights with toenails painted on.
Slippered or naked, pointed or flexed, the foot still has the power to bewitch and to shock. It is not only the defining image of different styles of dance - it is also the focus of dance's mystique.

webTitle: Have you got those back-to-work blues?

fields.headline: Have you got those back-to-work blues?
fields.standfirst: Try the best remedies the internet can offer
fields.trailText: 1. Did you wake up this morning and feel like running away?
fields.body:
1. Did you wake up this morning and feel like running away?

2. Chances are that your alarm clock and the cash nexus drove you back to work, despite the rain and gloom.

3. And to make things worse, there was no sign of the millennium bug, which everyone promised us would shutdown office computers for weeks.

4. Cheer up. There are worse jobs: you could be an English cricketer.

5. You have the blank canvas of the 21st century ahead of you. You could take up anything, from abseiling to zymurgy (but do something realistic: failing to give up chocolate will only depress you).

6. Change the way you work: upshift, downshift or retreat - to a nunnery.

7. Or make some resolutions for your boss to hold you to, such as: "Please do interrupt us while we are speaking on the telephone. We have two ears, so we might as well use both of them at the same time."

8. Thinking bigger and bolder, you could quit your job. Go to Kiss My Freckled Ass Bye and take this test. Just drafting an angry resignation letter might make you feel better.

9. But if you're really in the revolutionary mood, here's Bob Black: "Work is the source of nearly all the misery in the world. In order to stop suffering, we have to stop working."

10. One final tip: get back to work quick - your boss is looking over your shoulder.
